PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the Minister for Trade and Resources (Mr Anthony) left Australia yesterday to visit New Zealand for discussions on closer economic relations. The Vice-President of the Executive Council (Sir James Killen) is acting as Minister for Trade and Resources until Mr Anthony returns.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Notice of Motion

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act to provide for the recognition and enforcement of human rights in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer the Minister to the fact that 1,386 cases of discrimination have been dealt with by Mr Al Grassby, the Commissioner for Community Relations, in just over a year and that all of these cases have been dealt with by persuasion and negotiation. I ask: Is the Minister aware of the disquiet in the community at the reports that the appointment of Mr Grassby will not be renewed when it expires at the end of this month? Is he aware also that over 200 letters have recently been sent to the Prime Minister from South Australia alone, calling for the extension of Mr Grassby's term because of his experience, knowledge and talent in this area? In view of the excellent record of Mr Grassby, will the Government now renew his term?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I have no statement to make on behalf of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs with regard to the appointment held by Mr Grassby. I think it would be understood that it is the Attorney-General who is the Minister responsible for that appointment. I suggest that the question be put on notice and I will have the appropriate Minister respond to it .

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I made mention in my question of the fact that Mr Grassby's term expires this month. There are only four or five days to go until the end of the month. I wonder whether there is some more expeditious way of handling this matter than putting the question on notice.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will see that the matter is referred to the Minister and I will seek an early response to the questions raised by Senator Bolkus.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General. Is the Minister aware that video cassettes sold in Australia do not require any classification as do films that go into the general theatre/ cinema circuit in Australia? What can be done to prevent the purchase of these units by, say, children under 18 years of age?

—I do not know what method of censorship classification is adopted and what controls are put on the sale of video cassettes. I will have to refer that matter to the Acting Attorney-General for his reply.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Last week, in answer to a Dorothy Dix question by Senator Hill, the Minister affirmed that investment in South Australia under the Tonkin Liberal Government was 20 per cent of the national total. Is the Minister aware that no less a person than Mr John Stone disputed this figure? Does the Minister know that the investment figure is nearer 7.4 per cent? Does he also know that the investment figure includes projects which may or may not eventuate within the next five or six years? How can the Minister justify this deception of the Australian people? Is it not time that there was honesty in election advertising ?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it is time that there was honesty in election advertising, particularly the Australian Labor Party's claim that it is supporting Roxby Downs. I do not know what Mr Stone has said about figures. I do not recall the question that Senator Hill asked recently. I shall look at both matters and report to the Senate with a response. I am compiling a list of the projects that have been undertaken in South Australia. Contrary to Senator McLaren's statement that there were none, there have been many. I shall make the list available to the Senate as soon as it comes to hand.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Recent adverse media publicity has prompted the Australian Fisheries Council to agree that legislation should be urgently enacted to ensure that prosecutions for misrepresentation are possible in all States. What progress has been made towards bringing legislation into the parliaments? Is the Minister able to indicate the general thrust of the intended legislation?

—A meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council was held in Hobart within the last week or so. At that meeting Ministers endorsed recommendations that legislation be enacted to ensure that prosecutions for misrepresentation of fish are possible and, secondly, that legal status be given to a list of marketing names for fish. A draft list has been drawn up by the Australian Fishing Industry Council and will be finalised after comments are received from industry and government. I suspect that quite a lot of consumers will be pleased to hear about that, including the habitues of fish and chip shops, of whom I am one. Most of the legislation concerning the proper naming of fish is, unfortunately, not our responsibility, so we are not able directly to ensure that fish are correctly named. It is the responsibility of State and Territory authorities. But the Commonwealth has some legislative responsibility in the area. In particular, we are responsible for the naming of fish through the Customs Act, the Trade Practices Act and the Pure Foods Act of the Department of the Capital Territory. So the Minister for Primary Industry, following that Fisheries Council meeting, is writing to the relevant Commonwealth Ministers, drawing their attention to the recommendations and urging that they be given practical effect at the Commonwealth level, and no doubt that will be done.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact, as appears to be the case in South Australia at least, that Commonwealth Employment Service offices are not permitted to display or hand out pamphlets, information or posters from other government departments which outline the assistance available to unemployed people? Is it a fact, for example, that no Department of Social Security pamphlets or Department of Education information can be made available at CES offices and that the best that can be done is for officers there orally to suggest possible forms of assistance or other ways in which an unemployed person could better his or her chances of employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations would have to give some of the detailed information sought, but I am aware that the CES has over recent times tried to concentrate its attention on its primary function, which is facilitating entry to the work force. The administrative rearrangements which took place last year and which transferred to the Department of Social Security a good deal of the administrative responsibility for unemployment benefit and the various administrative requirements that relate to its payment were made with a view to trying to ensure that the CES could concentrate on its primary role. Of course, the CES tends to point to the number of job placements, both for employees generally and for special categories such as the disabled, as the true measure of its success and so on. I mention that because, if there is some restriction placed on the range of material available in CES offices, it would be, I am sure, on the basis that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations would not wish to see too much distraction from that primary role of those offices.

ANSWER.PARA: I am particularly conscious of the difficulty of information overload that can occur partly in the context of the sorts of requests which have been made to me over the last week by Senator Grimes on public radio and by the various Housing Ministers around Australia that the Government do more to advertise the benefits which are available to people in the sorts of programs mentioned by Senator Haines in her question and the programs which are administered by my Department and the Taxation Office to facilitate home ownership, to prevent hardship, to get people into employment and training and so on. I will refer the question for a more concise and precise reply from the Minister. But I make the point, in response to Senator Haines, that there is a very real difficulty for both departments and the Government in ensuring that the range of useful information which can be of benefit to citizens is made available. That is a matter which is certainly currently receiving my attention and the attention of other relevant Ministers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a question of the Minister representing the Minister for Health. I raise once again the matter of the labelling of foodstuffs, which is something I have raised here before and in which I believe a large percentage of the population has an interest. My question is prompted by an article in yesterday's Daily Telegraph-something that might have prompted Senator Missen's question of yesterday relating to sugar. That article states that a report is to be released next week that criticises the product labelling laws of Australia. The laws allow manufacturers to deceive us about the product contents. Will the Minister once again ask the National Health and Medical Research Council to expedite the requirement to label products and show particularly the amount of sugar and salt in a product? If the Council cannot influence the States to speed up their action, perhaps the Minister for Health should make labelling compulsory in the Australian Capital Territory because I think that would force manufacturers to take some action. If they have nothing to hide, why do they not do that?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Missen asked me a question yesterday and in the answer I gave considerable detail about the kinds of procedures which are now under way through the National Health and Medical Research Council, through its committees, through negotiations between the Council and the States, through the publications which are being distributed and through the availability of educational and informative material. It may not be necessary to go through all that again as it is in Hansard. What comes out of it, of course, is that the basic legislative responsibility rests with the States--
—Not in the Australian Capital Territory.

—I will come to the Australian Capital Territory in a moment because I think the honourable senator has raised a relevant point there. We are trying to provide the information and encouragement for the States to move in ways which they see as appropriate in the light of the situation as it is demonstrated to be as a result of surveys and the collection of information. We will continue to go down that road. Through the working parties we will continue to assist the States in taking reasonable and responsible steps to do certain kinds of things, such as considering labelling and considering regulating the content of some foodstuffs with the aim of enhancing and protecting the health of their citizens.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Townley asks particularly whether we should not be taking a more prescriptive and aggressive role in the Australian Capital Territory. I am not able to commit Mr Carlton on that point. I think it is proper that the question is put to him and that we seek from him a response as to what is being done in the Australian Capital Territory to promote the same things as we are urging upon the States, and I will do that for Senator Townley.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Education: When can universities expect government approval for the superannuation scheme for Australian universities? Can they expect government funding of 2 1/2 per cent towards the cost of the scheme? Given that universities have been waiting for this decision for over six months and are not able to make effective plans in this area until a decision is reached, will the Minister explain the reasons for the long delay and the nature of any problems that still stand in the way of the approval?

—There have been some problems with superannuation arrangements in higher education institutions in Australia, as a result of which the institutions have opened up discussions with the Government to see whether we would endorse and help them introduce a new scheme-the superannuation scheme for Australian universities-which might be better based in actuarial terms and which might meet their needs better. A fair amount of negotiation has been necessary to get that scheme worked out, particularly as to some of the more detailed parts. What is emerging is a proposal that there should be a scheme with the employers putting in 14 per cent of salary and the academics or those entering the scheme putting in 7 per cent of salary. A number of the details at the margin were, until recently, still under negotiation. I advise Senator McIntosh that I have this week been in contact orally with the Chairman of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee, Professor Caro. We may not be able to get all the details finally worked out. Rather than hold the scheme up, it has been suggested to Professor Caro that the Committee might be able to amend the proposal slightly for the moment and get the scheme into operation. The remaining item or two that require further negotiation and consideration by government could be set aside for further discussion later. Like Senator McIntosh, we want to see the scheme in operation . The Government has made an appropriate allowance of a small amount of money that will be required to help the universities should the scheme start. We have allowed money for 1983 and 1984 for this purpose.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Martin Sen K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to a report in today's Sydney Morning Herald which quotes the Prime Minister as saying:

QUESTION.PARA: I'm seriously thinking of putting to my colleagues again the referendum that we only just lost several years ago in which half the Senate would come out for election every time the House of Representatives went for an election,' . . .
'That would prevent the Senate and the House of Representatives getting out of line . . .

Is it a fact that this referendum proposal has already been defeated twice by the Australian people-in 1974 when proposed by the Whitlam Government and again in 1977, not 1976 as stated in the Sydney Morning Herald article, when it was proposed by the Fraser Government? Does the Leader of the Government agree that there are alternative constitutional amendments which could have the effect of adjusting Senate terms, following a double dissolution, to avoid the necessity for yet another early Federal election two years after a double dissolution? Will he undertake to outline these alternatives to the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did see in the newspaper a reported comment of the Prime Minister with regard to the possibility of a further referendum to bring the two Houses into line in the event of a double dissolution. It is true that this proposition has been put to the people of Australia on several occasions. My recollection is that it was very narrowly defeated last time. I think a very substantial majority of Australians were in support of it. I would be interested to look at alternative constitutional proposals. I would be very happy to have information that Senator Martin may have. Perhaps she will discuss it with me. I would be very happy to bring that material to the attention of the Prime Minister. I think nobody in Australia wants to have a situation in which separate Senate elections are held as we had during the 1960s, which gave a continuity of elections to the Australian people.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Communications aware that the secretariat of the National Party is sending to regional television stations on video tape items which can only be described as propaganda for screening on these stations? Are these stations screening this material without identifying its source? If they are, will he instruct the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to request these stations, as a matter of course, to identify this material and any other material from political or commercial sources, as is required by the Broadcasting and Television Act? Will he also confer with the Australian Journalists Association and people involved in the industry to get their reaction to this practice by the National Party which has developed in the last few weeks?

—I do not intend to make an ex parte judgment on any matter. Senator Button has advanced certain propositions which would require testing. There is no doubt that the various statutes require the identification of certain kinds of material; in that regard I believe Senator Button is correct. As to whether or not material which falls within that classification is being issued and thus requires identification, and if it is, whether or not such material is or is not being identified, I can make no comment.
—I am telling you.

—Senator Button says that he is telling me. In the circumstances, it would be proper for Senator Button to advise the Government of the material concerned and the instances of which he speaks. I will pass his question to Mr Brown, who I know would want to ensure that the statutes under his administration were being properly applied. It would be appropriate for the Government to look at the material to which Senator Button is referring and ascertain whether his assertions are correct.

—Has the Minister representing the Treasurer noted an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 October relating to the recent consumer price index figures and detailing certain costs but omitting such costs as electricity and so on? Could the Minister inform the Senate how these figures are arrived at , who decides which costs are included in the basket and whether the Australian Bureau of Statistics could publish a detailed analysis of all costs included in the calculation of the CPI and explain which are influenced by State or Federal government decisions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I do not know whether the Treasurer has seen the article referred to by Senator Lajovic. The Australian Statistician decides the composition of the basket of commodities which he measures for the consumer price index. A fair amount of information is published by him when he announces CPI changes. I do not know whether the precise information required by the honourable senator has been made publicly available. If it has, I will see that he is advised. If not, I will ask the Treasurer to respond to the various elements of the honourable senator's question.

—Can the Minister representing the Prime Minister inform the Parliament whether it is a fact that an artist has been commissioned to paint a portrait of the Prime Minister? Is a fee of $10,000 to be paid to the artist? If not, what is the amount of the fee? Who is the artist? Who authorised the painting of the portrait? Why was such a commission authorised at a time when Australia is facing a deep economic depression and the money could be better spent elsewhere?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have any such details but I should, if what the honourable senator outlines has happened, because it would have been as a result of a commissioning by a committee from both sides of the Parliament, one on which the Labor Party would have been represented. Therefore, any such decision would have been made with the approval of that party. As you would know , Mr President, that is the normal procedure in the commissioning of portraits. I am without factual knowledge of the matter. I can only outline the normal procedures and undertake to ascertain whether there is any substance in the honourable senator's statements and let him know.

—I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations whether he can inform the Senate of the percentage increase in salary that has already been granted to public servants in this financial year. Has the Minister as yet any information on the further increases that are proposed by public service unions? Since the Government has proposed that increases to members of parliament be kept strictly within a 7 per cent limit, does the Minister consider that any increase over 7 per cent to the rest of the public sector is justified in the present economic climate? Will the Government use its powers to limit increases to public servants in this financial year to not more than 7 per cent?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Hamer has asked me a series of questions relating to Public Service remuneration. The question is perhaps even broader than it sounded because, of course, the expression 'public servants' covers a fair variety of employees. The clerical, administrative, keyboard and related groups received pay increases in the range of 5.8 per cent and 6.6 per cent awarded by a Full Bench of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission with effect from the first pay period on or after 2 August 1982. That is one group of public servants . Another group, the physical and technical grades, received increases endorsed by the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission of the order of $25 a week plus $ 14 a week mid-term adjustment for tradesmen with different proportionate increases applying to other classifications. They were to take effect from 8 April and 3 June for the different categories. Those changes reflected variations in the metal and building industries outside the Public Service.

ANSWER.PARA: Pay rises of between 6.5 per cent and 7 per cent from 23 September 1982 are awaiting endorsement by the Public Service Arbitrator for those professional groups of public servants; that is, legal officers, engineers, scientists and so on. Statutory office holders received a 7 per cent increase with effect from 1 July 1982. So, overall, the percentage pay rise for the mass of the Public Service this year is somewhere around 6 per cent to 7 per cent. In no case is there to be further consideration of increases this year. But the clerical officers have already lodged an application for a further increase to take effect from next February, which is the expiration of the six months during which it was said that no further increases would apply. That claim is in hand and has yet to be dealt with.

As far as any question of the power of the Commonwealth is concerned, it will be well known to honourable senators that the Commonwealth has consistently, before the various wage-fixing tribunals to which it has access, asserted that there should be wage moderation. We had a fair amount of discussion in the Senate yesterday on the reasoning behind that. It is certainly the belief of the Government that in a time of some economic difficulty an expansion of the incomes of currently employed people can be only at the expense of those who are not in employment and indeed of those who will lose employment. What is likely to be granted is a matter for arbitration if no agreement can be reached. But it should be pointed out that the Commonwealth cannot insulate itself and its employees from the general Australian scene. The Commonwealth has tried to be consistent in its approach to wages across the board. It would not seek to impose a harshness of rule upon its employees that was not imposed upon the community generally. I emphasise that the wage restraint which we have urged before arbitral tribunals considering the wage rises of public servants is based on the same arguments that we have advanced with respect to broader or other areas of wages. I also wish to stress that the Government understands the need to be fair to its employees but it consistently believes that wage restraint is a very important element of economic policy in Australia in 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to a warning issued by two eminent Australian scientists urging the Federal Government to disallow French interests to become involved in the Australian uranium industry? Since the warning has come from a former scientist with the British Atomic Energy Commission, Mr Bob Robotham, and Monash University physicist, Dr Don Hutton, who claim that Australia's credibility in the Pacific region would be compromised if French interest in Australian uranium was encouraged, will the Minister examine the ramifications of this warning and the possible effects on Australia's reputation with its Pacific neighbours?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not seen the article. Perhaps Senator Jones will let me have a copy of it. I will certainly put it under study. Australia's reputation within the Pacific and elsewhere in the world on the question of nuclear matters stands as high as or higher than that of any other nation. We have established rules for safeguards and those rules are the most stringent in the world. We are active members of the International Atomic Energy Agency and we maintain our own safeguards provisions very strongly indeed. We will uphold the nuclear non-proliferation situation. We are strongly against the proliferation of nuclear weapons. We are opposed to the testing of nuclear weapons. We have taken that stand in relation to Mururoa and elsewhere. In any commercial undertaking that was involved in uranium we would apply all those principles, irrespective of the nation involved. If there were any question that a nation would be likely to be in breach of those provisions we simply would not have commercial intercourse with the nation. I will look at the report and put it under study.

—Is the Minister representing the Prime Minister aware of a report in this morning's Press of a speech made by Mr Ian Prentice, a member of the Legislative Assembly in the Queensland Parliament, expressing grave concern that the Queensland Government does not have a register of foreign ownership of land in that State and that the Premier of Queensland, Mr Bjelke-Petersen, is the strongest opponent of setting up such a register? Can the Minister inform the Senate as to what powers the Commonwealth Government does have to insist that a register of foreign ownership of land in Australia is kept, considering that there is grave concern throughout the community that we do not know what land is owned by what foreign companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of times in the last year or two honourable senators have raised in the Senate, as Senator Bonner has done today, the question of foreign ownership of land. I have made the point that the only government that can take action to maintain a register of foreign ownership of land and keep it up to date is a State government. The Commonwealth, through its Foreign Investment Review Board, can as a primary matter look to the directionalism of capital when it flows into Australia and could take certain steps if it felt that the direction of that money was against Australian interests in terms of ownership, but it could not follow that through after a series of secondary uses of that money. The conveyancing of land and its title to ownership is entirely a State matter. Therefore, it is a matter for each of the States to look at the ownership of resources in those States. I will bring the general question to the attention of the Treasurer, who has the responsibility for FIRB, but substantially what I have said is the situation.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN GOVERNMENT PUBLISHING SERVICE: LEASING OF BOOKSHOPS

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. It relates to the proposed leasing of the Australian Government Publishing Service bookshops to the private sector. I ask: What is the current state of arrangements to lease the bookshops and what procedures are being carried out with regard to the staff employed by the bookshops? Have staff and their representative unions been fully advised of the current state of negotiations to lease the bookshops and have they been fully advised of their employment or redeployment rights and options if and when the leasing goes ahead? I appreciate that the Minister may not have that information readily available, but I draw attention to the fact that in reply to a question asked by Senator McIntosh in August of this year it was stated that the future employment prospects of the employees had been discussed. I have a letter from the Australian Public Service Association dated 14 October which states:

QUESTION.PARA: The members do not know anything regarding the tendering of the Bookshops . . . There has been no discussions to date with the present staff regarding redeployment.

I think the Minister will appreciate that people's concern about jobs today is very much uppermost in their minds. I wonder whether the Minister would kindly undertake to have the matter clarified because there appears to be a discrepancy between the answers given and the statements by the union.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I do appreciate the concerns of Senator Gietzelt, the union he represents and the concerns it put forward in the letter. I will undertake to refer the matter to the Minister and seek an early reply for Senator Gietzelt.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: DEPARTMENT OF DEFENCE: PROPOSED TRAINING AREA

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. In June this year it became known to the shires of Exmouth and Carnarvon that the Department of Defence was considering using a large part of the coastline in that area for an amphibious landing, a gunnery and a bombing training area. This caused considerable concern because the matter had not been discussed with the shires and also because the coastline is important for tourism. Also, part of that coastline is being considered for designation as a marine park. I understand that Mr Sinclair met with representatives of at least one of the shires last weekend during the northern Australian development seminar. Can the Minister inform the Senate of the outcome of those discussions? Will the Minister point out to the Minister he represents that the Shire of Derby is happy for an area near that town to be used for these exercises in conjunction with the proposed Air Force base at Derby?
—Who has got the brief?

—Unfortunately, I do not have the brief. I am not aware of the particular concerns Senator Thomas evidenced in his question, nor of the discussions that apparently took place, according to his assertions, last week at Port Hedland. I would need to refer that matter to the Minister for Defence and see whether I can obtain a reply for the honourable senator. As to the broader concerns and the direction of progress of development of a field practice range or whatever in that area, I would need to bring to the Minister's attention the concerns evidenced by Senator Thomas and those of the local shires he is seeking to represent.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security a question regarding the payment of special benefit to sick people denied sickness benefit. Why is the income test the most severe of any test for pensioners or beneficiaries? Why are they not allowed to have any other income without losing dollar for dollar? Even a $1 bank interest on savings results in a reduction in benefit. How are such beneficiaries expected to pay for essential medication?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I outlined in the Senate yesterday, because of the ruling that section 108 of the Social Services Act requires a person to have lost income because of sickness before qualifying for sickness benefit, the present position is that in cases where a person was not in receipt of income and had therefore not lost income because of illness, sickness benefit cannot be paid. That is a legal matter. In the past there has been a differing view of that section but it seems quite clear that that is what the law requires. To ensure that this does not give rise to hardship, pending examination of whether there should be any change to section 108, as I indicated to the Senate yesterday, special benefit will be paid to people in those circumstances under terms which are more generous than those usually applying to special benefit. In particular, a test will not be applied on the basis of available cash resources. Normally special benefit is not available to people who have money in the bank or in some other form which is available for their maintenance. Instead the payment of special benefit in those circumstances would be subject to an income test only. The amount of special benefit payable, which would be the same as the amount of sickness benefit, would be reduced for any other personal income the person might have. The reason for that is that in fact it is a more generous provision than is usually applied. It is applied because of the history of the availability of sickness benefit.

ANSWER.PARA: On the purchase of medication, any person on a low income is entitled to obtain health card cover and any person who is entitled to benefit under these circumstances undoubtedly would be eligible for health card cover. That position should be covered for any person who is in the circumstances raised by the honourable senator. The question of the availability of benefit generally is one on which I think there could be some differences of opinion. If people were not in receipt of income-for example, if they were housewives, students, or something similar-and fell sick their financial position really would be little different from the position they were previously in. If they have available to them cash resources some might argue that the taxpayer ought not be called upon in those circumstances.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations: What percentage of young people employed under the Government's Special Youth Employment Training Program in Tasmania has been employed in private industry? Is the number increasing relative to the public sector intake?
—He just happens to have that information.

—I did have that information but I seem to have lost it. It is just another one of those cases in which Senator Grimes is not always right. My recollection, having made some inquiries into the matter, is that in the financial year 1981-82 the percentage of those receiving the Special Youth Employment Training Program benefit employed in the private sector was 87 per cent. In the first quarter of this financial year it has risen to 89 per cent. There has been a relatively small shift in the figure but the shift is in favour of private employment under that scheme.
—As a supplementary question, can the Minister indicate whether the number is increasing, relative to the public sector? He said it was, but is it a general increase?

—I feel a bit like Bob Hawke addressing a youth audience in Perth when he said: 'I have obviously got communication problems. You don't understand what I am saying'. I am sorry, Mr President, I thought I had indicated that in fact there had been a shift-my recollection was from 87 per cent to 89 per cent- in favour of the private sector. I meant that to indicate that by definition that would mean a reduction in the public sector, a drift from 13 per cent to 11 per cent of public sector employment.
—Ipso facto.
—Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle has just helpfully thrown in ' ipso facto'. So, ipso facto, I think I will sit down.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer her to the Treasurer's statement of 27 August this year in which he announced the Government's intention to legislate against tax avoidance by means of Eagle bonds and other forms of fixed interest investments masquerading as life insurance policies. I ask: When will that legislation be introduced? What will be its commencement date? Further I ask: Does the Minister recall that when I raised this matter in the Senate on 27 November 1980 I was told by Senator Durack that 'the matter has been under consideration'? I received similar assurances from her on 8 September and 29 October last year. Why then did the Treasurer attempt to mislead the Parliament by saying in his statement of 27 August that it is only recently that this tax exemption has been exploited for tax avoidance purposes when he has known about it for two years or more? Finally, how can the Treasurer and the Government claim to be actively combating tax avoidance when, after two years, the Government has still not moved to block this blatant form of tax avoidance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I am sorry that information has not been given in response to the earlier questions raised by Senator Evans on this matter. As I understand it, no relevant legislation is ready for introduction in this session of Parliament. As has been stated by the Treasurer, it is a matter that has been under consideration. If the Treasurer wants to make any comment on the matter of the timing of the introduction of legislation I will see that it is passed on to the honourable senator. As to the claims that the Government has not been active on tax avoidance and other matters, I think in this place on a number of occasions lists have been produced of the number of amendments that have been made over recent years to close the tax avoidance schemes that had been perpetrated. This matter has had the attention of the Treasurer who is directing his efforts towards necessary legislation. But I am not aware of the precise date on which it will be introduced. I will see what information I can get.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, concerns the effect that the diesel fuel rebate scheme is having on the tourist industry. Is the Minister aware of results of a survey of caravan parks that show that in Queensland alone it is estimated that in excess of 75 per cent of caravan parks are using distillate as a method of water heating? Does the Minister agree that the removal of exemptions from this tax may lead to serious cost increases in an industry which, even though providing the lowest cost forms of accommodation, must still work to restrain costs to compete? Following the passage of the legislation in the Senate earlier this week, could the Minister advise whether there is any possibility of consideration being given to the inclusion of the tourist industry, and particularly caravan parks, in the rebate scheme?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that various industries which have not received the exemption from the diesel fuel excise feel that they are hindered by that and regard that as a disadvantage. I am really indebted to a number of government senators and, in particular, to Senator Collard who, in the debate on this measure in the Senate on Tuesday, pointed out that this is a revenue raising measure and as such the impost does have to fall somewhere. It is unfortunately true that the wider the exemptions one provides for any form of taxation, but certainly excise, by definition the more heavily it has to fall on the remainder of the community to raise any given amount of revenue. One could go on, as indeed the debate in the Senate on Tuesday indicated, endlessly suggesting further exemptions. But if one is to raise the revenue which is sought it is necessary to impose taxes to do so.

ANSWER.PARA: The tourist industry is one that has received considerable attention from the Government over recent years. I think the industry has grown very steadily. It has been assisted greatly by the fact that it, of all industries, I think, was first given assistance in terms of depreciation of buildings. That significant encouragement to the industry was certainly widely welcomed. If we look at the figures for building in the tourist industry it is clear that it certainly was beneficial.

The particular section of the tourist industry to which Senator Bjelke-Petersen refers, the caravan parks, is of course a section of the industry which will benefit from the Government's move to improve the national road network and indeed, not least in her State of Queensland, I think there will be significant advantages if there is a significant upgrading of the national roads as will now occur under the Government's program.

In response to the final part of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question, whilst it could never be said that laws cannot be changed and so the possibility of the widening of the exemption is present as a possibility, I would not hold out a great deal of hope for that. I would rather direct the attention of the honourable senator and through her direct the attention of her constituents to other steps which the Government has taken to try to ensure that the tourist industry is able to advance and prosper in Australia. I believe that in general under the recently retired Minister, Sir Phillip Lynch, the industry has received close and favourable attention. I am sure that will continue under Mr Andrew Peacock's administration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Prime Minister to the report in this week's Newsweek magazine of an interview with the joint winner of the 1982 Nobel Peace Prize, Mrs Alva Myrdal of Sweden, in which she contends that smaller nations can play a very concrete role in the quest for disarmament. In this context, what is the Fraser Government doing to encourage world disarmament? In addition, why has it been necessary for the Australian President of the United Nations Association, Dr Keith Suter, to claim, as he did in yesterday's Australian, that this country is being acutely embarrassed by the Fraser Government's failure to pledge funds to the United Nations world disarmament campaign?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Commonwealth Government would agree entirely with the premise, whether stated by the Nobel Prize winner or anyone else, that smaller nations can play a significant role in world disarmament and that they should. Indeed, the Fraser Government's aim is to play such a role in every avenue in which it can, because it is implacably opposed to world armament, to nuclear armament and to any insensate move towards war. It plays an active role in the United Nations and all its agencies. It has taken a very active part in moves for multilateral nuclear disarmament. That is the primary key to the situation. Wherever there is such a cause, people will find the Australian Government putting its arguments with force. The real problem that all peace- keepers face is that peace, in itself, whilst a very significant goal, must be peace with dignity, freedom and justice associated with it. Senator Georges would agree with that. I accept the sincerity and objectivity of his question.

ANSWER.PARA: However, as other nations have armed, and armed strongly, there must be a substantial measure of defensive armament in this atmosphere. That is the tragedy of the world. Even Bertrand Russell, in the end, could not insist that unilateral disarmament or unilateral conscientious objection had any role. Whilst I understand the philosphical viewpoint, the practical one is that, if there is an aggressor and that aggressor should move, it is necessary to have some defence. Otherwise, one would not need a police force in one's domestic situation.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is getting away from the question. Why is not the Australian Government supporting the United Nations by providing funds?

—I am not aware that it is not doing so. I did not seek to get away from the question. I thought that the question was a profoundly interesting one and that it deserved a detailed answer. As to the funding of a particular association, I do not have that detail. I shall seek it out and let Senator Georges know.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Aviation. Is it a fact that the following airlines -Air Zimbabwe, Air Botswana, Air Malawi, Lesotho Airways, Royal Swazi Air, Zambia Airways and Air Mauritius, from countries regarded as black African nations, conduct passenger services which take in South Africa? I refer the Minister to a reply that he gave me to another question on 17 February this year, when he said that Qantas Airways Ltd should be granted greater flexibility to set fares in accordance with market conditions. Does the Government believe that the same commercial independence should be accorded to Qantas in deciding what routes would be most profitable to it, including, if it so decided, a service to South Africa? Does the Minister agree that, as South African Airways has flown a South Africa-Australia service for many years, Qantas should not be prevented from also participating in this profitable passenger run?

—Over time the Government has made its position concerning Qantas services to South Africa abundantly clear. The Government does not consider it appropriate for Qantas to resume services to South Africa. In effect, it has told Qantas to consider other alternatives. Along those lines commercial considerations are coming into play. As Senator Crichton-Browne has identified, profitable opportunities are available in the African service. It is clear that alternatives do exist. To that end, discussions were held recently with the Zimbabwean Government about the establishment of a direct route to Harare from Australia. Any decision in relation to that service would be one for Qantas to make in the light of all commercial circumstances. As I understand it, Qantas is undertaking that very process at the moment. I have made it clear in the reply I have now given that Qantas is free to operate as it deems commercially acceptable on the African continent in respect of markets that it perceives, but the Government's position concerning the direct service to South Africa remains.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Is it not a fact that Qantas has been allowed to fly between Australia and Zimbabwe to permit it to attract part of the profitable route between Australia and South Africa and that this is a back door method of allowing a passenger service into South Africa?

—There are opportunities all over the African continent for a service into Zimbabwe. Clearly they will be opened up by a service conducted by Qantas. South Africa is not the only country in Africa with which Australia does business in various ways and other opportunities will be available in other parts of the African continent.

—My question is directed to you, Mr President. I refer to the resolution of the Senate dated 26 November 1981 concerning the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Parliament's Appropriations and Staffing. What stage has been reached with the transfer from the Executive departments to the Senate of the administration of the responsibilities and functions relating to senators?

—In response to that question I can say only that discussions are continuing. Progress is definitely being made, but rather than rush in and make mistakes we are making sure that when the transfer takes place it will be done properly.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to a report tabled in the Northern Development Seminar at Port Hedland last week by an officer of the Marine Operations Branch of the Coastal Services Division which indicated that last year 600 reports were debriefed, which included 130 reports of foreign fishing vessel activity, 70 reports on aircraft and 115 reports on small craft, et cetera. Is it the intention of the Government to step up northern surveillance? Is a report correct that some aspects of aircraft surveillance are to cease in the north? Will the Minister table a comprehensive statement on overall northern surveillance?

—Apart from the information which Senator Kilgariff seeks, very real questions of policy are intertwined with the points he has made. Therefore, I would need to refer the matter to the Minister for Defence and obtain a reply for him. I undertake to do that as quickly as possible.

—I ask the Minister representing the Acting Attorney-General whether any action has been taken by either the Attorney-General or his Department on the comments of Magistrate Brown in the so-called social security fraud case in Sydney many months ago about the conduct of former Detective Inspector Thomas. The Minister will remember that at that time the magistrate made extremely critical comments, suggesting that Detective Inspector Thomas had indulged in perjury and similar offences, and announced that he was referring his comments to the Attorney-General. It is now five or six months since that statement was made. Can the Minister say just what action will be taken?
—I will refer that question to the Acting Attorney-General and seek his reply.

—My question, which is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry and Commerce, concerns the problems of the Australian steel industry and the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd. Is it not a fact that BHP helped Pohang Steel in Korea to set up its current modern plant which has, in effect, made Australian steel uncompetitive, so that we can conclude that BHP has the necessary expertise as to the nature of a plant which would be necessary to become competitive again? Has BHP acknowledged publicly or to the Government that the future of the Australian steel industry lies with the modernisation of its plant to at least the same standard as Pohang Steel? Finally, has BHP acknowledged publicly or to the Government that it will take advantage of the generous accelerated plant depreciation allowances in the current Budget which were tailored to allow modernisation of major industries such as the Australian steel industry?

—It is my understanding-I confirm that it is no more than an under - standing-that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd was involved in the establishment of that Korean plant. I have little doubt that BHP does have a very high level of technical expertise and the technical expertise to run a modern steel industry. Indeed, it is, running a very substantial steel industry on any world standards. Again, I have heard no argument which would suggest that Senator Lewis is wrong when he puts forward the view that the future lies in modernisation of plant. I have seen no acknowledgment by BHP of the value of the recent alterations to the depreciation provisions. I am not saying that BHP has not given any public indication, but I am not familiar with any. It is certainly true that the Government, in altering the approach to depreciation, has endeavoured to provide Australian industry with a clearly understandable and workable system of depreciation which will encourage the sort of capital investment which is essential if we are to have modern industries in Australia. So I will ask the Minister for Industry and Commerce to consider the series of questions raised by Senator Lewis. I would also wish to say that I think that many of the points he made are semi-axiomatic and a further reply from the Minister may not be necessary.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 20 October Senator McLaren asked me a question without notice concerning industry development in South Australia. I undertook to seek out the names of companies that had come to South Australia during the term of office of the Tonkin Government. It will be recalled that an interjection from the Australian Labor Party was: There were none. I now provide the following information.
—The other interjection was: How many have left?

—I will pick up the interjection: 'How many have left? ' The annual reports of the South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission show that in 1979-1980 and in 1980-81-that is two of the three years of the Tonkin Government-nearly 7,000 new companies registered in South Australia.
—How many went to the bottom of the harbour?

—We will come to that. No doubt Senator Robert Ray would know. After all, it was the painters and dockers who provided the residua for that. I am delighted to have these interjections because each of them will have a dusty answer for the Australian Labor Party. I repeat that in the first two years some 7,000 new companies were registered in South Australia. The 1981 -82 figures are not yet available. The number of companies actually on the register increased in one year from 39,041 in June 1980 to 41,570 in June 1981, an increase of some 6.5 per cent. So there was a very substantial net increase in the number of companies. So far I am dealing with companies that have actually been established.
—On a point of order--

—I suggest that the honourable senator permit the Leader of the Government to answer a serious question that was asked by another honourable senator. I hope that the Senate will give the Leader an opportunity to respond in relation to the figures. There is no point of order, Senator Bolkus. I have ruled--

—I suggest that you do not know whether there is or is not. My point of order was to be that the Minister had been asked to provide information. He has gone on to argue the point. I asked him to table the information.
—There is no point of order. The Minister was asked a question concerning, or challenged to supply, certain figures. He is in the process of responding with the figures and associated comments.
—During which he has encouraged interjections.
—I am asking that interjections cease.

—I make it clear that these figures relate to the first two of the three years involved. They show that there are 7,000 new companies and that in one year there has been an actual increase of 6.5 per cent in the total number of companies. The identification and naming of each of the new companies that have come to South Australia over the past three years would require the commitment of very substantial resources indeed. However, I have obtained from South Australia's Department of Trade and Industry a list comprising 84 major manufacturing projects, with total project costs amounting to more than $250m, which have been completed in South Australia since October 1979. In a moment I will seek the incorporation of details of those 84 major projects. I repeat, they represent projects that have been completed. Of course , they do not take into account the very substantial developments that are now taking place. They do not take into account the developments associated with the Stony Point-Cooper Basin pipeline or the foreshadowed refinery. They do not take into account the moves to establish Roxby Downs and other mineral interests. Therefore, taken together, they more than confirm the evidence that the Tonkin Government has achieved the attracting of very substantial industry to South Australia. I repeat, the details cover only two of the three years involved. I seek leave to have the list incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Lewis asked me a question with regard to certain statements by one Colonel Langtry in connection with the defence industrial structure in Australia and drew attention to certain deficiencies. I now have a reply for Senator Lewis. There are a great many types of aluminium and steel alloys used in defence equipment. Australia manufactures only those for which sufficient demand exists to enable them to be produced with reasonable economy. Some quite sophisticated alloys are in fact produced, including electroslag refined steel used, for example, in making gearboxes. We do not produce special alloys used in small quantities, for obvious economic reasons, but this is not to say that the capacity to do so does not exist if the need arises. The Department of Defence Support is conscious of the need to assist industry in respect of special defence needs. Typically, a project to develop high strength HY80 steel used in warship and submarine hulls is currently in progress.

ANSWER.PARA: A similar answer applies to composite materials and petrochemical products. In peacetime we manufacture those products which are reasonably economic but the basic capabilities exist to develop and produce a wider range of products if economy becomes subservient to special exigencies. Australia does not presently make a very wide range of general purpose machine tools for the same economic reasons as have been outlined. Nonetheless, there are more than 90 companies which presently receive the machine tool bounty. Several companies are producing complex machining centres with computer control. Many more companies currently engaged in other work could produce machine tools given the need. A review of the defence mobilisation of Australian industry along World War II lines has not been carried out in recent times because it would not be a very meaningful exercise except in very specific areas. Our current defence industry policy concentrates on achieving a balance between the possible need for reliable overseas supply lines, the stockpiling of spares and critical items and the selective development of specific capabilities in industry. Our needs in this direction are kept under constant review by the Department and also by the Defence Industry Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation concerning statements yesterday made about me by Senator Jones. I would have preferred the opportunity to make a personal explanation yesterday but I was not in the chamber when Senator Jones made his comments and, of course , I had no knowledge that he was about to launch an attack on me. It seemed to me more appropriate that, rather than use hearsay evidence of comments made yesterday, I should wait until this morning to have the opportunity to read Hansard and to know exactly what he said. In effect, he accused me of lying and I regard that as a very serious attack on my reputation. I was not forewarned of it in any way. I heard as secondhand evidence that I had been virtually called a liar in this place by Senator Jones. He knows that I am making a personal explanation this morning because I sent him a note to inform him that I intended to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: The matter under discussion relates to funds spent by the Federal Government on sport in this country. The Australian of 6 October, referring to Senator Jones, stated:
He also discovered that if you want to be a sports star in this country the first step should be to move to Canberra where nearly half of the federal sports funds are spent.

Of course, the fact is that nearly half of those funds are spent on the Australian Institute of Sport which is a national facility located in Canberra, which is, of course, the appropriate place for it to be located. Those funds are not spent on Canberra. About $7m of those funds was spent this year on the swimming and tennis complex; in other words, on capital developments; and $4m on the Institute itself.

It is true that there are a few Canberra students on scholarships at the Institute, but most students come from the States. It is totally misleading of Senator Jones to suggest that to move to Canberra is the way to get into the Australian Institute of Sport. If students want to get into the Institute of Sport-young sportsmen and women in this country should know this and not allow themselves to be misled in this way-they have to become proficient and show expertise and potential in their state. It is from their State that they apply for a scholarship to the Institute. Moving to Canberra will not assist them to get in unless they have those qualities and they apply in their State. It is best for young people to know the facts.

Of course, the sort of Canberra bashing that this implies is something that we have become accustomed to from the Australian Labor Party. I am sure that everyone in Canberra remembers that the 'fat cats' comment was started by a colleague of Senator Jones, Mr Clyde Cameron. That was made some years ago but we have long memories and we know exactly what the Australian Labor Party had in mind at that time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to you, Senator, that you are digressing very broadly at present with regard to a personal explanation. I suggest that you bring your remarks back to it.

—To return to that, I have made some comments to try to explain what Senator Jones was doing. Yesterday in this place he virtually accused me of lying. As I said, I regard that as a very serious attack on my reputation and I wanted to make this explanation to the Senate. I do not accept that as an explanation of my conduct on this or any other issue.

—by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation in response to the statement made by Senator Reid. The explanation made by Senator Reid is far from the truth. If she had read the Press release instead of taking note of a Press report, in which certain matters stated were not quoted by me, she would find that what she said in her statement in the Canberra Standard was totally untrue. What she should do is go back to Hansard and read the report so that she is well aware of the facts. I have forwarded a letter to the Australian Institute of Sport, the Canberra Standard and my solicitor, because I believe the terms used by Senator Reid in her public outburst were quite unfair and unwarranted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I wish to make a personal explanation regarding some remarks made after the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory brought down a report in this place last Thursday on retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory. The report consisted of three major sections. One was a large section, being the main report of the Committee, then there was a dissenting report which was supported by Mrs Kelly, Mr Fry and myself, and a further dissenting report which was submitted by Senator Georges. Last Thursday evening, I happened to be listening to the Australian Broadcasting Commission local radio news which went on air at about 10 minutes past 7. I heard some disparaging comments about those who submitted the dissenting report. I have not been able to obtain a transcript of that program. The Parliamentary Library does not record that program and I was not able to obtain a transcript from the ABC. However, I did obtain a transcript of the ABC television news of that evening. The Parliamentary Library does tape that program.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to quote from some parts of the transcript. The program went on air at 6 .55 p.m. A person called Ron Miller, among other things, said:

The Committee recommended that all Canberra stores be allowed to stay open six days a week, but that only small shops be allowed to stay open on Sundays, still a long way from total deregulation, but some of the members of the Committee aren't happy with the decision. So much so that today Labor Senator, George Georges, and a group led by the Labor Member for Fraser, Mr Fry, each put in separate dissenting reports. The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Margaret Reid, says it's the Labor Party simply supporting trade union opposition to deregulation. Mr Fry says this is nonsense.

The statement that the Labor Party was simply supporting trade union opposition to deregulation is nonsense. Not only is it nonsense but also is it a reflection on the integrity of the Committee members concerned who put in this dissenting report. Anybody who read the report would see that we agreed with the points of view which were put forward by the Shop, Distributive and Allied Employees Association. Not only did we support the Association's views but also we put forward other views which supported our dissenting report. It will be seen that we made reference to the fact that the evidence did not establish any demand for changing the present ordinance. It will be seen that we pointed out the amount of opposition to deregulation. The opposition was overwhelming.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Could I suggest that-

—I must mention these matters to indicate that the comment made by Senator Reid that we were 'simply supporting trade union opposition to deregulation' is incorrect. I must make reference to some of the points that we mentioned in our dissenting report. We mentioned that there was strong opposition to deregulation in the evidence presented. We also mentioned later that we were concerned about possible price increases if deregulation occurred. Paragraph 12-further on in the report-is the first time we mentioned any arguments raised by the trade union concerned. I will quote the paragraph because it is quite pertinent. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: We support the major arguments raised by traders, the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Association as well as religious and community groups who have appeared before the Committee and who stated that deregulated retail trading hours would-

We went on to mention points (a), (b), (c) and (d). It is pertinent to note that in that paragraph we did not mention only the trade union concerned. We mentioned traders, religious groups and community groups.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston, you have given a lot of background information in making your point. I ask you to bring your remarks back to the points to which you have taken offence and on which you are giving a personal explanation. In this place we do not allow honourable senators to range too broadly when giving a personal explanation and to debate the subject matter.

—Mr President, you anticipated me very well because I was about to conclude when you interrupted. I point out that there was an interjection from the other side that we will be here until tomorrow. It was never my intention to speak at length. I believe that when people are misrepresented in this way they should be given the opportunity to explain themselves in this chamber. Snide remarks such as the one from the other side should not be made.
—The Chair will protect you, senator.

-by leave-The interview I had with the Australian Broadcasting Commission was of some 10 to 15 minutes duration. I did not see the television program but I was told what was contained in it. In the program a fairly short phrase was taken out of what I had said, which was only part of the explanation I had given in relation to the report and comments on the report. I understand that the rest of the program showed me without my saying anything and summarised the interview. Perhaps there is little point in taking the matter further. The comments made were part of what I had said in an interview of some 10 to 15 minutes duration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The first item on the paper that you, Mr President, have presented relating to outstanding Government responses to parliamentary committee reports is a report by the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs on the constitutional qualifications of members of parliament. It was presented to the Senate on 2 June 1981. The Committee's inquiry arose principally but not entirely because of a private member's Bill that I had presented to the Senate- the Constitutional Alteration (Holders of Offices of Profit) Bill 1981. Originally this Bill was presented on 15 November 1978 but after the new Parliament met, following the 1980 election, the Bill was again presented to the Parliament. Recommendation No. 10 of the Committee stated:
The Bill entitled the Constitutional Alteration (Holders of Offices of Profit) Bill 1981 should not proceed . . .

In other words, amongst other things the Committee recommended that the Bill I had presented originally in 1978 and then later in 1981 should not proceed. I was quite content with that recommendation even though I have left that Bill on the Notice Paper. I was content because recommendation No. 11 suggested that section 44 (iv) of the Constitution should be altered in a particular way. Basically, the intent of my original Bill had been to allow public servants to be candidates both for the Senate and the House of Representatives without first being forced to resign from their Public Service positions. Recommendation No. 11 which the Committee brought down certainly goes further than my original Bill but it encompasses the intent of my original Bill. That is why I was quite content when the Committee said that the Bill should not proceed.

At this stage, I indicate to the Government that it is well over 12 months since this report was brought down-it is something like 15 months or even longer . It seems to me timely that we should receive a response from the Government so that, for a start, I could be aware of whether I should proceed with my original Bill, whether the Government is going to proceed with any of the recommendations that the Committee brought down or whether the Government is going to suggest that if the recommendations of the Committee are going to be pursued then it is up to a private member to bring down a further private member's Bill. At this stage I ask the Government to respond to this Bill as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter now before the Senate deals with the paper which Mr President has put down. I should like to comment on it briefly. I do not think we should let it pass without comment. I was the Chairman, of course, of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs which presented the report to which Senator Colston referred. I am very concerned that the Government has not responded to that one report despite its undertakings to respond within six months. As I understand it, each of the 17 reports mentioned are beyond the period of six months. Other reports have come in since then. The Government is in default of its undertaking in relation to all these reports. I want to make some general comments. I am not speaking specifically to the one report about which I am particularly concerned. I am concerned about all reports. I am concerned about the future of the committee process in the Senate and the enthusiasm which honourable senators are expected to engender in relation to the creation of reports. I am concerned about the series of failures of response from the Government to these reports. Reports will go out of action and will become out of date if they are allowed to go too long without attention and therefore they may be turned down on the grounds that they are no longer up to date in their recommendations.

SPEECH.PARA: This development is a very sad one indeed and a concerning one. I am sure that senators who are concerned for the future of the Senate committee system and its reports would like to have, perhaps not at this stage today but later, a real explanation of what will be done to ensure that reports are responded to so that where they make sensible recommendations they may be acted on at a later date. I say that, I trust, calmly and without rancour. But I feel that this a matter about which the Senate must be very concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I should like to make some brief comments on this matter. I am afraid I am not as soft on the Government as the previous speaker, Senator Missen. I can appreciate the difficulties in which he perhaps finds himself, having been very active over the last several years in attempting to get the Executive Government to respond to the very worthwhile reports that are made to the Senate. The numerous reports have resulted in a great deal of information being made available and a great number of recommendations being made to the Parliament. This has been of great value to the Parliament and to the Australian community. But these recommendations become meaningless unless the reports are given life and they can be given life only by the government of the day. The Opposition does not take the view that there are not pressures on the Government; of course there are. There are pressures on the Government all the time and because of those pressures the processes of government are slowed down to the extent that they do not always respond to the efficient workings of the Parliament. If the pressures on the Government are such that it is not able to respond to recommendations made in reports and to the very important work carried out by Senate committees, the Government has to take some responsibility in this area and it has to take some steps to allow the very effective work of the Senate committees to have some life. I do not think we can sit back, in a sense, year after year accepting an inadequate response on the part of the Government.

SPEECH.PARA: I know, Mr Deputy President, the pressures that were on you when you were a Minister of the Crown. I accept that there are pressures on all Ministers. But that is not good enough. The pressures are always there. There are pressures on members of parliament. But there is a responsibility lying here that has to be resolved. If in fact the pressures are such that the work of the Senate committees is not being attended to and their recommendations are not being taken into consideration, particularly in respect of a number of matters that are related to the effective working of the Parliament, the Government has to accept the responsibility for failing to carry out the work of the Parliament as distinct from the work of the Executive. Surely we should be looking to the Government, particularly this Government, to appoint a Minister or to take some other Executive action to ensure that at the end of the session this year we are not confronted with a problem similar to the problem that we were confronted with at the end of the session last year and the year before which culminated in the decision of the Senate to have a more effective review of the Executive and its relationship to the Senate. If the problem is not solved we will destroy not only the effectiveness of the Senate committee system but also the enthusiasm of honourable senators.

I know how many honourable senators during non-sitting weeks come to Canberra or go to various cities and provincial centres throughout Australia looking at problems, which have been referred to them as a result of a decision of the Senate, with a view to assisting the Parliament, and to some extent the Government, with the varied matters that are referred. I know that the Opposition, as distinct from the government of the day, always says that we are supposed to be wedded to a system called parliamentary democracy. But in fact we have allowed that system to degenerate into a government democracy. You, Mr Deputy President, together with the Presiding Officers, have made some progress this year in at least establishing the role of the Parliament, as distinct from the Executive, in establishing better processes and procedures for the effective functioning of the Parliament as such. That is a matter that certainly concerns me. It would certainly concern me if I were a Minister; I would still be concerned at the role that the Parliament plays, as distinct from the Executive or the Cabinet.

Again, we have an unsatisfactory position. I understand the difficulties that Senator Missen finds himself in again being a critic. But we on this side of the House can only say that we will continue to maintain the role of being a carping critic. We will be more critical than Government members because we feel that there is a degree of irresponsibility, a degree of inadequacy, in the way in which the Government is treating the reports of the Parliament.

We are grateful to the President for carrying out the function that has been requested of him by the Senate. There should be regular reports or at least annual reports to the Parliament on these matters. When we look at the nature of the reports, whilst we have referred to only one or two of them, we see that there are some very valuable reports about our security, about refugees and about the natural resources of our country and the state of them. From time to time important work has been carried out by the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations in relation to statutory authorities. All of this work in essence remained in limbo because of the inability of those reports to come to life and become part of the work of the Parliament and part of the work of the Executive of the day. On behalf of the Opposition I applaud the initiative that has been taken by my colleague, Senator Colston, and by Senator Missen. If this state of affairs continues we will have to consider a much more effective criticism of the role of the Government and its failure to take these important reports into consideration.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

In fact, it can be truly said, quite contrary to what Senator Gietzelt has said, that in the years of the Fraser Government, including in particular those years in which it commanded a majority in the Senate, it went out of its way to encourage the parliamentary authority within this chamber in its fullest development.
