TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Senator Archer, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement concerning the cost savings in the distribution of parliamentary publications.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Senate may recall that the Joint Committee on Publications, in its report entitled Inquiry into the Purpose, Scope and Distribution of the Parliamentary Paper Series, made a number of recommendations concerning the free distribution of principal parliamentary publications, excluding Hansard. In their response to the Joint Committee's report in November 1979, the Presiding Officers accepted the recommendation that the free distribution list for principal Parliamentary Publications be revised.

The Joint Committee has been advised that the first part of the review, that concerning publications other than Parliamentary Papers, has been completed and will result in considerable savings through a substantial reduction both in the quantity of documents distributed and the number of wrappers prepared and sent.

The documents concerned are Notice Papers of both Houses, proof and final Journals of the Senate, proof and final Votes and Proceedings and Bills of both Houses. Reductions in print runs were effected from the commencement of the Budget sittings and estimates provided by the Australian Government Publishing Service indicate that savings at this stage amount to $420 per sitting of the Senate and $660 per sitting of the House. On the current distribution this will result in a saving to the Parliament of over $75,000 per year.

The Joint Committee has been assured by the Presiding Officers that the distribution will be kept under review on a regular basis and looks forward to the expedition of stage 2 of the review relating to the revision of the free distribution list for Parliamentary Papers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Australian Shippers Council has made a number of very important points in its report which I should like to draw to the attention of the Senate. The first point is that the Australian National Line-ANL-was scarcely mentioned in the Crawford Report on the Revitalisation of the Australian Shipping Industry and the subsequent task force report. The Shippers Council has drawn attention to its disappointment that nothing has apparently been done by the Government over the past 12 months to review the role and performance of the Australian National Line. I share the Council's concern, and I think that the investigation into the ANL is much overdue and is an urgent task for the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I am delighted to hear that Senator Archer agrees with me. The Australian Shippers Council also continues to be concerned about the number, severity and costs associated with waterfront industrial disputes. A major dispute in November-December last year disrupted shipping in Australian ports almost totally and led to delays in the export of liner cargoes and consequent financial difficulties for export shippers, importers and ship owners.

SPEECH.PARA: The most important point to which I draw the attention of the Senate is the Council's remarks about the Crawford report on the so-called revitalisation of Australian shipping. It gave consideration to the Crawford report when it was produced and sought consultation with the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt). Unfortunately, the subsequent task force employed to look into the recommendations of the Crawford report did not consult the Shippers' Council or any other organisation representing the users of shipping services. That is a matter of great concern to me. I would like to make it clear that I am fully in agreement with decisions to extend the five-year depreciation period to ships, to provide investment allowance for overseas trading ships and to eliminate the 2 per cent import tax on ships-provided that the crews are brought down to reasonable international levels. Also, I am all in favour of a revitalised Australian shipping industry, but with two vital provisos-that it does not increase the cost or the unreliability of our overseas trade.

As I said before, the shippers, the people who have to pay the first cost-in the long run to be passed on to the Australian community-were consulted very little in this whole process. It looks to me and, I think, to them, very much like a cosy deal between ship owners and unions. That is, of course, my worry. However, before I deal with that I should like to dispose of one other matter with regard to the revitalisation of our shipping, and that is the defence argument. At present coastal shipping is an Australian flag monopoly. All the ships on the coast are Australian owned. We have 70 ships of 1.5 million tonnes on the coast, with 13 ships of 450,000 tonnes engaged in overseas trade. I am sure that we could get enough ships from these to support even a Falklands scale operation, provided that there was proper prior planning. We have not been doing this; but that is another story.

The arguments advanced by the Crawford report on the revitalisation of shipping , in my view, are all either wrong or suspect. It is unlikely that increased Australian flag shipping would make a significant net improvement in our balance of payments. It would be most unlikely to lead to increased employment and even more unlikely to provide a useful window on real shipping costs. Even if all these advantages were there, they would still have to be balanced against the cost. At present the ANL is the darling of the conferences with a cost structure which is so high that it raises the average freight rates for all the other members of the conference-a bonanza for overseas shipping lines-and we, the Australian community, pay the resultant costs.

Why are our shipping costs so high? Australian shipping is costly because of excessive crews demanded by unions. For example I mention the crew sizes of three sister ships-identical ships-on the Australia to West Coast of America service. The Swedish crew in the Paralla numbers 28; the British crew in the Dilkarra is 35; and the Australian crew in the Allunga is 36. That is typical; the Australian crew is about a quarter more than the Swedish crew. Worse still, not only are the Australian crews the largest and the highest paid but also they have five months leave a year; nearly two crews are needed for each ship. They do less on-board maintenance than the smaller crews of other nationalities. This , of course, increases costs still further and reduces the ships' operational availability. One of the main reasons for the excessive Australian crews is the number of unions involved-six. There is one encouraging development there. Two of the unions involved-the Seamen's Union of Australia and the Marine Cooks, Bakers and Butchers Association of Australasia-are in an advanced stage of amalgamation, which will reduce the number of unions involved in a ship to five. Obviously this is an improvement but this surely is one area where we should be looking for a single industry union. What we need in a single industry union for shipping is appropriate cross training so that members of the various previous unions can carry out all the functions involved in the ship. I am glad to see that the Minister is tackling that by allowing ratings to be trained at the maritime college in Launceston.

The Minister for Transport and Construction in his statement said that about 12 ships might be added to the Australian flag for overseas trading in the next three years. The only way that these could be economically justified would be if the unions showed, by performance, that they were prepared to bring the total manpower cost-not just the crew numbers-of running an Australian flag ship into line with that of other developed countries such as Sweden or Norway. My worry is that we will be pressed into negotiating bilateral deals with other countries , as we do with airlines, and our shippers will be forced to use Australian ships despite the fact that labour costs have not been brought down to world standards. As I said earlier, the shippers have been consulted very little in this whole process and they are the ones who bear the initial cost. The community will bear it ultimately.

I am all for bold initiatives that will overcome the high costs and low productivity of our shipping, but industrial peace can be bought at too high a price. I am fearful that we will burden ourselves with high cost ships providing unreliable services and with industrial blackmail being used to force shippers to use them despite their uncompetitive costs. I hope I am wrong. I hope we will not negotiate bilateral shipping deals until our total manpower costs-not just the crew numbers-have been brought down to competitive levels and the whole scheme will be dropped forthwith if the unions are not fully co-operative. If the Government sticks to its announced principles I think that no new ships will be acquired. When this becomes clear, the Government will be under enormous pressure to water down its requirements. This must be resisted. It would be much better to have no new Australian flagships involved in overseas trading if the alternative is to saddle ourselves with high costs and unreliable ships, which would do great damage to our position as a trading nation. The Government has announced its principles in this area. I hope and pray that it will stick to them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Administrative Review Council Report

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I remind the Senate that steps were taken during the last Australian Labor Party administration to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of the Australian Federal Police, to which Senator Murphy and his successor in the position of Attorney-General, Mr Kep Enderby, were subsequently traduced by the conservative parties at the time. They delayed the eventual amalgamation of the Australian Capital Territory Police Force and the Commonwealth Police Force until 1979 when they established the Australian Federal Police by legislation. Section 38 (2) and section 39 of the Australian Federal Police Act provided the Commissioner with the power-this is part of the process of the amalgamation that I want to refer to-to retire a member of the Force, transfer a member to a lower rank and transfer a member to a different position. Here we were in a position of amalgamating two forces which had similar definitions but also in a contradictory sense different functions. Clearly such powers as we said then were held by the Commissioner of Police would demand a system of review. That was one of the points consistently made by the Opposition in the debate over the Australian Federal Police Act in 1979. The Opposition moved, among many other things, for-I refer specifically:
the creation of rights of appeal in relation to transfers, promotions, discipline, demotions, retirements and dismissals.

That is referred to in page 3 of the report. The government of the day, as is pointed out in the report, refused to accept these suggestions. Of course there was considerable dissension in the Force in the last three years as the amalgamation and all of the processes associated with it took place. We are now confronted with a situation, some three years later, where the serving members of the Australian Federal Police still have no adequate appeal mechanisms for the matters which we referred to in that debate. Currently available measures of review are and have been shown to be inadequate. They are summarised by the Adminstrative Review Council-again I refer specifically-as follows:
It is thus the position that both review by the Ombudsman and judicial review have their limitations. By way of summary, neither means of review can:
effect a review on the merits;
result in a decision on the merits of the reviewing authority being substituted for that of the Commissioner.
In addition,
the Ombudsman does not investigate action taken in relation to employment.
applications for judicial review involve the prospect of substantial legal fees being incurred.

Of course that has the effect of creating a degree of discontent within the Force. Further, it is the case that other Acts which give the authorities power similar to those under sections 38 and 39 do have review and appeal procedures. This report identifies the Commonwealth (Redeployment and Retirement) Act 1979, the Postal Services Act 1975, the Telecommunications Act 1975, the Overseas Telecommunications Act 1946, the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 and the Government and Related Employees Appeal Tribunal Act 1980. The report recommends that the Promotions Appeal Board, which has been created pursuant to regulation 18 of the Australian Federal Police regulations, appears to be a welcome and long overdue step to overcome the difficulties that exist within the Australian Federal Police and affect its effectiveness as a police organisation. It is now essential that the relevant Ministers-the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) and the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman)-consider this recommendation as a matter of urgency to overcome the discontent that exists and consult the Australian Federal Police Association, which is now amalgamated and currently electing its officers. They should act on the recommendation very quickly.

Another matter to which I wish to refer concerns the serious question of staff shortages and the ability of the Australian Federal Police to police organised white collar crime, which was raised by me during a hearing of Estimates Committee C. In reply to a question related to Medibank fraud Mr J. C. Johnson, the Acting Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, replied:

The Medibank fraud matters have been particularly worrying this year. It has caused us to allocate additional staff to that area. It has been reported to me that we are handling the problem adequately at the present time.

That was on 13 September. However, on 12 October, a month later, according to the Canberra Times of 13 October, the Australian Federal Police submitted to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts that there were insufficient resources within the force to deal with medical fraud. Mr Johnson is reported to have said:

At present . . . the unavailability of resources in AFP divisions is a significant factor when determing the effectiveness of any concerted action taken to suppress medical fraud, or for that matter any form of criminal activity.

He went on to say that there were problems with training and with the level of demand placed upon skilled investigations. When these claims are added to the criticisms of the Australian Federal Police by Royal Commissioners Woodward and Costigan it is clear that a response is needed from the Government.

I released a Press report which referred to statements by Commissioners Costigan and Woodward. The report of the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Ship Painters and Dockers Union pointed out that the police force did not have sufficient personnel of the appropriate intellectual training and capacity to undertake the difficult analysis of facts which is necessary to identify major criminal organisations. The report of the Woodward Royal Commission into the Australian Meat Industry had this to say:
When the police were called in, their work was ineffective.
I put the following question to Acting-Commissioner Johnson during the hearings of Estimate Committee C:

There has been an increase of some 50 staff from one year to another. Having regard to all that has been said over the last couple of years about white collar crime, drug running, gun running, the Nugan Hand Affair, and all of the other issues which have become areas of public interest, is the present complement of 3,098 men adequate to carry out all the responsibilities which clearly come to the fore in areas of crime in Australia?

The answer to that question was not given to me by the Acting Commissioner. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle replied yes. I submit to the Senate that Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle misled Estimates Committee C when she answered that question which was directed to the Acting Commissioner. I will admit that the procedures for Senate Estimates committees are such that the Minister is the person responsible for answering the questions asked by honourable senators. In this case, however, the Acting Commissioner replied to all of the other questions asked. Subsequent to the hearings of Estimates Committee C we had the reports from the royal commissions I have mentioned. Mr Johnson has also made a report to and answered questions before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. Admissions were made to that Committee in respect of staff and other deficiencies within the Australian Federal Police. Yet, the Minister in charge of the estimates which were considered by Estimates Committee C said that all things were satisfactory and that there was no need to consider further the sorts of matters that had been raised. Mr Johnson was not allowed to answer the question satisfactorily from the point of view of the Estimates Committee. However, subsequently he made submissions to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts which contradict-I think that is the best way to put it-the evidence that was given before the Estimates Committee and contradict the statement made by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. I find that a very unsatisfactory state of affairs. I do not know what course of action is available to us other than to say that the Australian Federal Police has a tremendous responsibility in this area of fighting white collar crime in Australia. It obviously lacks the resources and the skills necessary to carry out its work. The Senate, through the Estimates Committee, was denied an opportunity properly to deal with those matters because of the way in which the Minister replied to the question.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to congratulate Qantas Airways Ltd for its report. I think the Australian editorial of Wednesday, 27 October, summed up the situation very well when it said that the Qantas loss should be commended. The report shows an overall profit for the year of $61m, compared with a $19.5m loss in 1980-81. The passenger growth of the airline was up 5.2 per cent. I think this is a very good result given the world-wide decline in tourism and international air travel. There is a recession at the moment in international aviation. The major airlines around the world are in a horrendous state.

In the last 12 months two major airlines have crashed. One was Laker Airlines. I remember many Government senators telling us when Laker first came on to the market that the deregulation of airlines was going to be the new wave of the future, that Laker was going to be a great success. That airline has now gone to the wall. More recently Braniff collapsed. It was not a small airline. Apparently it was the eighth largest airline in the United States of America. It employed 10,000 people and had over 50 aircraft. British Airways has just reported a loss of approximately $900m in the last year. Closer to home, Air New Zealand has posted another major loss this year. This led me to ask a question in the Senate recently about the position of the two United States airlines that fly into Australia. I asked that question because of an article on the Braniff crash which appeared in Newsweek of 24 May 1982. The article pointed out that six airlines in the United States were in danger of financial collapse. Two of these airlines-Pan American World Airlines Inc. and Continental Airlines Inc.- fly to Australia. I was concerned about the possibility of Australians, especially those travelling in internal routes in the United States, being stranded if either of these two airlines was forced to cease operations and strand passengers in the way Braniff did.

I was staggered by some of the figures in the Newsweek article. The article pointed out that Pan Am has at the moment a total debt of over $11 billion. That company's current assets amount to $7 billion to $8 billion and its current liabilities are between $9 billion and $10 billion. The article points out that Continental has a total debt of between $4 billion and $5 billion. Its current assets amount to only $2 billion and its current liabilities are between $5 billion and $6 billion. In 1981-82 the airlines associated with the International Air Transport Association, the world body, showed a loss of $1.9 billion. In 1980-81 the loss was $1.6 billion. There are some reports that next year the figure will be approximately $2.5 billion. I think, therefore, that we have to compare the actual airline operation loss by Qantas of only $24m for the year in the context of what is happening on a world-wide basis and see that as a very good result. But I am concerned that the Qantas profit of $61m which I have mentioned was achieved by selling during the year for $75.5m the Wentworth Hotel in Sydney. Qantas was forced to sell the hotel because of what I believe to be this Government's shortsighted policy. I wish to quote what was said on this subject by Mr Leslie, the chairman of Qantas, in presenting the airline's annual report. An article in the Australian Financial Review of 27 October states:
Mr Leslie raised hopes of a break-even result for Qantas in the 1982-83 year but this is expected to hang largely on the proceeds of the sale of Qantas House .
That is another property that will have to be sold. The article continues.

He complained bitterly yesterday of the airline's need for further capital injection from the Federal Government, and made pleas for capacity control on air traffic to the United States and greater freedom for the Qantas Board from day-to-day ministerial direction.
He said it was vital for the airline to reduce its debt ratio if it was to keep its position in a cut-throat market environment.
While the Government had injected $25 million into the airline early this year, it needed a further $120 million to bring its debt to equity ratio back to a commercially sound 40:60 basis.
Mr Leslie said the outdated air transport agreement between Australia and the US had resulted in the presence here of two US carriers Continental and Pan Am.

The Chairman went on to speak of the difficulties of those, a subject on which I have already spoken. This Government should be concerned about the proposal that Qantas staff be reduced by more than 1,000 in the next five months. Given the horrendous unemployment in this country at the moment, one can imagine what will happen, especially in cities such as Sydney, from which the majority of Qantas staff come, if 1,000 people lose their jobs in that period. I am also concerned about the safety issue. Qantas has the record of being perhaps the safest airline in the world, but I believe that there has been a decline in airline safety worldwide as a result of falling income and the need to cut costs. One has only to consider the recent crash in Chicago of a DC10 aircraft, in which almost 300 people died. According to the investigation report the crash was brought about because the company involved had indulged in time saving as far as the maintenance of engines was concerned.

What concerned me greatly about the sale of the Qantas property was a report on what is said to be the most efficient airline in Europe. I refer to Swissair, in respect of which I would like to quote a statement made in Newsweek which stated :

Unlike most European airlines, Swissair is turning a profit. It expects to end this year in the black with an estimated profit of more than $26 million. But even at hyperefficient Swissair, spiraling flight costs have taken their toll . . . Fortunately for Swissair, the airline's top managers understood the cyclical nature of the industry early on. Their response: diversification. Swissair owns two charter airlines, Balair and CTA, and services the planes and engines of other carriers. It runs an insurance company, an auditing firm, an aerial-survey company, a convention-booking agency and a chain of hotels that includes the Drake in New York City, the President in Geneva, the International in Zurich and the Bellevue Palace in Bern.

The article states that Swissair is the most efficient airline in Europe and is showing a profit because it has diversified; that part of the diversification involves owning international hotels, but Australia's airline, because of the Government's shortsightedness, has been forced to sell its hotel in order to show a profit in one year. That is a nonsensical approach.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a facile analysis, absolutely facile.

—The Minister will get his opportunity to speak. Honourable senators are faced with a time problem; we have only 10 minutes in which to speak on these items. When the opportunity is presented to undertake a proper debate on the airlines and some of the problems that they face worldwide I will elaborate on some of the points that I have made this morning. We used to hear from the Government that Laker's method of running an airline would prove successful, but we saw what happened. In summary, I ask the Government to try to understand the crisis that is affecting the airline industry worldwide. I ask it especially to consider the problem that must be faced in the next five months of trying to reserve the jobs of the 1,000 Australian workers who might be laid off by Qantas. I ask it to inject into the company urgently the $120m that was sought by its chairman, Mr Leslie, and thus help to preserve a great Australian company.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK AUTHORITY

PROCTEXT.PARA: Annual Report 1981-82

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This is an interesting and indeed quite beautiful report on the Great Barrier Reef. It is very well documented and illustrated. I wish to express concern about the reef because, in a sense, we feel that what passes for government policy in relation to it really constitutes a series of platitudes. The Government has consistently claimed that under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act the reef is protected, in the sense that environmentalists, the majority of Queenslanders I suspect, and anyone concerned about the great attributes of the reef would like to see it protected. The Opposition does not believe that that claim has sufficient reality because only those sections that have actually been declared a marine park-Capricornia and Cairns-Cormorant Pass- are protected by the Commonwealth Act. In 1979 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) gave the Queensland Government power of veto over the areas that could be protected. In 1980 the Government handed control of the three mile territorial sea around all the islands and reefs to the Queensland Government. It gave the Premier of that State the right, if he thought that course necessary , to permit oil drilling on the reef. In 1981 the Commonwealth Government excluded from the Cairns section of the park 70 per cent of the three-mile territorial sea. It is clear at this stage the Government has no intention to declare the entire reef a marine park.

The report itself is largely devoted to the beauty of the reef and its importance, but it is fairly silent on some of these important issues concerning its ultimate protection. The Opposition believes that the Queensland Government will declare its own marine parks in the reef area. That could have all sorts of consequences for the use of both marine parks for oil drilling and so on. It would be disastrous if oil drilling or mining were allowed in the area of those marine parks. It would mean that all reef areas not included in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park could be subjected to oil drilling. The Government has handed over to the Queensland National Parks Service the day to day management of the marine park. The record of that Service in managing its own island national parks is not very good. There are in the Cairns section 27 Barrier Reef islands that have Queensland National Park status, yet only two are ever visited by Queensland rangers and one, Michaelmas Cay, is visited only twice a year.

The raising of some of these matters represents merely expressions of concern by the Opposition, which is conscious of the fact that they involve important questions of Commonwealth-State relations. Our view is that, in respect of a number of matters, the Queensland Government has not displayed sufficient diligence in the protection of these areas. If one goes to the Barrier Reef area what is increasingly seen there, particularly on the beaches of north Queensland , is the exclusion of the public for private development-a sort of public squalor and private affluence in relation to the development of these areas-and a series of policies which in the long term will result in disaster because of unco-ordinated, unplanned and unprotected development of the whole of the north Queensland region.

Recently, as a political party, we announced a number of policies for north Queensland. Central to our policy statements was the need for emphasis to be placed on tourism for the area's future prosperity. We see north Queensland as an area of specific tourist interest and we take the general view that, in looking at regional policies in Australia, it is important to identify what regions can do best and what particular characteristics those regions have in terms of their economic potential. There is growing concern in north Queensland about the need to diversify the economy of that region, very much dependent as it is on sugar and the prices which commodities receive in overseas markets. Tourism, under the present Government, is the only growth industry in Australia apart from tax evasion. It is labour intensive, would employ a lot of people and is a profitable area of economic activity. It is because of that that we expressed special concern about the preservation of particular attributes of north Queensland.

Something of the same sort of argument should be put and could be put by a responsible Commonwealth government in relation to parts of Tasmania. Again, that area has particular and significant tourism potential. Tourism in north Queensland is already a big employer and a big industry, albeit somewhat haphazardly developed, because of the great natural resources of the region and the great natural beauty of the Great Barrier Reef area. That potential will never be realised if the Federal Government does not live up to its responsibilities. If it does not move quickly and firmly to protect the reef the area's single greatest asset could be destroyed. That is something about which all Australians ought to be concerned even if the Premier of Queensland is not particularly concerned.

The Queensland Government is more interested in gung ho development than in weighing up the damage to the national and regional interest in the long term. Our view is that the hour is late and that the protection of the Barrier Reef, as with protection of other areas not only of environmental significance to Australia but also of potential great economic significance because of their capacity to attract tourists, is in danger. Again, it is an issue which all Australians, particularly north Queenslanders, are aware of and concerned about. We persistently hear arguments in this Parliament that all these things are best left to the interests of the State concerned and to management by State governments. If State governments do not discharge their responsibilities the Comonwealth Government has a role in respect of areas of national importance, which we believe the Great Barrier Reef to be. I commend the report to the Senate for careful attention but I commend it only in the context of saying that we have great qualifications about the attitude of the Commonwealth Government to the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. We will continually express our concern about this issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some remarks on the annual report for 1981-82 of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority. Firstly, I must congratulate the Chairman on the presentation of the report. It is certainly an outstanding report, both in the colour plates and photographs that adorn it and also in the comments in relation to the establishment of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park. I share the point of view put forward by Senator Button about the doubts we have about the Queensland Government and its view of the Great Barrier Reef and the marine park. The Queensland Government's view is one of development rather than one of preservation for future generations. But that is not the point that I would like to speak on very briefly today; I wish to deal with research documentation. The report states quite clearly:

SPEECH.PARA: Two projects are underway to facilitate the co-ordination and dissemination of marine research information. The first, entitled Australian Marine Research in Progress is a co-operative venture between the Department of Science and Technology, CSIRO-Division of Computing Research and the Authority.

On dealing with that research or with the bodies involved in that research, particularly the Department of Science and Technology, I was somewhat amazed, when I asked a question on an Estimates committee, to find that it was quite obvious that the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) had endorsed a recommendation to terminate Federal funding for research into the box jellyfish. It seems to me that, although one could say that the box jellyfish will not affect the reef itself, certainly when we extend our view of the reef to include its potential for tourism we see that the box jellyfish would certainly have some effect because of its ability to keep people out of the water in the northern areas. I was amazed that when I asked the Minister a question he indicated that something like $500,000 was spent on research generally in the northern part of Australia. The amount actually spent by the Government was in the vicinity of $138,000-not $500,000 as the Minister had stated. So at the Estimates committee I decided to try to gather a bit more information on the Government's real ability or real desire to go on with research, particularly research that affects the Great Barrier Reef. On asking a question I found that a Dr R. F. Hardwick of James Cook University applied for further funding for research into the box jellyfish and the problems as they affect the northern waters of Queensland. He wanted to continue research into the control of box jelly fish infestation through the northern waters. He also wanted to have further investigation into diesel fuel slug, which he was investigating at the same time. But the allocation in the Budget showed very clearly that the Government was not greatly interested in that sort of research continuing.

TALK.START.PARA: —How far south does the box jellyfish come?

—It could develop from, say, the Townsville area right down. It certainly affects the area that is part of the marine park and will affect the Barrier Reef area. Dr Hardwick made a request of the Department to seek an extra $24,375 for research into the areas that I have spoken of. At the Estimates committee I was informed that only $9,800 would be available for the continuation of that research and that the Australian Marine Sciences and Technologies Advisory Committee had endorsed the payment of that amount of money . It also endorsed-or the Minister had endorsed-the fact that there was to be no further research. In other words, Dr Hardwick requested somewhere in the vicinity of $24,000 to finish the research that he had started in the area. He was allocated only $9,800 and in no way, with that amount of money being allowed to Dr Hardwick, could he finish the research that he had started into the box jellyfish and other problems that exist in that northern part of the reef area. I draw the attention of the Senate to this matter. The report of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority is of a very high quality. I feel sure that those people who are responsible for this report would be very interested in the fact that this Government intends to neglect to pay the extra amount of money required to continue the research into the infestation of the box jellyfish in north Queensland.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Review of Radioactive Waste Management and Synroc

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
The Australian Labor Party's policy with regard to uranium contains the following paragraph:

The uncritical support of nuclear technologies by governments worldwide encouraged the nuclear industry to develop before the fundamental questions of safety, disposal techniques, effective regulatory and safety systems were tackled and which still remain unresolved.

It is in relation to those very questions that the Australian Ionising Radiation Advisory Council reports from time to time to the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment (Mr McVeigh) and hence today to the Parliament. It cannot be denied that in the Australian community there is a very real fear. There are misgivings of a grave nature as to the waste products from the nuclear fuel cycle not least because of their hazardous nature but also because of the very long life of those waste products. The Labor Party is most concerned that sufficient research effort be applied by both government and private industry to ensure that if the industry is to operate at all it should do so only when the risks associated with the disposal of waste have been minimised to a degree which is acceptable within the whole of the Australian community.

When one reads the two letters from the Council to the Minister which are before the Senate today-one might say that we are indebted to the distinguished members of that Council for the time they have put into reviewing the state of the high technology which is being developed, some successfully and some with less success, in order to deal with waste disposal-one finds, in the first letter a reference to an incident in the Tsuruga nuclear power station operated by the Japanese Atomic Power Co. where a cubic metre of low level liquid radioactive waste overflowed from the storage tank at that nuclear power station and found its way to the local stormwater drainage system. That incident alone demonstrates that the safety of nuclear plants and of surrounding communities has not been given sufficient attention in as much as the overflow from that plant flowed into the local stormwater drains. It strikes me and, I am sure, most honourable senators that simple matters such as that which go wrong give rise to the very real apprehension in the community. It is as to the long term disposal of waste products that the Council directs the bulk of its letters to the Minister.

I believe it would be of interest to most Australians to hear what the Council has to say about the Synroc method of trapping wastes in a way which is said to prevent their leaching or movement into the surrounding environment. The Synroc proposal did capture the imagination of the general public in Australia, particularly those with real political concern in this matter, because it seemed to be a case of Australian expertise, learning and techniques perhaps providing some solution to this problem. I was astounded to read in the letter from the Council to the Minister that at present no radioactive waste has been incorporated in Synroc. My general impression was that even at the laboratory level experiments had taken place whereby radioactive waste had been introduced into the Synroc artificial material in order to see what effect that waste radiated product might have on the encasing material. It seems that to the present crucial experiment has not been undertaken at the laboratory stage and certainly not even at the pilot plant or full-scale demonstration stage. The Council made certain comments in relation to the Synroc process. These comments need to be related to a previous letter which discussed the enclosing of waste products in glass. The letter states:

. . . one advantage which is claimed for SYNROC is that in accelerated ageing tests the leach-rate rapidly declines to a much lower value than that measured for glasses. However, there is evidence that some naturally occurring minerals which have structures not dissimilar to SYNROC become amorphous-glass-like-after substantial exposure to radiation. It is therefore vital that extensive studies should be undertaken of the effect of radiation on the structure and leach-rate of SYNROC.

Those experiments have not yet been undertaken. It is a cause of concern that that should be the case. The Australian Labor Party has a strong policy in relation to the need to find methods to store waste products safely from the nuclear fuel cycle. We have an international concern in this regard. For example , our present policy states:
For example, any contract with the Japanese could only be contemplated subject to them withdrawing from their intention to dump waste material in the Pacific.

The attitude of the Japanese is perhaps at one extreme-a contemptuous disregard for the environment of the Pacific and of the wishes of the peoples in those island states. That is at one extreme in relation to which the Labor Party says certain things ought to happen-this is embraced in the second last paragraph of our policy which follows from other paragraphs. The Labor Party says:

In adopting the view that the onus and responsibility to meet the conditions as outlined rightly belongs to the miners, producers and developers we determine that an Australian Labor Party government will have neither a moral, legal, or political obligation to compensation to the industry as such. The responsibility is theirs to meet the above necessary and reasonable conditions. It is not the responsibility of government.
That refers to an earlier paragraph which requires that:

. . . miners, producers and users of the products of the nuclear fuel cycle accept responsibility for developing effective waste disposal mechanisms, satisfactory safety and occupational health conditions, proposals and funding for the decommissioning of nuclear plants and also provide financial assistance for the development of safe alternative energy sources.
That brings me to the final paragraph of the Council's letter to the Minister. In relation to Synroc being taken to the pilot plant stage and then to full demonstration, the Council stated:

The Council recommends that the Commonwealth Government should give continued strong encouragement to the SYNROC programme and should endeavour to provide a guarantee of adequate support over a period of at least several years.

It is not my place at all to speak for the incoming Labor government and the resources which it will provide in accordance with that strong recommendation of the Council. But I can say that in accordance with our policy the level of resources which might be contributed by the national government to that project would be a contribution, a supplementing, of the research expenditure which would be required of the industry itself. That research effort by industry would be a condition of its operating at all in the phasing out of that industry under Labor Party policy. The disposal of waste is a problem which has to be tackled with the expenditure of quite considerable financial resources. Those resources must come not only from the general community through national government but also from the industry. That will be a key point in Australian Labor Party strategy on coming into government. Because of the brief amount of time available to me, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the Australian Labor Party's uranium policy.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Uranium

Recognising that the provision of Australian uranium to the world nuclear fuel cycle creates problems relevant to Australian sovereignty, the environment, the economic welfare of our people and the rights and well being of the Aboriginal people; believing that, having regard to the present unresolved economic, social , biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the mining of uranium and the development of nuclear power, and in particular-
(a) to the proven contribution of the nuclear power industry to the proliferation of nuclear weapons and the increased risk of nuclear war; and
(b) the absence of procedures for the storage and disposal of radioactive wastes to ensure that any danger posed by such wastes to human life and the environment is eliminated;
It is imperative that no commitment of Australia's uranium deposits to the world's nuclear fuel cycle should be made until-
(a) a reasonable time has elapsed for full public debate on, and consideration of, the issues;
(b) the ALP is satisfied that the abovementioned problems have been solved; and
(c) the Australian Government endorses Recommendation 6 of the First Fox Report which states-

'a decision to mine and sell uranium should not be made unless the Commonwealth Government ensures that the Commonwealth can at any time . . . immediately terminate those activities, permanently, indefinitely or for a specific period.'
Accordingly, a Labor government will-
54 (a) declare a moratorium on uranium mining and treatment in Australia;
(b) repudiate any commitment of a non-Labor Government to the mining, processing or export of Australia's uranium; and
(c) not permit the mining, processing or export of uranium pursuant to agreements entered into contrary to ALP policy.
This policy will be implemented in the light of the following-

55 The ALP's approach to uranium policy is dominated by its concern that the economic, social, biological, genetic, environmental and technical problems associated with the nuclear industry are unresolved and that uranium is a source material leading to nuclear armaments proliferation, which poses the most serious threat to world peace yet experienced and to Australian sovereignty.
56 We have remained steadfast in our opposition to the growing propensity for reliance upon the nuclear fuel cycle as a source of energy and for other commercial and military applications.
57 The development of the nuclear fuel cycle has delayed the development and application of passive energy technologies more suitable to our fragile global environment.

58 The uncritical support of nuclear technologies by governments worldwide encouraged the nuclear industry to develop before the fundamental questions of safety, disposal techniques, effective regulatory and safety systems were tackled and which still remain unresolved.

59 The acceptance of nuclear power as an energy alternative by developing countries has not only presented these countries and the world with a substantial safety and surveillance problem but has provided many with the option of becoming nuclear weapons States adding to the dangers of increased armament proliferation.

60 Labor believes the development of a nuclear weapons capability from civil nuclear programmes is the most distressing feature of nuclear power, and one which requires the most urgent and earnest international attention.
61 Australia is not a producer of nuclear power but is involved in the international nuclear fuel cycle as a supplier of uranium.

62 Despite widespread concern in the community, the opposition of the Australian Labor Party and the trade union movement, commitments have been made by previous governments to certain corporations operating uranium mines in Australia and to the governments of customer countries, to maintain Australia as a uranium exporter.
63 We recognise on becoming government-

(a) we will inherit an existing position of Australia under the Fraser government of having made treaties and authorised contracts of supply of uranium to a growing number of countries with little effort to impose controls and conditions on supply;

(b) an incoming ALP government is already committed to repudiate all existing commitments. In adopting our repudiation commitment an ALP government has neither a moral, legal, or political obligation to compensation to the industry as such;

(c) understanding the difficulties which could be encountered in the implementation of that commitment our minimum position would be a total unequivocal commitment to phase out Australia's involvement in the uranium industry and that certain conditions as outlined will and must be applied to those mines existing in production as of July 1982; and
(d) as an ALP government we give total commitment to preventing any new mines from being developed during our period of office.
64 Accordingly, a Labor government will-

(a) make a total commitment to exerting all possible influences on the development of creating effective international arrangements covering nuclear non-proliferation treaties, waste disposal, arms control and nuclear disarmament ;

(b) review bilateral safeguard agreements governing supply under these contractual arrangements and, if necessary, renegotiate these agreements to impose conditions relating to the nuclear practices of the customer country (e.g . the cessation of French atomic testing in the Pacific area);

(c) consider applications for the export of uranium mined incidentally to the mining of other minerals on a case by case basis and on the criteria of whether in the opinion of a Labor government the mining of such minerals is in the national interest; and
(d) allow no new uranium mine developments to commence or come on stream whilst the government of Australia.
65 In government if the only recourse is to implement a policy of phasing out the industry as of July 1982, the following conditions will be applied-

(a) miners, producers and users of the products of the nuclear fuel cycle accept responsibility for developing effective waste disposal mechanisms, satisfactory safety and occupational health conditions, proposals and funding for the decommissioning of nuclear plants and also provide financial assistance for the development of safe alternative energy sources;

(b) measures are adopted in the International Atomic Energy Agency and elsewhere not only to improve the technical efficiency of existing safeguard systems but also to establish new and multilateral approaches to a reduction in nuclear proliferation and to more effective control of existing nuclear facilities;

(c) satisfactory arrangements have been developed for the storage or disposal of the products of uranium mining, low level waste such as equipment or material contaminated by radioactivity, spent fuel, plutonium and depleted uranium as products of reprocessing and high level waste separated by reprocessing;

(d) arrangements have been established by mining companies, in cooperation with national health authorities, for health screening and study of employees, both while employed and for a period considered by medical authorities as being necessary, to detect the incidence of disease related to exposure to radioactivity; and

(e) not permit the treatment, storage, or enrichment of nuclear materials in Australia nor domestic use of nuclear power. Whilst opposed to the establishment of domestic storage and treatment systems, Labor will support the development of safe long-term nuclear waste disposal technology for application to existing waste problems.

66 Consistent with clauses 63b and 63c an Australian Labor government will adopt the process of phasing out our involvement in uranium mining, and certain conditions will be imposed upon the producers in accordance with this policy and we will utilise our right to apply trade embargos to ensure these conditions are met.
For example, any contract with the French government could only be contemplated subject to that government ceasing all nuclear testing programmes in the Pacific .
For example, any contract with the Japanese could only be contemplated subject to them withdrawing from their intention to dump waste material in the Pacific.

For example, any contract with the Finns would be subject to our being satisfied beyond all doubt that the supply of uranium was not being deflected into the nuclear fuel cycle and nuclear arms programme of the USSR.
For example, any contract with Great Britain would be subject to our being satisfied beyond all doubt that the supply of uranium was not being used to assist in developing nuclear armaments.

For example, any contract with the West Germans would be subject to them ceasing the supply of technology and equipment to countries such as the Argentine which is leading to the establishment of yet another potentially nuclear armed country.
Any such conditions will apply to purchasing countries over and above existing international safeguard agreements being agreed to and observed.

The principles inherent above which apply to specific markets will be applied in relation to contracts to any other countries, arising out of the production of current mines, within which similar circumstance arise.

67 Labor is commited to reversing the direction of nuclear developments worldwide. As part of this Commitment, a Labor government will undertake appropriate research and provide assistance to the energy impoverished nations of the world to find energy solutions which are more suitable to their decentralised populations and which are a real alternative to reliance upon large blocks of expensive centralised nuclear generation with extensive reticulation grids.

68 Labor will take steps in international forums such as the International Energy Agency to promote a fair distribution of available energy resources so that the rich nations are precluded from placing inordinate demands upon the world's scarce and finite fuels.

69 Nations must also be convinced that their interests are best served persisting with energy systems which utilise their indigenous fuels and decrease their dependence upon the international oil trade, transnational oil companies and the merchants of nuclear power.

70 As part of its comprehensive approach to uranium policy and its concern for the gravity of the international outlook for peace and security, Labor will monitor the nuclear activities of other countries and their propensity to develop weapons capabilities. In tandem with its monitoring programme and to reduce the prospect of a nuclear war, it will indefatigably pursue a policy of international arms control and disarmament.

71 If in implementing this policy opportunities for employment are affected on a regional basis then provision will be made for adjustment assistance, compensation and alternative employment opportunities to those workers, and the provision of financial assistance to an alternative means of economic development for those Aboriginal communities adversely affected will be guaranteed.

72 On a regional basis, the provision of special assistance to those local economies adversely affected by the implementation of the policy will be given to facilitate the implementation of alternative policies for economic development.

73 In adopting the view that the onus and responsibility to meet the conditions as outlined rightly belongs to the miners, producers and developers we determine that an Australian Labor Party government will have neither a moral, legal, or political obligation to compensation to the industry as such. The responsibility is theirs to meet the above necessary and reasonable conditions. It is not the responsibility of government.

74 Finally, no revision of this policy with the view of allowing the industry to develop further will be undertaken by the Australian Labor Party until and unless all of our unresolved concerns related to the industry are satisfactorily resolved and agreed to by the ALP National Conference.
NUCLEAR POWER
75 Prohibit the establishment in Australia of nuclear power plants and all other stages of the nuclear fuel cycle.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF PLANT CAPACITY AND EQUIPMENT IN THE COMMONWEALTH GOVERNMENT PRINTING OFFICE

PROCTEXT.PARA: Report 1981 and Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report was prepared by Mr H. W. Paterson. I believe this is a very good report but it is long overdue. It is long overdue not only because it is a report on the capacity of the Commonwealth Government Printing Office but also because, in a most scandalous way, this report, which is dated February 1981 and which left the Government Printing Office in April 1981, is before the Senate only now. One can well ask: What has happened? Why has this report been suppressed from at least April 1981 until today? The delay is unforgiveable. That delay represents the way in which this Government has treated the Government Printing Office, which is a very efficient organisation. This Government has been seeking to give government printing work to private enterprise.

The report sets out to examine the capacity of the Government Printing Office. Mr Paterson refers in his report to the Printing Office having a turnover worth $20m a year. It is a very sizable and very efficient government enterprise. A serious problem for the Government Printing Office is the fact that this Government has continued to sabotage its own office by its ideological prejudice in that it insists on hiving off work to the private sector. I refer to the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette No. G 43 dated Tuesday, 27 October 1982. On page 59 of that Gazette, under the sub-heading 'Australian Government Publishing Service', I find a typical example of the way in which this Government has directed the Australian Government Publishing Service to give preference to commercial enterprises. That typical example in the Gazette shows contracts to the Canberra Publishing and Printing Co., the Union Offset Company, Moore Paragon (Aust.) Limited, the Canberra Times and Trade Typesetters, Canberra. They are all companies in the Australian Capital Territory area. In particular, the period contract referred to in the Gazette refers to the typesetting and supply of reproduction material. I think these are annual contracts or contracts at least for a considerable period.

Those contracts are particularly significant because in the report Mr Paterson refers to the changes taking place in the Government Printing Office. Changes in technology are taking place which are absolutely essential in order to make the Government Printing Office comparable with commercial enterprises. In the Gazette for the week previous to the one to which I have referred the amount of money shown as having been given to commercial enterprises was to the extent of $129,000, which I think is fairly typical of the way in which this Government is giving work to private, commercial enterprises. This is happening at a time when the Government Printing Office is under capacity. The Government is sabotaging the Government Printing Office by, on the one hand, giving work to the commercial companies and yet, on the other hand, not utilising fully the capacity of the Government Printing Office.

The other aspect of this report which is of concern and to which I have referred is the tremendous delay in its presentation. When Mr Paterson addressed himself to the problems of the Government Printing Office he was dealing with the situation in 1980. Now we find that some of his predictions, which of course were genuinely made in 1980, are out of date. For example, on page 28 at paragraph 4.14 of his report under the heading 'Conclusions and findings' he states:
That adequate use will not be made of the photocomposition system illustrated in Appendix V when it is completed in 1982 unless input is lifted by about 30%.

His estimate was that there was a need to plan towards that use of new equipment . My information is that that under capacity of work in the Government Printing Office at present is 50 per cent and that the new system which has been introduced into the Government Printing Office has increased the capacity of the Government to be concerned with its own typesetting for reports and other matters with which it deals. As I have already referred to, the Government, through the Government Publishing Service, is giving work away to the Canberra Times which is part of the Sydney Morning Herald group, to Trade Typesetters and other commercial printers. That is clearly a stupid system of allocation of resources. The Government is clearly attempting to sabotage what is an excellent service-the Government Printing Office.

Over a period, the service has been undermined because of the way in which work of the Government Printing Office has been curtailed by the development of the Publishing Service hiving off work to the private sector. In paragraph 8.4, listed under the commercial options to which Mr Paterson refers, he points out that it would be interesting to conjecture what should be done and to speculate on the possibility of the Government Printing Office actively seeking work to combat what he describes as the passive attitude towards the Government Printing Office. The Government Printing Office has not been encouraged to accept work from government departments and other government sources. In paragraph 8.7 (b) of the report Mr Paterson proposes:

Develop a group of up to eight persons, trained to service departments, with clear and quantified objectives concerning the nature of timing of contracts required by the CGPO, and ensure that their commitments to customers are faithfully carried out.
In paragraph (c) of his recommendations he goes on to point out that it is necessary to do the following:

Change the production control system of the Kingston plant from passive status reporting to a positive management tool which discloses in advance the location and likely extent of unfilled capacity and closely monitors the progress of orders through the plant.

Mr Paterson is doing something that I would support very strongly. He is proposing, in an intelligent and sensible way, that when the Parliament is not sitting the Government Printing Office be able to solicit work from government departments and, in that way, keep working to capacity, as it should be. At the moment the Government Printing Office works at a 90 per cent capacity in parliamentary periods. The remaining 10 per cent, apart from any cases of sickness or matters of that nature, is to cover ordinary maintenance on that equipment. The real problem lies with the use, during probably 50 per cent of the time, when the Parliament is not sitting, of the typesetting capacity which is available. It is there as a result of changes in technology and the installation of new equipment. It would appear that the Government does not have any plans to use that equipment as it should be used.

In talking about the equipment I should like to add that the Government Printing Office has a particularly skilled section of trades people. It has some of the most skilled people in the Australian printing industry. The work of the Government Printing Office requires special skills. It requires extreme accuracy . Quite often a Bill with many alterations is sent at 4.30 p.m. to the Government Printing Office. The required number of copies of that material is always available the following morning, despite the interference of politicians and the alterations that are often necessary in such a situation. It is necessary for officers at the Government Printing Office to be given the opportunity to exercise their skills. If the Government Printing Office is allowed to be undermanned the valuable skills in the bookbinding and finishing area, in the trade typesetting area and in the many other skilled areas of the Government Printing Office will be lost to this Parliament. Unfortunately, we will then pay through the nose for commercial printers to undertake work that at the moment is quite capably done by the people at the Government Printing Office .

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —For the sake of keeping the discussion open, I point out to the Senate that, apart from the Independent Review of Plant Capacity and Equipment in the Commonwealth Government Printing Office which was carried out by Mr Paterson, there is the special report to the Parliament on the Australian Government Publishing Service and its role in Commonwealth printing and publishing. Honourable senators will find that the recommendations made in that report are similar to those advocated by Mr Paterson. At page 34 of his report Mr Paterson gave a commercial option. A bureaucratic option appears at page 35. If honourable senators care to look through those options and compare them with the report on the Australian Government Publishing Service they will find that they run along similar lines. Therefore, it behoves the Government to look at those two reports before it comes down with any recommendations. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I advise honourable senators that at page 150 of the sixty-first report of the Commissioner of Taxation tabled in the other place this morning my name appears, though I am not identified as a senator, as having understated my income by something less than $1,400 a year for a period of four years. For a very long period I and my father before me had engaged a firm of accountants. The firm had full details of my business and private affairs and each year prepared my taxation return from that information. In 1979 I received a request from the Commissioner of Taxation for details of interest received from investments. On investigation I discovered to my horror that interest received from term deposits had been overlooked by my accountant. The interest had not been disclosed over a period of four years. My accountant had full knowledge of all my investments but had failed to obtain details of accrued interest which had been automatically added to the investment and did not appear on my bank statements. In 1980 I paid the amended assessment and the penalty.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Children and Television: Government Reponse-Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Honourable senators will recall that on 11 June last year, the then Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts tabled the Committee's report entitled 'Children and Television Revisited'. This report was a review of the study undertaken in 1978 by the Committee into the impact of television on the development and learning behaviour of children. The purpose of the review was to re-examine the recommendations of the earlier report in the light of developments in the area of children's television. The Committee canvassed the views of a number of individuals and organisations and held public hearings during March and April 1981.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to inform the Senate that the Government has carefully considered the recommendations contained in the report entitled 'Children and Television Revisited'. I can assure honourable senators that the issue of the impact and effects of television on children continues to be of great concern to the Government. I am pleased to say that, since the 1978 inquiry by the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts, the Government has achieved a great deal in the area. This is reflected by the fact that the majority of the Senate Standing Committee's recommendations in the latest report, which re- affirm or amend those of the previous study, have been or are currently being implemented. Major recommendations of the review are: The reduction of the total amount of violence on Australian television; the suggestion that the Film Censorship Board be responsible for program classification; endorsement of the concept of an Australian children's television foundation; and further research into the promotion of the concept of consumption of healthy diets. A schedule of Government responses to the Committee's recommendations has been prepared. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-

PROCTEXT.PARA: RECOMMENDATIONS OF THE REPORT OF THE SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS ENTITLED 'CHILDREN AND TELEVISION REVISITED'
Recommendation
1. The Effects of Television Violence
That the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal as early as practicable fulfils all the relevant terms of Recommendation 1 of the Committee's original Report:
(i) that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in consultation with Australian researchers and where relevant overseas authorities, including broadcasting authorities:
(a) formulate guidelines designed to reduce the total amount of violence on Australian television; and
(b) that such guidelines take particular account of the more damaging forms of violence identified by researchers;
(ii) that the Broadcasting Information Officer monitor telecasts to determine the amount and kind of violence being presented on television; and

(iii) that periodic assessments be made of the amount and kinds of violence against the criteria and principles of the guidelines and this information be made readily available to the public and be taken into account by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal when assessing a station's performance during licence renewal hearings.
Response
Any action to be taken on this recommendation is a matter primarily for the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT).
The formulation of guidelines relating to violence will be part of the current review of television standards being conducted by the ABT.

The ABT has issued a discussion paper on 'Violence on Television' designed to obtain information on community attitudes towards violence on television as a pre-requisite for regulatory or other action.
Concerning the Broadcasting Information Office see comment for Recommendation 2 .
Recommendation
2. Broadcasting Information Office (BIO)
That the Government reconsiders its decision not to establish the Broadcasting Information Office.
Response

On 15 April 1981 Cabinet agreed not to proceed with the establishment of the BIO. It was subsequently decided that some of the proposed functions of the BIO would be absorbed, in a suitably reduced and modified form, in the ABT.

The ABT has been reorganised taking into account recent Government decisions on the BIO. The major research and information gathering functions that had been proposed be transferred to the BIO continue to be performed by the ABT. Accordingly the Government has decided not to accept Recommendation 2.
Recommendation
Program Classification
3. That the Film Censorship Board be responsible for program classification on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Response

The Government has considered these recommendations and has decided that the Film Censorship Board will not assume responsibility for the classification of programs on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal.
Recommendation

4. That in the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 the responsibilities of, and procedures to be followed by, the Film Censorship Board in undertaking program classification on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal be clearly specified and take account of the terms of the provisions outlined in this Review.
Response

The ABT is holding discussions with the ABC and the industry representative body, FACTS. Following these discussions I shall take up the matter of options in the longterm for the classification of imported television material with the Attorney-General.
Recommendation
Children's Television Program Production Unit
5. That the Commonwealth Government supports the Australian Children's Television Foundation and that this support encompass financial contribution.
Response
The Government is supporting the establishment of the Australian Children's Television Foundation and has provided $250,000 in 1981-82 towards the cost of its establishment.

The proposal is that the Commonwealth meets approximately half the cost of the Foundation during its initial three years of operation (i.e. up to $1.5m) with the States and Territories sharing the remaining $1.5m. It is expected then that the Foundation will be self supporting.
The Commonwealth is committed to support the Foundation in 1982-83, with the balance of funding in 1983-84 and 1984-85 conditional on its performance in the initial two years of operation.
In 1982-83 $500,000 was appropriated to the Foundation in the Budget.
Recommendation
6. That Films commissioned by the Foundation for local production qualify for tax concessions under the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936.
Response
The Income Tax Assessment Act provides for four kinds of eligible films. Films made for children may be eligible, having regard to approved guidelines.
Recommendation
7. That financial support to the Foundation from the private sector qualifies as a tax deduction.
Response
The Government has recently decided that gifts to the Foundation shall not be tax deductible.
Recommendation
The Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal

8. That the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942 be amended so as to provide for formal status of the Children's Program Committee of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and that in the drafting of such legislation note be taken of the comments made in this Review.
Response

The ABT in consultation with the Children's Program Committee drafted a formal Constitution governing the operations of the Children's Program Committee, which came into effect on 1 December 1981. Legislation is, therefore, unnecessary.
Recommendation
Advertising

9. That the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal continues to review the criteria on which advertising standards are based taking into account the possible harmful effects of the influences of advertising on the formation of children's attitudes and values.
Response

All the matters raised in the Report concerning advertising are being taken into account in the current review of the ABT's Television Advertising Standards . The ABT anticipates publishing discussion papers concerning these matters which will invite public comments before the Standards are finalised.
Recommendation

10. That appropriate funding be made available to the National Health and Medical Research Council to allow it to undertake an advertising campaign on the electronic media during children's listening and viewing times designed to promote the consumption of healthy diets.
Response

The National Health and Medical Research Council (NH and MRC) Working Party on Television Advertising of Foods Directed to Children has recommended that an advertising campaign promoting the consumption of healthy diets be undertaken by the Department of Health.
Recommendation

11. That the National Health and Medical Research Council continue to pursue its research into the dietary habits of Australians and the effectiveness of television advertising in influencing what Australians eat.
Response
The NH and MRC is presently giving consideration to action it may take in regard to pursuing its research on matters mentioned in Recommendation 11.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator PETER BAUME

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of the Committee's recommendations concern the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, such as those relating to advertising standards and assessment of the effects of televised violence. The Tribunal is currently undertaking a review of television standards and will be paying close attention to these matters.

INTERJECT.PARA: The review recommends that the Government reconsider its decision not to proceed with the establishment of a broadcasting information office. Honourable senators will recall that this decision was taken in the context of the Review of Commonwealth Functions committee. The Government has since decided that some of the proposed functions of the broadcasting information office would be absorbed within the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will, therefore, continue its research and information gathering roles in a suitably modified and reduced way, taking into account the Government's decision on the BIO. The Government has reconfirmed its decision on the BIO and does not accept the recommendations of the Senate Committee on this matter. In view of the time and the procedures of the Senate, there is a short additional part of the Government's response which might be suitable for incorporation in Hansard. If that were the wish of the Senate, I seek leave to have the remainder of the statement incorporated in Hansard.
Some of the Committee's recommendations involve other departments and authorities. These have been referred to the relevant body for appropriate action.

The Senate Committee also recommended that the Children's Program Committee be given formal status under the Broadcasting and Television Act 1942. However, the ABT subsequently developed a Constitution governing the Children's Program Committee, which took effect on 1 December 1981. The Government has therefore decided that it is not necessary to give a legislative base to the Children's Program Committee.
I turn now to the classification of programs which is a difficult but necessary task.

The Committee considered this matter and recommended that the Film Censorship Board assume responsibility for classifying all imported and locally produced television programs on behalf of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal. After careful examination of the complex issues involved, the Government has decided not to add to the responsibilities of the Film Censorship Board in this way. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is currently discussing the classification of imported television material with the ABC and the television industry representative body, the Federation of Australian Commercial Television Stations (FACTS). The aim is to establish acceptable arrangements which acknowledge the importance of generally accepted standards and the capacity and experience of the industry, the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal and the Film Censorship Board . I will consider any recommendations which come forward as a result of these discussions at the appropriate time in close consultation with my colleague, the Attorney-General.

The Senate Standing Committee devoted considerable time to investigating the area of advertising and I have already mentioned that the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal will be pursuing the matters raised in the Committee's Report.
