In addition, the National Health and Medical Research Council is considering the matter of supporting further research in relation to the dietary habits of Australians as proposed by the Committee.
Finally, I come to the matter of an Australian Children's Television Foundation . Honourable Senators will join with me in commending the principles on which the concept of the Foundation is based.

The Commonwealth has agreed to provide $1.5 million to the Foundation over a period of three calendar years, representing 50 per cent of the Foundation's estimated expenditure during that period. Of this amount, $250,000 was provided late in the 1981-82 financial year, and $500,000 is to be provided in 1982-83. The provision of the balance of the Commonwealth commitment in 1983-84 and the first half of the 1984-85 financial year will be conditional on the government being satisfied that the Foundation is making a worthwhile contribution to the improvement of children's television by its performance over the initial two years of operations. The Foundation is expected to be self supporting after three years. The Senate Standing Committee is to be congratulated on the painstaking work it has undertaken and the depth of analysis which is reflected in its Review. Through its efforts, there has been a general increase in awareness of the television needs of children which, it is hoped, will result in better children's television programs in the future.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 October, on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle:
That the Bill be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a number of points in respect of South Australia in this pre-election period in that State. Three years ago the South Australia electorate elected the Tonkin Liberal Government on a promise of stopping the job rot and on a promise of developing confidence in the future. Three years later it is very much a situation of the time being up, not only for Dr Tonkin and for the Liberal Government in South Australia, but also for thousands of South Australians who, in the last three years, have in one way or another discovered that the promise for the future was not met. It is a government that now goes into an election bankrupt economically and bankrupt of ideas. It is a government which, to the electorate of South Australia, is presenting itself with the intellectual capacity of the Muppet Show. It has presented no policies during this campaign, and, despite that fact, it is now about to embark on a campaign of deception and smear. We have seen in South Australia-in fact we have not seen in South Australia in recent weeks-the phantom Premier, Dr Tonkin, who has quite conspicuously not been there. The great government announcement this week of a new bank for South Australia was made by the Minister of Industrial Relations, Mr Dean Brown. Dr Tonkin did not grace the photograph in the newspaper.

SPEECH.PARA: We know that the election will be held in nine days time. One thing that we know in South Australia is that the election, which could be held up to March next year, is to be held at this particular time for a particular reason. In that respect I refer to an article in the South Australian Advertiser by its industrial reporter Michael Grealy, in which he says:
The worsening employment situation in South Australia, more than any other reason, has prompted the State election sooner, rather than later.

That very much is the crux of the situation in South Australia. Let us turn for a moment to the record of this Government. Let us turn to its economic record, the record of the Tonkin Administration as economic managers. Let us look at some of the indicators. Let us look at employment and unemployment. In Australia over the last three years there has been an increase in unemployment in the vicinity of 300,000. In South Australia there has been an actual decrease in full time employment of approximately 2,000. When we look at total employment, both full time and part time, we see that even in this respect the increase has been 0.01 per cent of the national total, which is hardly the share that South Australians have been used to. When we look at other indicators such as the number of persons unemployed for each job available, we see that whereas in 1979 there was one person unemployed for every 20 jobs available, this figure has now increased to a massive 50 persons unemployed for every job vacancy. In the actual indicator for unemployment, the unemployment level, we find that in the three years September 1979 to September 1982 there has been an increase in unemployment in South Australia from 7.6 per cent of the national unemployment rate to 8.5 per cent. In 30 of the 33 months of Tonkin Government we have consistently had unemployment at the highest level of all mainland Australian States. The construction industry is in the same position.

TALK.START.PARA: —Unemployment is falling.
—I am informed by my friend that unemployment is falling. Let us have a look at that situation. Let us return once again to the article by Michael Grealy which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Employment always drops seasonally from March to August but the 22,000 drop this year is 10,000 more than in any of the past five years.

The number of people employed in South Australia showed a net drop of only 300 between September, 1979, and September, 1982. In the view of the Government which promissed to 'stop the job rot'; that amounts to South Australia's ' holding the line' better than any other State.
However, in the year since September 1981, the employed total has dropped by nearly 13,000.
Grealy goes on to say:
These figures prove three things. The Tonkin Government had two good years, but --
He goes on to say-
the last has been a shocker for employment and South Australia is strapped into a downward slide.

That is the improvement we are talking about. So we have the spectacle today of the Minister for what we on this side of the House are starting to call him, the Minister of funny talks, presenting to the Senate a document lising projects for which the Tonkin Government, or so Senator Sir John Carrick claims, is responsible. He tells us that there has been a huge amount of $200m. I have had a chance to go through this list and analyse some of it. In fact I have not had a chance to go through more than about one-tenth of it. But let us have a look at some of these items listed in this document; for instance, Adelaide Brighton Cement Ltd, Birkenhead, an expansion of $17m. This expansion was announced under the Labor Government in 1979. It includes a new ship which was commissioned and started under the Labor Government. We turn then to the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd at Whyalla, and the projects there at the cost of $52.5m. These projects were announced by Des Corcoran the South Australian Premier in 1979. In fact, one of them was announced in March 1979 under the Labor Government. This list is littered, I might say, with companies that in recent months, in fact in the recent year, have had to retrench workers. I will come to them in a moment.

The list continues with Levi Strauss (Australia) Ltd at Elizabeth West, $2.5m, a project commenced in the early 1980s and commissioned under the Labor governments of Dunstan and Corcoran. We have the lube oil refinery expansion at Port Stanvac. That project was announced by Labor in 1979, at a cost of $20m. We go on again and again. We have the South Australian Brewing Co. Ltd, a $21m project for the rationalisation of production facilities, or so the Leader of the Government in the Senate claims. That project was announced by Hugh Hudson and in the 1977 annual report of the South Australian Brewing Co. Hugh Hudson was thanked by the Brewing Co. for the co-operation of the then Labor Government . Not only do we have projects that were commenced and announced and for which the Labor governments of Corcoran and Dunstan should take the credit included in this list but also we have included Government expenditure. For instance, included is the Woods and Forests Department at Mount Gambier, re-equipping of log mills, at a cost of $8.2m. How the inclusion of those sorts of statistics indicates any sort of industry confidence in the Tonkin Government is quite amazing.

I said that there was another aspect of this list which we should take into consideration. I refer to the scores of South Australian companies referred to by Michael Grealy which have significantly reduced their work force. When we go through that list we find that the names of companies which have retrenched staff also appear on this list. My submission to the Senate is that even though industries have invested in South Australia, much of that investment, approximately $121m in my very early assessment of the $200m projects announced by Senator Sir John Carrick, were of pre-September 1979 vintage. Since that period those companies which showed confidence in South Australia at that particular time are now in the position in which they have to retrench workers. Let us consider those companies. They include John Shearer Ltd, down 180; Adelaide Steamships Ltd, down 140, including its subsidiary the Mount Barker Tannery; Tubemakers of Australia Ltd, down 95; Trans Australia Airlines, down 40 ; Sapfor Timber Mills Ltd, down 75, and on the list goes, hitting both metropolitan South Australia as well as country areas. So we have this embarkation by the Tonkin Government on a scheme of deception in substitution of adequate policies which it is not geared towards either producing or presenting to the electorate. As another part of this deception we have the spectacle of the Premier of South Australia, last weekend, getting the nod from the Prime Minister. It is rather a strange thing to get from this Prime Minister, but Mr Tonkin says that he got the nod for a giant uranium plant. As quoted in the Sunday Mail last weekend, Mr Tonkin said:
The Prime Minister has indicated to me we have a better than even chance of getting a uranium enrichment industry ahead of Queensland . . .
After the Prime Minister's visit to South Australia, I am more confident than ever South Australia can win this plant.
That is not and was not the start of the deception. The deception started in a speech made by Mr Doug Anthony, the Deputy Prime Minister, on 7 October 1982. In South Australia Mr Anthony said:
South Australia is also under active consideration as a possible site for a uranium enrichment plant.
He referred to the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia and he said that it had given the Government:
a further report on its study into the feasibility of establishing a commercial uranium enrichment industry in Australia.
Senator Sir John Carrick continued the deception on 19 October in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suggest to you, Senator, that you should be careful about using the word 'deception'. I allowed it earlier because it related to remarks in general terms, but on the last occasion it was related to the remarks of a senator of this place, Senator Sir John Carrick.
—I withdraw it, Mr President.
—Thank you. I suggest that you watch that very carefully, Senator, because there is a difference in how that word is used and how others are used.

—Thank you, Mr President. The whole question of the development of this project was put to rest by correspondence from UEGA to members of this Parliament dated 20 October 1982. Let me quote a number of points from that correspondence. UEGA said:

SPEECH.PARA: UEGA is not proposing at this time to proceed with the construction of an enrichment plant in Australia, nor even with a detailed feasibility study.

That contradicts what the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Anthony, was saying. Let us look at the date of this correspondence-20 October, as compared with 9 October. It is much later correspondence. The Government cannot claim that there have been developments since then. The correspondence goes on to say:
Whether or not a detailed feasibility study is undertaken in the near future will depend on our joint assessment, with Urenco-Centec, of the extent and timing of future markets.

It is very much up in the air. It is very much, at this stage, pie in the sky. UEGA, in its correspondence to us, enclosed correspondence that UEGA sent to the Canberra Times. Let me quote a couple of passages from that. UEGA stated:

There is no firm proposal to establish an enrichment industry in Australia at this time. UEGA has merely advised the Australian Government of the preferred technology to be used as a basis for further studies and investigations. Whether or not a uranium enrichment industry is established in the future will be dependent on the results of the proposed market and feasibility studies. It is therefore quite premature to be talking of any enquiry of any kind.
Further on UEGA stated:

The key to the matter will be the size of markets available to an Australian plant. Such markets could be available in the early 1990s which is the timetable towards which UEGA is presently working . . .
The nomination of the technology for further study--
Which is the process which UEGA claims that it is undergoing now-
is merely one step in a fairly lengthy process of study and investigation.

Let us look at UEGA's stated commitment and compare it with the allegations of the Government, both State and Federal, and let us look at it in the light of the international scene. In doing so, I should like to quote an international authority in this area, Mr Walter Patterson, who is a nuclear physicist and the editor of the Bulletin of Atomic Scientists. He is also the author of the best selling book Nuclear Power. In mid 1981 he was asked about benefits from the uranium enrichment industry and whether he thought there would be a market for enriched uranium from South Australia in the late 1980s. He said:

Personally I very much doubt it. The industry's record of forecasting future demand is abysmal, and this is, of course, one reason why private industry and private finance world wide won't touch enrichment with a barge pole unless it is given iron clad guarantees.
When asked whether he thought that an enrichment plant in Australia would end up as a white elephant, he went on to say:

I think it is likely to be a very large white elephant which, once in place, will be a white elephant that will be very difficult to get rid of, because once you have that kind of financial commitment of capital investment in terms of hundreds of millions of dollars, you will find that the Government will not know how to stop.

So that is the only relief that the Government of South Australia is prepared to present to the people of South Australia. My time is all but up. It is very much the same situation as that of David Tonkin. He has nine days to go as Premier of our State, and from indications within the State parliamentary Liberal Party he will not have much longer to go as leader of that party.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak for some quarter of an hour in relation to world military and social expenditures and the disparity between the two which has emerged as a feature of this global community's madness, particularly in the decades since the Second World War. That this is a matter for concern cannot be doubted by any person of good will. Indeed, the desire for peace and disarmament which is being promoted this week around the world by the United Nations in particular, as this is United Nation World Disarmament Week, is a force with which I believe politicians everywhere will have to grapple, because it unlocks one of the deepest aspirations of mankind-to live in a peaceful society in which human beings can come to their fullest development. One is reminded forcibly of the quotation from the prophet Isaiah, in the great Jewish tradition, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: They shall beat their swords into ploughshares and their spears into pruning hooks. Nation shall not lift up sword against nation, neither shall they learn war any more.

That aspiration there given voice by Isaiah is one to which we would all wish to give voice ourselves. But we need to give voice to it in practical ways, because not only is it an aspiration but also it is an ethical imperative, for us individually and as a society. We have to see the ethical imperative calling us to evolve a system in which international disputes can be resolved peacefully, and we also need to devise a system in which the tremendously disparate expenditure on armaments is not such a feature of our communities. I shall outline some of the disparities shortly.

The fact is that there is, I believe, a hopelessness pervading the general community which comes about because of the awesomeness, the very nature of the destructive power, which could be unleashed from the nuclear arsenals of the super-powers. The fact is that we are confronted for the first time in human history with a completely new possibility-the annihilation of mankind. For that reason we need to come to this question of disarmament with a completely new perspective, a perspective that is not partisan nor determined by which country one happens to live in. We are very fortunate to live within one of the democracies, an industrialised democracy. Therefore, we are able to have rallies , which have occurred with increasing frequency and with increasing numbers of people participating. One thinks of the April rally this year right around Australia. Even in my area of north-west Tasmania last Sunday there was a rally organised by Don Herron and some country and western bands in the Burnie Park, where children gambolled and played with emus and kangaroos in what was really an idyllic setting, but it was a setting which those a little older than the children realised nevertheless had hovering over it the prospect of nuclear annihilation.

We in the democracies surely have a responsibility not only to give voice to our own fears but also to voice the concerns and fears of those in dictatorships who are not permitted to give voice to their very real concerns. Can it be denied that the mothers and fathers in Moscow and Leningrad fear as deeply for the future of their children as do the mothers and fathers in Washington or Sydney? If we do not express their fear then we could well be haunted by their reproach should the inevitable catastrophe occur. Even then, I am slipping into the wrong sort of language. It is not inevitable, it is likely unless we, around the world, take steps to tell the political leadership of the super-powers that to defend their concept of how society ought to be organised by the use of nuclear weapons is utterly immoral and likely to lead only to the destruction of both the competing systems which try to dominate this world.

It was indeed for that very purpose that I raised at Question Time yesterday, in perfectly good faith-it was responded to as such by the Minister for Finance (Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle)-the interesting report of a committee of the United States Catholic bishops conference, which stated, amongst other things, that any use of nuclear weapons is immoral and called for immediate bilateral verifiable agreements to halt the testing, production and deployment of new strategic weapons. I asked then whether the Australian Government, in conveying, as a constant and reliable ally of the United States to the American Administration its view as to the future of the world and the peril in which the whole of humanity is at present, would take into account the sorts of criteria that are there outlined by what might be thought to be-we have an historic reason to know what used to be-a most conservative body within the United States social and political establishment. If within that establishment there can arise that call then so much the more within Australia one would hope that this call could be made by a variety of community organisations.

One would expect that if the religions of the world-whether they are from the Hindu or Buddhist tradition, the Jewish, Christian or Muslim tradition-looked objectively at the sources of their tradition and at their great books and the words of their founders, they would find inspiration for giving hope. That is so necessary in this struggle because the lack of hope of course paralyses and induces an atmosphere in society where what is thought to be highly likely indeed becomes inevitable and is not protested against. In addition to the religious organisations within Australian society it is very gratifying to note the constant proliferation of non-government organisations, such as small community groups and groups under more widely known and respected national organisations such as the United Nations Association of Australia, which are gathering people together so that as a united force, although speaking from different traditions and perspectives, they might put forcibly to governments that disarmament is an absolute ethical priority and is imperative.

It is very pleasing to note that the United Nations Association of Australia has been putting forward the concept of a ministry of peace, so that at the highest level of Cabinet decision-making in Australia there might be that input which is so essential, that perspective which would be well researched and backed up, to enable those making the decisions to have a viewpoint put with the authority of a Minister of the government to supplement that view, and perhaps to contradict on occasion, the view of the defence establishments in particular.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sweden has such a ministry.

—I am informed by Senator Hill from South Australia, who I know has a very keen interest and concern in this matter, that Sweden has such a ministry . In that it may lead the way, a way which I hope we will follow. The point is that the armaments industry-the defence establishment and the bureaucracy which supports it-is an extremely powerful force within society in the sense that it is very hard for other forces within the society to shift the inertia. It has an ever growing, rapacious appetite for funds and expenditures which are thereby being diverted from the proper addressing of the real social needs of mankind. Honourable senators will be aware of the excellent annual publication put out by Ruth Leger Sivard entitled 'World Military and Social Expenditures'. I have the 1981 edition before me, in which the two expenditures, military and social, on a global scale are contrasted and outlined. For example I just pick a small point. It mentions that the world spends 2,300 times more for military activities than for international peacekeeping. The figures which I want to present to the Senate are contained in this thought: If there were an immediate reduction by half of the nuclear arsenals of the super-powers, some $50 billion could be saved in 1982. These savings would then be available for some of the real social concerns which humanity as a whole ought to be addressing. Here are some examples:

SPEECH.PARA: Unsafe water is a factor in 80 per cent of all infectious diseases. Over half the population of the Third World lacks an adequate supply of safe water; even larger numbers are without sanitation facilities. Water taps and sewage systems could halve the incidence of diseases like typhoid, dysentery, cholera--
It goes on to mention other notable diseases. To provide safe water for all within the decade some $7 billion would be required. Another example is:

Six diseases measles, poliomyelitis, tuberculosis, diphtheria, whooping cough, and tetanus, are child killers. WHO estimates that every minute 10 children may die as a result of these diseases. Although vaccines have existed for decades only 10 per cent of the 80 million children born yearly in the developing world are immunised. The cost of immunisation is $3 per child.

To speed vaccination protection for all children the expenditure would be $1 billion. There are but two examples of humanity-the poor, the opporessed and the children of this world-crying out for governments to direct expenditure to meet their real needs. One is reminded of the words of Pope Paul VI who said that armaments kill the poor by causing them to starve. In that statement one has encapsulated the very real truth that the very existence of the nuclear arsenals of the Trident class submarines, of the huge expenditure on maintaining military forces, even without their use, causes the poor to starve, the children to die and the malnourished and ill of this world to go untended. If we have any responsibility one to another as human beings without regard to partisan, racial , religious or sexist divisions then surely it must be that we all unite to ensure that the wealth of this globe is directed to the real needs of our fellow human beings.

One is always graphically reminded of what a fragile and interdependent world we live in when one sees the photographs of the earth taken from satellites or, more particularly, from the moon by those intrepid cosmonauts and astronauts who have stepped on to that satellite which has circled this earth for so many millions of years. When one looks down on the earth from that moon one sees, as I say, how small the earth really is. One realises what a great responsibility is involved in our being privileged to exist within the universe in such an environment as is the case with the earth. It is a great tragedy that instead of directing our resources, our abilities and our expertise in a creative fashion to ensure that all humans reach their full potential, we continue to divert so much expenditure into the arms race. I hope that the Senate responds to the constant plea of Australians and other persons throughout the world to ensure that our Government understands the real concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: — This, of course, is the last sitting day of the Senate before the South Australian election. Therefore, I feel that I should say something about the options facing the South Australian voters. It was just three years ago that the voters in South Australia overwhelmingly swept the Australian Labor Party out of office after a decade of government. They did so because they feared for the future, for their jobs and for their standard of living. They had accepted the social experiment of Labor; they had responded to the charisma of Dunstan. But, by the end of 1979, they recognised that no longer could the soft path, the soft options, be taken, that the relative position of South Australia had disastrously slipped and that the economic future under Labor management was gloomy.

SPEECH.PARA: What the Liberals offered was to return South Australia to its former competitive position; to reduce the costs of government and to be able, therefore, to reduce taxes; to encourage industry and investment by the advantages that follow; and, therefore, to offer to voters and even more importantly to the children of those voters a future in South Australia. The slogan was 'Let's make South Australia great, again'. The electors remembered when South Australia was in fact great. They accepted that, at the end of every party, there has to be a reckoning and, to use another famous election slogan, they said 'It's time'.

In just three years, all a government can do is build a foundation. If that foundation can be built when the world around us is in the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s, when 30 million people in Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries are unemployed, when the OECD growth rate is down to half of one per cent, when for the first time in 20 years international trade actually shrunk last year, a State government has done a good job. If it can build that foundation when its business is ravaged by the flow-down effects of the worst drought in Australia's history, it certainly deserves the opportunity to build upon that foundation.

The South Australian voters must make the decision whether to let the Liberal Government build on that foundation, the foundation which it has established over the last three years-in other words, further advance the mandate that they so enthusiastically endorsed just three years ago-or whether, in the panic of the world recession, they should grasp the soft options, the handouts, the artificial job creation schemes, the extension of protection-the traditional Labor alternatives which in the Federal sphere have been condemned so widely in the editorials which appear in today's newspapers. In difficult times it is tempting to take the easy course and not concern oneself with the question of who will pay.

In the last year, two most worthwhile papers have been produced in South Australia by the State Development Council. This body, which is made up of a highly accredited group of South Australian businessmen, academics and bureaucrats, was charged with the responsibility of recommending to the Minister of State Development in South Australia policy guidelines for the development of the State defining aims, objectives and priorities. The Council's report is set out in two volumes of a document entitled 'South Australia-A strategy for the future'. The report asks the question: Does South Australia have a chance of a prosperous future or is it destined to be a parochial stagnant backwater in Australian life? The report concluded that South Australia could grasp prosperity but only by taking the hard road, not by groping for the soft options . These two positive documents look at the strengths of South Australia. The second volume of the report recognises the strengths as follows: The changing view of South Australia's location from isolation to one of being advantageously placed in relation to the rest of Australia and the Asian-Pacific region; a lean , competitive agricultural industry which is capable of further development and diversification; a wealth of manufacturing experience, a stable, educated and skilled work force with a good industrial relations record, lower direct and indirect manufacturing costs; a revival of industrial development though one not yet sufficient to reduce the present disturbingly high unemployment rate-which is, of course, accepted; the rewards from resource development and exploitation are closer and the possibilities are expanding; low cost housing, a good education system, excellent community facilities, and in general a fine environment and life style.

Take those strengths and add to them the right philosophy of government. In that regard the question of the correct philosophy of government for economic recovery in South Australia was examined in the first volume of the report. The report looked at two alternatives. One advocates heavy emphasis on government involvement, protection of industry and regulation. The other prefers minimal government involvement and emphasis on individual enterprise and initiative. The report states:
The Development Council recommends policies based on the minimal- interventionist approach.

Add to that the right philosophy of encouraging an attitude that is positive, opportunist and innovative. One can contrast that with the Dunstan Labor rule in South Australia where the community was brainwashed not to expect too much but rather to lower its standards. The report states:
What exists can be turned into a springboard to success.

That is in fact the Liberal recipe. We were advised by this expert group that, if we are conservative, pessimistic, deprecatory and resistant to evolutionary change and ideas, the opportunity that is still apparent in the 1980s will be squandered. That is in fact, when examined, the Labor alternative.
So the cornerstone of Liberal Government policy in South Australia is investment and development. As was said in one view of the strategic plans, which appeared in the Adelaide Advertiser:
The political processes which determine who gets what are meaningless unless there is something there to distribute.

In South Australia, even in these difficult times, there is a government which has the runs on the board. It has in fact rebuilt the foundation. It can point to cuts in gift duty, death duty, payroll tax, and land taxes-in all a total in excess of $100m. It has been able to prune the public sector of more than 3,000 positions purely through attrition. It has been able to establish Technology Park to encourage firms developing high technology industry. It has upgraded the Small Business Advisory Bureau to provide information and management training.

What it is now able to offer prospective investors considering moving to South Australia is the lowest rate of industrial disputation in Australia, wage levels 6 per cent to 9 per cent below the national average, the highest percentage of skilled workers in Australia, industrial and residential land half the price of land in the eastern States, establishment grants of up to $400,000 for new industries with loan guarantees, payroll and land tax reimbursement and rent subsidies and opportunities that will be at the heart of resource development of the future.

The recipe which has been offered is working. Only in September the Premier announced results which showed that investment in manufacturing rose dramatically in South Australia against the backdrop of a national decline. He was referring to a survey by the Federal Department of Industry and Commerce which showed that investment in South Australia had jumped $440m in the six months to June of this year while in the other States it fell by $1,440m. Since October 1979, South Australia has attracted 19.5 per cent of the national total of investment which is, of course, well in excess of South Australia's share of the population which is 9 per cent. Overall investment committed or in the final feasibility stage for manufacturing and mining projects in South Australia had risen by $550m at the end of 1981 to $4,030m by the end of June this year. That is another figure which is in excess of South Australia's proportion of the population. New investment and development will bring new jobs and prosperity. One only has to look at the Roxby Downs development alone, for which a recent independent study by Melbourne's Monash University predicted up to 18,600 new jobs.

This is, in fact, an exciting time for South Australia. Roxby Downs, which I have just mentioned, is well on the way despite Labor opposition. The liquids pipeline to Stony Point has been completed and construction of the fractionation plant is on schedule. The construction of a refinery has now been announced. Feasibility studies for an associated petrochemical plant are continuing. The new international aviation terminal is ready to open and the first overseas flights will soon arrive. The new international hotel has been completed. The Tonkin Liberal Government has laid in just three years the foundation for the future prosperity of South Australia. It must now be given the opportunity to build on that foundation. In difficult times the electors must be aware of the Labor soft option that will not bring long term gain but will only further retard South Australia's competitive position and therefore its prospects.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose briefly in this debate on the motion for the first reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1982-83 to discuss a matter involving strange dealings in Tasmania. It concerns bottom-of-the-harbour companies and certain personalities are involved. It relates to a property at 159 Collins Street, Hobart, across the road from the Commonwealth Government Centre. The Commonwealth should have bought the property itself but did not. The Commonwealth now rents it from a company which paid a vastly increased sum for the property compared with its cost at the time when it was first offered for sale. At this stage I have more questions than answers about this matter. It is a further example of the strange dealings which go on in the world of property and business dealings which call for many more answers than we get.

SPEECH.PARA: The company to which I am referring is called Ancam Investments Pty Ltd. It began in 1973 in Victoria with people called Zarro as its directors. On 11 July 1979 Ancam Investments Pty Ltd began operations in Tasmania also and appointed a company called Murdos Pty Ltd. However, it operated in Tasmania for less than one financial year. It was out again before the end of the financial year 1979- 80, which seems a bit strange to me. I have documents which show the appointment of directors and an agent, that the registered office of the company is at 10 Victoria Street, Hobart, that the authorised capital of the company was $10,000 and that the Zarros were still directors of the company. On 19 July 1979, a few days after beginning business in Tasmania, the company bought the property at 159 Collins Street for a sum of $413,000. On 30 July 1979 Australian Guarantee Corporation Ltd leased the building. On 17 August 1979, within 18 days, Ancam sold the property to Wales Management Pty Ltd which, of course, is a company closely linked with AGC. That sale was for a sum of $1,027,755, a $600,000 profit in less than a month. That again raises all sorts of questions. On 19 June 1980, less than 12 months after Ancam commenced operations in Tasmania, it ceased trading in that State.

The story then goes back to Victoria. On 30 June 1980, still within the 1979-80 financial year, the Zarros resigned. On the same day the now infamous John Walker Wynyard of 142 Cathedral Street, East Sydney, was appointed as a director of a company called Shareholder Pty Ltd. Trevor Burton Huttley, whose name is also well known in connection with the tax evasion stories of recent times, was appointed as one of the secretaries. Ancam Investments Pty Ltd is one of those hunderds of companies that were listed in the National Times a couple of weeks ago as companies from which Mr Huttley resigned as secretary. The complication continues because on the same day as John Walker Wynyard was appointed a director of the company he resigned. On that day John Patrick Connell was appointed as director and as the other secretary of the company with Trevor Burton Huttley. So it is a complicated story of which I do not pretend to know all the ins and outs. But there is clearly enough information to require further investigation, especially as the property concerned involved the Commonwealth Government as what ought to have been a potential buyer and now as a sublessee leasing the property from AGC. It involves property speculation and a profit of $600,000 by Ancam over 28 days on an investment of $400,000. There is a link with certain tax avoidance personalities. I add that all this was happening right across the road from the Commonwealth Government Centre in the electorate of the honourable member for Denison and Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman.

One could go so far as to say that because the Commonwealth did not buy the property in the first place it merely encouraged the speculation which followed because the Commonwealth, in particular the Department of Social Security, occupied part of the building from July 1980. I seek answers to some of these questions: Was Ancam liable to pay tax on its $600,000 profit, made within that 28-day period? If so, has it been paid? To what extent is the Australian Taxation Office investigating Ancam Investments Pty Ltd? Has the company been involved in any other property deals in Hobart and are the appropriate authorities investigating this? I again ask the basic questtion that I raised some months ago: Why did not the Commonwealth Government buy the building in the first place as it needed the building to provide extra office accommodation for the Department of Social Security? The answer from the Minister at the time was that the building was not suitable for office accommodation. But not long after that-certainly after some renovations, but not very long after-the Commonwealth leased the offices for about $50,000 a year. They could have been bought by the Commonwealth, renovated and turned into the offices which it needed. But, I suppose because of its ideological objections to buying property instead of leasing it from private enterprise, the Government did not do that. It would be interesting to know to what extent Ancam was aware that the Commonwealth was going to sublease part of the building at the time it was sold for the highly inflated amount.

The situation is that the Fraser Government's property policies are clearly encouraging waste and extravagance by paying high rents when the Government could buy existing buildings or build appropriate office accommodation. The policies are obviously encouraging property speculation and tax avoidance. One would like to know to what extent such tax avoidance, involving property speculation by mainland companies who blow in and out of Hobart to make a fast buck on the way, is still happening and what efforts are being made by the Government to make sure that this sort of thing does not happen. In raising this matter, I raise more questions than answers, but they are important questions which ought to be asked. On this occasion they are being asked by me. They have been asked also by Kathy Smith, the Australian Labor Party's candidate for Denison, who has done a lot of work in querying this matter. I am pleased to be able to bring it to the attention of the Senate on her behalf.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hearn Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his Budget Speech, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) said:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia now faces more daunting economic prospects than for several years, with the possibility of prolonged recession overseas and high inflation and weak activity at home.
No mention was made of the high unemployment and the plight of the people who are unemployed. In last year's Budget statement on strategy, it was stated:

For more than half a decade the present Government has pursued an economic strategy directed towards establishing an environment conducive to sustainable strong private sector growth. To this end policies have sought to eliminate a number of distortions in the economy, the most important of which were inflation , an over-expanded public sector, and depressed profitability.

Again, there was no mention of unemployment or the people who are suffering as a result of it. Great numbers of Australian people are suffering as a result of the strategies and of this Government's policies. They are suffering not only material deprivation in a rich country but also the fear of insecurity for their jobs, for their family life, for the aged and for youth. Their hopes and dreams are shrivelled with the frost of monetarism. What benefit has resulted from these seven years of suffering? Where is the good management promised by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) seven years ago? The state of our nation suggests that we are the victims of bad management. The Government's philosophy of the user pays is in complete opposition to the accepted ethic that every person has a basic right to the necessities of life, security and dignity. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights states:

Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for health and well- being of himself and his family, including food, clothing, housing, medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability and widowhood.

It is only when people have these necessities that they can become constructive, creative and responsible forces in the community. Only when people's rights to these necessities are satisfied is there real democracy in a country. It is this force and this energy of people which this Government ignores. Yet it is only out of this force of the human spirit and the human person that the answers and remedies for the problems of these days will come. People must be listened to. Their problems must be heard. The miners recognised that the other day when they came to this Parliament to be heard. It is a necessity for Government to listen to what the people are saying and to their needs.

This Budget is concerned only with the economy. What research has been done by Government departments into the effects of Government policies on the families and the people of Australia, on the unemployed, on the aged and on our children' s development and their future? Surely we should be given some evidence of such research when a Budget is presented. There should be consideration of the effect of the Government's actions on families. Of all the things in the world, people are the most precious, and all things that are done should be done in the interests of those people. The way that the youth and the people of this country are being used and dehumanised to aid the economy goes beyond human acceptance. The results of this Government's policies are public issues which threaten the social, historic and spiritual environment of our nation. They are destroying the real values which are our people. They are not creating or building a national concept or a reality of which we can be proud. When the Royal Commission on Human Relationships made its interim report, it stated:
Our files are full of reports about increasing suicide among young people, unwanted pregnancies, battered wives, battered children, alcohol and drug abuse.

Does this sound like a happy society where people enjoy living, where people are creative and where people are achieving things? The pressing problem in Australia seems to be for its people to rediscover what it means to live in a real community where people matter, where people are concerned for one another's welfare and have a sense of purpose and values that makes existence become truly living. What are the basic needs of people? They are homes, income security and a sense of achievement. Why are people homeless in this country? Why should young and old people on low incomes be deprived of the most basic necessities of life, of shelter, good food, enjoyment and the simple pleasures to which people have a right? How do Federal Government policies develop security and allow people truly to live and not just to survive when their emphasis is only on economic principles and not on people?

The economic policies of the Federal Government are unethical. They totally lack social concern and social responsibility. It is the result of the Federal Government's policies that in the past 12 months, for the first time since figures started being collected, there has been no growth in employment throughout the country. At the same time the Federal Government promotes the family unit and yet at no time has the Government considered the impact of its policies on people or upon the family before it implemented them. In the area of work and unemployment these irresponsible policies are causing grave social problems. People have a right to work. If work is not available they have a right to a social security system which allows them to live in dignity. Today's workers are in fear of decisions made in board rooms overseas because profits being earned in this country are going overseas and are not being invested for the welfare of the Australian people. Men and women are being thrown on the scrap heap as though they are mere scraps of disused machinery.

The very foundations of Australian society and economy are shifting. The Australian economy is being transformed in ways that will change the character and the quality of our society for the worse-not for better. The control of our wealth producing resources which should belong to the Australian people is rapidly passing into foreign hands. Unemployment is rising; the social wage is deteriorating. There does not appear to be a very happy future or any hope for our greatest resource, which is our children. What is the Government doing about it? If the capitalist free market economy is so efficient, why is the Government in the mess it is now in? It has failed totally. Full employment is not impossible. A Labor Government achieved it during the rehabilitation program from war to peace after the Second World War. It is the will to achieve full employment that is lacking by the present Government. A Labor government would have that will to work and would act urgently to provide employment, hope and achievement for the people of this country.

The very foundation of our society means that people should be put first. To put people first means that work has to have a special meaning. At this time work is being denied its true meaning. Work is not only the means by which a person provides for his needs; through work a person produces the goods and services that his fellow men need. It is this which gives work its dignity and its purpose. Because this should be the quality of work it is wrong for its availability to be left to the whims, the manipulations and the fluctuations of the market place. We know that there is a huge amount of work to be done to supply the needs of people in this country. There is a need for planning to fulfil those needs. Workers have spoken to us about the fact that they are being made redundant because of the Government's policy to hand over to private enterprise in the name of so-called greater efficiency. What is that greater efficiency when workers lose their jobs? Some of these people have been in jobs for 10 to 30 years. Yet all their lives, their families and their homes, have to be sacrificed in the name of economic efficiency. We have to ask ourselves: Where is the greater efficiency? Is it efficiency in the services provided to the public? Is it efficiency in making our country a great country, or is it just economic efficiency to make greater profits?

I feel a deep shame at the way in which future generations will look back at our caretaking of this country and the history in which we are now taking part. We do everything to achieve the greatest profit. We take as much as we can from the soil and in our greed leave a desert. We sell our forests and leave a land of drought and salt. We rip out the wealth from our earth and leave nothing for future generations. We deny the money needed to develop our own culture and to educate our people. The foreign policies of this Government and other governments would even deny that there could be future generations. We do not have to follow the ways of the United States of America, Europe or any other country. So often people ask: 'Why can't we just be Australian-working for Australia and for our own future?'. Unless Australians control the resources of our country and unless the people of Australia are put before the growth and purpose of technology, Australia will become structured in the interests of international capital and not in the interests of the Australian people. I wish to conclude with a quote from Professor Manning Clark. He said:

In the nineteenth century Australians enjoyed the reputation of being in the vanguard of human progress: They were often the pioneers in the introduction of bourgeois democracy, and rather boastful about it. By contrast, in the twentieth century Australians seem to have missed the bus carrying humanity into the future.

Australians are no longer the pathfinders, but rather the men of the army in the rear . . . We had the institutions and the value to promote the use of parts of our country as quarries for foreign powers, but neither the institutions, nor the inclination, nor the belief to make our country a paradise for the people.

If Australians are once again to be in the vanguard of human progress they must insist that capital, the economy, technology and the services of government serve our people instead of the reverse situation which is now developing.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a first time.

The Schedule to this Bill is the same as that contained in the document ' Particulars of Proposed Expenditure for the Service of the Year Ending on 30 June 1983' which was referred to the Senate Estimates Committees on 24 August 1982 for examination and report.

DEBATE.TITLE: SENATE STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Children and Television: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:
