SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Committee will recall that last evening when considering clause 23 Senator Harradine raised some points relating to another possible avenue by which the needs of the State of Victoria might have been approached. These points were raised in response to some criticism that had been made of that State's action in imposing a levy upon health insurance contributors. I promised to get the honourable senator some information. Some information has come to hand just this moment. It has been quite difficult to get it all together. I will read the information I have to see whether it can help us by elucidating the point.

SPEECH.PARA: The Premiers Conference held on 25 and 26 June accepted the Commonwealth's proposal for new tax sharing relativities based on the 1982 report by the Commonwealth Grants Commission on tax sharing entitlements. It was a 1982 report . A condition of the Commonwealth's proposal then was that no special grants would be paid during the phasing-in period. That is the nature of what happened in June. The Victorian Minister of Health wrote a letter on 28 June. In that letter he noted that section 12 of the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act provides for a State's revenue raising capacity to be investigated by the Commonwealth Grants Commission. Given the heavy work load of the Commission over the last financial year it may have been impracticable to ask it to investigate the basis of the 1981-82 health grants. The Victorian Minister raised the possibility of the Commission examining revenue raising capacity applicable to the 1982-83 grants. He specificially asked:
Would you please let me know if you are prepared to refer this matter to the Commission?

The Minister whom I represent responded. In his response on 6 August 1982 he indicated that Mr Roper's suggestion of a reference to the Grants Commission would also not be appropriate. I think Senator Harradine was aware of that response. Mr Carlton's response did not indicate a refusal. It was made against the background on which decisions at the Premiers Conference were taken. It may be possible, if it is the desire of the Committee, to table the letters which passed between them. That could be done if honourable senators wanted to clarify this matter further. It may not be necessary, but I will not object to that course.

Under the Commonwealth Grants Commission Act 1973 States are entitled to seek an assessment by the Grants Commission on claims for special assistance. The basis of such a reference to the Grants Commission is an approach from the State Premier to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and to the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) who is responsible for the Grants Commission . That avenue is open; it is provided for. In the light of the above it was not open to Mr Carlton to refer the question to the Grants Commission as the procedure for an approach to the Commission is well established. It is another avenue. However, whilst the Minister did not consider that such a reference was appropriate, he did not preclude formal approach by Victoria to the Commonwealth on the specific question of the tax sharing grants. Particularly, the Minister's letter did two things: First, it provided the basis for the Commonwealth's assessment of revenue raising capacity and, secondly, it pointed out that the identifiable health grant was only a component of the tax sharing package. The tax sharing package as such is a matter for the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and, as honourable senators would know, the Treasurer properly has these matters under his consideration.

I am advised that there is no doubt that the Minister would facilitate in any way he could a formal reference to the Commission. To the extent that Senator Harradine's question to the Committee last night wanted to explore the possibility of going down that route, I hope that what I have said has clarified the matters raised. I am advised further that the report issued by the Grants Commission in 1982 actually makes clear the approach taken by the Grants Commission to these and other matters. I refer the honourable senator to pages 63 and 64 of that report. I can give further details if they are required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Committee well knows, the Australian Labor Party Opposition opposes this clause. I do not think anything the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has just said in answer to the question Senator Harradine asked last night changes our views on that clause. The matters under contention are, firstly, whether the Victorian Government can or should put such a levy on out-patients' attendances in Victoria through the voluntary health funds. Secondly, the matter of contention which has been very heavily alluded to by Senator Peter Baume is in fact the calculation, the actual costing , of this levy by the Victorian Government. At one stage Senator Peter Baume seemed to place great emphasis on this.

SPEECH.PARA: We have, as we frequently have, a dispute between a State and the Commonwealth about the level at which such a levy should be put on and the amount of money which would be raised by it. The Victorian authorities contend that they made their calculations on the basis of Commonwealth figures. There is a dispute. The Victorian Minister suggested that it should go to the Commonwealth Grants Commission. The Federal Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) in a letter to the Victorian Minister said quite clearly that this was not appropriate. Yet, we now have the situation where the Minister says: 'Although he said it is not appropriate, we could go down that road if we liked, if the Victorian Government made a formal application.' It seems to me, from the letter that was sent by Mr Carlton to Mr Roper, that the Commonwealth was clearly opposed to any independent arbitration, if that is what the Government wants to call it, about the size of this levy.

Another problem arises from concerns expressed by Senator Harradine and later expressed by the Minister that certain people would be disadvantaged by the application of such a levy. Such levies have been common in health insurance in this country and other countries. The basis of these levies is that we in fact end up with a community rating, a distribution of the costs of health care over the community. Senator Harradine expressed the concern, for instance, that country people would be disadvantaged because they do not have available to them the out-patients facilities that exist in the cities. I think there are two points to be made about that. The first is that country people are already disadvantaged if we just consider out-patients because the health funds build into their premiums a segment which is concerned with out-patients facilities. It is distributed throughout their contributors in the same way as this levy would be. The second aspect, of course, is that in Victoria or any other State there is, for instance, a considerably higher number of in-patient beds per capita in the country than in the city. In that way country people could be said to be at an advantage over city people. I put it to the Minister that in fact this means of distributing the premiums across all people, be they resident in the country, cities or suburbs, is the way in which the health funds themselves operate. It is a sensible way of applying a levy like this.

There is one final difficulty. The Victorian Labor Government has instituted this levy. Quite clearly from the correspondence, the previous Victorian Liberal Government was investigating this course of action and was talking about introducing the same levy. It was a continuous process as the governments changed. The levy, the collection of fees of this type, has been introduced into Victoria. The basic purpose of this levy is to provide a means of more simply collecting outpatients' fees and everything else. As Mr Roper and others have said in a Press statement today-they have said this on previous occasions also- one of the unfortunate results of the Federal Government's attempts to wipe out the levy in this way will in fact be that there will be a considerable decrease in the amount of funds available for hospitals in Victoria in the near future. Unfortunately, as a result of that action, expenditure in the hospital system in Victoria will be at risk. In fact, some jobs may well be at risk.

I think it is a very serious matter that the Government should quite suddenly, after the Budget, decide to tack this legislation on to the Budget without holding consultations of any meaningful nature with the Victorian Government. It suddenly announced that it would chop down on this action for the spurious reasons given by the Minister in another place. He announced that the Government would persist with this legislation. Provision is made in this legislation for pensioner health benefits and sickness benefits and we have been told that we should pass it and that we should ignore the fact that it will severely disadvantage the State of Victoria and the Victorian hospital system in particular. We have been told that, because one section of the legislation deals with sickness beneficiaries, it is our duty to pass what we consider is an offensive part of the legislation. I attempted to simplify the process by dividing the legislation. For reasons of which we are all aware, I was unable to do that. That would have made no difference to the treatment of this Bill in another place. I think we should persist with our opposition to clause 23 and Part IV of the legislation.

I urge the Government to come to some reasonable compromise with the Victorian Government rather than to put Victoria's out-patients services, hospital services and particularly employment in those areas under threat by what I consider to be precipitate and unfair action. I believe that States should be able to adjust the methods of collection of fees for out-patients in this way. I believe it is an administratively sensible cost-saving device. I believe in fact that it is as equitable as any method of collecting fees can be in our system. I think it is quite wrong of us to interfere with the Victorian Government's arrangements in this way. I repeat what I said last night: If the Federal Government tried to intervene with the Queensland hospital system-that system would be as contrary to the stated philosophy of the Minister for Health in this Parliament as is the Victorian Government system-all hell would break loose. Of course, the Government will not attempt to do this because the ideology of the Queensland Government is so much akin to this Government's ideology that it does not want to be seen to be in dispute with the Queensland Government. I urge the Committee to continue to oppose this clause.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add a little to the point that Senator Grimes made relating to the possible loss of jobs in Victoria if the Victorian health levy proposal is not implemented. I have taken some considerable pains this morning to look into this matter. I am sure that the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) will be only too glad to correct me if I am wrong but I understand that the $20m shortfall that apparently will affect Victoria in the next six months is likely to mean a loss of jobs, not for one, two or even 200 people but for up to 2,000 employees of the Victorian Government, who work at the moment in Victorian hospitals. Quite frankly, I cannot see how any government could allow itself to compound a mistake, which was of its own making apparently, to affect so drastically a further 2,000 people in a period of massive unemployment not only in Victoria but also right across the country.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Grimes raised the hypothetical question of Federal Government interference in Queensland vis-a-vis the manner in which the Government is prepared to interfere with the Victorian Government's policy decisions on health matters. What is going to happen in States like Tasmania and South Australia when 1985 rolls around and those States too fall into the same sort of grant system that is now affecting Victoria? What will happen if, in the intervening period, the governments change, as is likely to occur in South Australia? How many more people will be thrown out of work simply because the Government makes some sort of arithmetic mistake and then is prepared to compound that mistake when the State government concerned attempts to take corrective action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I know that other honourable senators want to speak in this debate. I respond by saying that the argument put forward by Senator Haines is not sustainable. On 16 May, Mr Roper presented a paper in which he made it clear that the revenue shortfall in Victoria was due in part to that Government's incapacity to mount the appropriate resources to collect the money. The money was there. The services had been given. The money was recoverable. Mr Roper, at page 9 of his paper, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The incapacity of hospitals to devote the requisite resources to the pursuit of fees for all chargeable occasions of service-means that the hospital benefit funds are avoiding payment of benefits . . .

Clearly the capacity was there for Victoria not to have a shortfall had it decided to put into place the resources which were necessary to collect what was its under a process to which we would not have objected.

I do not want to go over all the arguments that we have gone over as to why the Government opposes the levy introduced by the Victorian Government, but I should like to draw Senator Grimes's attention to page 1908 of yesterday's Senate Hansard. There Senator Harradine is reported as setting out some of the bad features of the levy and some of the systematic effects it will have which are undesirable. He made a number of points. I will not go through them. Among other things, he said:
Many people in country districts of Victoria will not have the ability to go to outpatient departments. I am concerned about it because of the principle and the likely flow-on to other States.
Further on he makes this comment:

Also, whilst I consider that another problem about this whole question of a levy of the character that is being proposed in Victoria is that it appears to shed responsibility for accountability in certain public hospitals, let me say this very clearly . . .

I have had a chance to look at what my colleague said and I should like to endorse those kinds of criticisms. It is not just a simple matter of efficiency, as set out by Senator Grimes. It has some quite significant adverse effects and the Government will persist with the clauses as they are. It will oppose any move to remove the clauses. I do not wish to prolong the debate unduly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to prolong the debate but I have to answer a couple of points made by Senator Peter Baume. First of all, I spoke of the concern that Senator Harradine had for country people. I pointed out that in fact this disadvantage exists under the present system and is counterbalanced by other factors. It is inherent in the present system of voluntary health insurance. It is not unduly aggravated by the levy which is intended to be imposed.

SPEECH.PARA: The second thing is that I think the costs of the collection of funds are important. It is not just in Victoria that a government is having difficulties in collecting out-patients fees, as Senator Baume has said. Hospitals are designed to assist people who are ill. If they have to divert manpower and finance to the collecting and processing of accounts, inevitably they have to have that much less in resources for the caring of people. The aim of this levy, which is certainly creating interest in other States, is to make the collection of out-patient fees more efficient and more equitable and to enable hospitals to concentrate more on treating people and less on running around trying to collect bills.

I come to the final point I want to make. It concerns something that is frequently said in this place. It is false and it is an insult to the people in public hospitals to suggest that the best way of making them accountable for what they do is to have them going around collecting individual bills from people. One never hears comment of that sort about the Queensland hospital system from members of the Government. We only hear about it when we are talking about the Victorian or New South Wales hospital system.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the insistence of the AMA.

—Sure. The people who run these hospitals are people who run efficient hospitals and who are concerned about their patients. If the hospitals are not run efficiently, if they are not properly accountable, there are procedures available through their boards, government regulations and everything else to improve that accountability. To suggest last night that the key way and the only way that that accountability can be improved is to have people crossing the palm with silver at each service is utter nonsense and Senator Baume knows it is nonsense.
—Who said that?

—The Minister said it. He said that one of the best ways to make public hospitals accountable for their services is to wipe out this levy and have them charging individual fees for individual services. That is nonsense.
—Show me where I said that, Senator.

—The Minister had better explain what he did say. I have heard that said so often in the Senate before and it is the sort of explanation that we get all the time from the other side of the chanber. If the Victorian Government system is not good enough for the Minister, I suggest that the Queensland Government system is not good enough for him and he ought to get stuck into the Queensland system. The Minister should be a bit consistent and not try, because of his ideological blinkers, to put a State Government under difficulties, and should not put the jobs of hospital workers in Victoria under threat just because of the insistence of the Australian Medical Association and the voluntary health insurance funds in this matter. He should remember that the hospital associations and others are very much in favour of the procedures used in Victoria. I think we should consider their views, the views of the Victorian people and the views of other commentators in the field just occasionally.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —It appears that this matter can be relatively easily overcome because it appears from the answers given today by the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) that there has been some misunderstanding between the Commonwealth Government and the Victorian Government. The Minister said today that in June 1982 the Minister for Health in Victoria, Mr Roper, wrote to his counterpart in the Commonwealth Government, Mr Carlton, indicating that it was the desire of the Victorian Government that the question of the capacity of the State of Victoria to raise the revenue proposed to be raised should be referred to the Commonwealth Grants Commission. At that stage apparently the Minister for Health considered that matter and, in a response to Mr Roper in August of this year, indicated that that was not, in his words, appropriate.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Peter Baume, the Minister representing the Minister for Health, has stated clearly to the chamber that it is now the attitude of Commonwealth Government to facilitate this reference to the Commonwealth Grants Commission. It seems to me that under those circumstances the raison d'etre for the intoduction of the levy in Victoria is gone because the initial argument that was mounted by the Victorian Government over this issue was that the Commonwealth Government, in considering the arrangements to be made for Victoria in respect of tax sharing and health grants, had underestimated the amount of money that Victoria could raise and its capacity to raise revenue in respect of public hospitals. It seems to me, therefore, that the undesirable features of the Victorian levy would not be necessary if an objective analysis were undertaken of Victoria's capacity to raise that revenue. I think that the whole of the chamber would agree, and I suspect that the Victorian Government also would agree, that if it could have avoided the type of levy that it introduced and had passed through the Victorian Parliament it would have done so.

We have a situation in which the Victorian Government has a responsibility for health. It has undoubted tax gathering powers that the Commonwealth should not take away from it. On the other hand, the Commonwealth Government is using its undoubted insurance power under the Constitution to block that levy. I am concerned, as I said last night, about the flow-on effects of all of this. One point that was raised by the Minister last night is that the Commonwealth Parliament has an interest in this matter for another reason and that is that the real tax gathered by the Victorian Government in that way is tax deductible because the people who are paying the levy are in fact paying the contributions, and that is tax deductible. That, of course, affects the Commonwealth Parliament 's tax gathering rights as well. So in my view there is in place, under the States (Tax Sharing and Health Grants) Act, a mechanism to overcome the very problem for which the Government of Victoria has mounted this levy. My understanding now of the Minister, and it appears to be a fresh policy that the Minister has stated in the House today, is that the Commonwealth Government, to use his words, 'would facilitate the reference to the Grants Commission'. Therefore, in those circumstances, I am prepared at an appropriate time, to seek leave for the Senate in some way-whether it be this Committee or at the third reading stage-to request the Government to refer to the Commonwealth Grants Commission the question of the capacity of Victoria to raise the revenue proposed to be raised by the proposed taxation of health funds.

The Minister having stated his Government's policy on this issue, the Government surely should go along with that proposal. If it is prepared to go along with it, I am prepared to support the Bill as it is, because what worries me is the timing of this whole episode. The Senate is faced with either having to pass the Bill or, if it knocks out these clauses, having to send the Bill back to the House of Representatives. We all know that the House of Representatives is getting up today-or whenever. The situation is: All right; if they refuse it, it comes back to us. What do we do at the end of that line? If we then still take out those two clauses, the Government can say, with some justification, that we are holding up the pensioner health benefits which are incorporated into the Bill.

All that I am proposing is that this seems to me a way out of the problem. It seems to go to the crux of the issue, to the problem where it first started-the underestimation by the Commonwealth of the revenue gathering capacity of the Victorian hospitals-and then the matter can be referred to the Grants Commission . Obviously, once the Grants Commission has considered that matter it is then up to the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Victorian Government to give due consideration to that and to come in with supplementary legislation. That seems the obvious way of overcoming this problem. Therefore, it is my intention to vote for the legislation as is, and it will then be my intention to move that proposition, as outlined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate Senator Harradine's difficulties. I appreciate that he has gone through the same sort of soul searching as people in the Australian Labor Party and, I suspect, people of the Australian Democrats have gone through. He knows, as we know, that the Government will attempt to accuse us of preventing people with sickness benefits from getting pensioner health cards if the legislation does not go through. But there is one aspect of the legislation which I believe Senator Harradine has ignored, and it has been the thing that has held us up. Firstly, I believe we should oppose the Government's action in clause 23 and Part IV, because that is the right thing to do. Secondly, we must consider the immediate consequences of the legislation going through as it is.

SPEECH.PARA: The first consequence is that the health funds in Victoria, as they have said repeatedly, will immediately stop paying this levy. The second consequence is that as a result of that, the Victorian Government will be in immediate difficulty with its funding of hospitals. The third likely outcome of that, I am afraid, is that numbers of hospital workers will have their jobs threatened. What the Victorian Government must do if the legislation goes through in its present from is immediately to assist hospitals and others to set up what I think even Senator Peter Baume will admit is this complicated and administratively cumbersome system of ensuring that it collects all these outpatient fees. The only group which will benefit from this legislation going through, certainly in the short term, is the voluntary health funds. That is why they are putting on the pressure in the way in which they are.

TALK.START.PARA: —The contributors.

—The voluntary health funds will immediately have great delays before they have to pay up. They will have this great advantage of having money in their funds, invested, and all the other things that they do with it, and the Victorian Government-the people of Victoria, if you like, Senator Walters-will be the people who will suffer from this. It is for that reason that I do not believe that we should pass the legislation as it is. It is for that reason that this House should take note of the views of the Victorian Government and remove these three clauses from the legislation. Finally, the Government could, of course, take this legislation to the House of Representatives, accept the amendments and have it come back here. As it is not a cash sum, the Government can make simple arrangements, as exist now with the disadvantaged health card, to ensure that the sickness beneficiaries get their pensioner health benefits card retrospectively and are covered for illnesses which occur beyond 1 November . This chamber should not be blackmailed in this way into passing this legislation because that small group of sickness beneficiaries might not be eligible for their pensioner health benefits card next week. We are in this situation because the legislation came in too late.

SPEECH.PARA: I make one final point. This is the third time in my period as shadow Minister for Social Security that the Government has adopted this tactic. Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle did it when the Government attempted to abolish the funeral benefits. She said in this place, 'If you people do not accept the Bill and do not accept that we are abolishing the funeral benefits, the pensioners and unemployed beneficiaries will not be paid', and people on the Government side of the House described that as blackmail, and that is what it was. When we had earlier in the year legislation about payments to families and wives of people involved in industrial disputes, exactly the same thing happened with Senator Chaney. We were here until 1 o'clock or 2 o'clock in the morning with the Government saying: 'If you do not go along with every bit of this legislation, including the bit tacked on to it, we shall not pay the pensioners or unemployment beneficiaries, and it will be your fault.' As the people then accepted, they will also accept now that if this legislation to provide a pensioner health benefit card for sickness beneficiaries does not go through, it is the fault of no one but the Government. The fault is on the Government's side , firstly, because the legislation has come into this chamber so late; secondly, because the House of Representatives is getting up early, when its program, which we were all given, provided that it sit for another three weeks; and thirdly, because if the Government was really concerned about the matter, it could take the legislation back and get it back here in time.

This chamber should not be stood over by these blackmail-type tactics. If the Government just refuses to cop this amendment at all, if the Government takes the legislation back and will not have it, eventually the legislation will go through in some form, and there is no reason why arrangements cannot be made for those sickness beneficiaries to receive their entitlement to their pensioner health benefit card retrospectively-that is, their entitlement to medical treatment and to free pharmaceuticals. It may be a nuisance, but I believe that it is better that we be not stood over in this way and that we continue to oppose clause 23 and Part IV of the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats support what Senator Grimes, on behalf of the Australian Labor Party, has just said. We believe the action of the Government, in tacking these two irrelevant, extraneous matters on to the Budget Bill, is a sneaky exercise. It is a snide exercise. It is loaded with hypocrisy and it is a heartless act-trying to score cheap political capital at the expense of sick people. I hope that honourable senators on the Government benches will take heed of those accusations. I wanted to read into Hansard-because I believe it has not been done yet-a statement released today, of which I have a copy, of the Victorian Minister of Health, Mr Tom Roper. Either Mr Roper is telling an untruth-I do not believe for one moment he is-or the Senate has to answer Mr Roper's statements. The Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) has to answer the statements and allegations that I am about to read out. Apart from other things, I am a Victorian senator. These are serious statements by a Minister of the Crown in Victoria. His Press release reads:

SPEECH.PARA: The Federal Government was posing a direct threat to the jobs of thousands of Victorian health workers in its attempt to quash the Victorian Government's health levy . . .
I am leaving out the political asides that Mr Roper inevitably makes in his Press statements. I know the chamber will excuse me for doing that. The statement continues:
Put quite bluntly the Federal Government is playing politics with the jobs of hospital workers and the health of many Victorians.

That is an extraordinarily serious allegation for a Minister of the Crown to make against the Federal Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) and the Minister representing him in this chamber. The statement continues:

If the Federal Government's legislation is passed it will mean a shortfall of $ 20 million in the State's health funding. This can only be met by laying off staff. The saving would have to be made in the second half of this financial year and this would mean that up to 2,000 jobs could be lost before Christmas.

I would like to hear from Senator Peter Baume whether that statement or that estimate from Mr Tom Roper, the Minister of Health in Victoria, is correct. Is this an extravagant or a wilful misleading of the public or this chamber? Can the Minister prove those words to be wrong? Has he any solution if he can see there is some validity in that statement? The statement goes on to say that there will also be longer waiting times and less efficient services. One could well say that Mr Roper is doing this for political purposes. It would be a strange political exercise. He has just been elected. I cannot see why he would be doing this. I cannot see why the Federal Labor Party and the Democrats would be taking the stand they are because with the influence Mr Fraser has with the media-I am talking about the people who write the headlines-there is no question that he will come out tomorrow with a misleading statement that the Senate is being obstructive, disruptive and holding up Budget legislation. I would like to hear from Senator Peter Baume this time, not Mr Carlton. Senator Peter Baume is in charge of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982 in this chamber.

Why does the Government not allow it to be split? Why does it go to the despicable, sneaky and snide tactic of tacking on two extraneous matters, which are totally irrelavant to a Budget, on to a Budget Bill? Obviously it was so that he could go to the Press with a cheap headline to say: 'Look, the Senate is being obstructive and disruptive again'. That is a pretty rotten sort of exercise if the jobs of 2,000 health workers could be put at risk before Christmas. I am not necessarily accepting Mr Roper's figures but I want Senator Peter Baume to deny them in this chamber, to say that they are not right. I am very attracted to Senator Harradine's proposition, in its philosophical thrust, of having the Grants Commission substantiate or otherwise this claim. However, I do not trust this Federal Government on this issue. I am not prepared, as Senator Harradine is-with great respect to him-to give the legislation a blank cheque and pass clause 23 and Part IV of this Bill. Once that is done the party is over; the Bill goes back to the House of Representatives.

I plead with the media to expose any attempt by Mr Fraser, the Liberal Party, or above all Mr Anthony, to make out that this is a plot by the Senate to obstruct the Government. The House of Representatives is getting up tonight or tomorrow. For how long has it sat or will it have sat when it finishes? In the second six months of this year it will have sat for only eight weeks-24 days out of six months. Yet this legislation is coming in here now. I can hear those highly paid people in Mr Fraser's office rattling their typewriters typing out Press releases. They will be up in the Press gallery before 6 o'clock saying: ' Look what the Senate has done to us again. If the Senate obstructs this Bill today it will not be passed before 1 November or 1 January when the benefits accrue to the beneficiaries in this Bill'. The Government will say: 'It is the Senate's fault'. I am sorry to say that there will be some members of the media- not all, thank God-who will run that naked headline on page one tomorrow: ' Fraser says ''Senate obstructs again'' '. They will then eulogise the actions of the Government even though it is getting up after sitting only 24 days of the last half of the year. I would have thought that that is one of the most outrageous things I have seen in the many years I have been here. I can remember a few years ago in the House of Representatives when Dudley Erwin and Billy Snedden abused the Parliament by using the guillotine to rush legislation through. Every newspaper in this country carried an editorial condemning the deterioration of parliamentary standards, using the Parliament as a rubber stamp . They did that to poor old Dudley Erwin, whose major crime was to whip through 15 Bills in an all night sitting. What is this doing to the parliamentary institution? Why is this irrelevancy tacked on? Where is the Government's philosophy about States' rights? If it does this to John Cain in Victoria why does it not chat up Bjelke-Petersen in Queensland, whose system of health insurance is so much further down the track than what is proposed by the Victorian Government? I hope that the media will look at the proposition that the Senate has a right to review legislation. We very strongly believe that we are exercising that right now in a proper way and responsible way without being obstructive. If this chamber decides to knock out these two clauses then why should the House of Representatives not come back the week after next, or whenever, to contemplate that amendment and amendments to other legislation?

The suggestion that Senator Harradine has put could be a way towards a compromise between the Government parties in the Senate and those non-government parties in the Senate. I believe if the matter of whether Mr Roper's figures are correct is handled sensibly, with the idea of trying to reach a consensus, it should be referred to the Grants Commission before the legislation is passed. Why not? I make this final plea to Senator Peter Baume: Why not split off the irrelevancy today? We will pass the Bill in five minutes. I say that without having to get the concurrence of Senator Grimes because I am sure he would agree . The Government can have the Bill intact in five minutes without clause 23 or Part IV. All the benefits accruing can then be granted. We would agree to obey the umpire's decision, if that is the way it can be expressed, about whether the figures of Mr Roper are fair dinkum or not. I do not think we can be fairer than that. But we are not going to be stood over by the Government, which appears to be the case at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It may not be appropriate for me to try to respond to the rather extravagant rodomontade of some parts of Senator Chipp's speech. However, I will try to pick out the essence of what he was addressing. He raised issues which we had not raised and then proceeded to demolish them. As a result, a number of straw men came to grief. But let me take the point that he did raise and to which he wants a response.

SPEECH.PARA: First of all I have already advised Senator Harradine of the willingness of the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton) to try to facilitate a reference to the Commonwealth Grants Commission. I take it that if this Bill remains intact Senator Harradine would seek to move a motion at a later stage.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is what I have said.

—The Government would not oppose that course of action; it would in fact go along with that. I think that Senator Chipp at the end of his speech asked how we would respond to Senator Harradine's suggestion.
—Why don't you knock out clause 23 and then do it?

—I will answer Senator Chipp anyhow. I am giving an indication that we will go along with that suggestion. Fancy asking me to comment in detail on what was, in Mr Roper's statement, a most blatant attempt to blackmail the Senate by trying to pretend that jobs are at risk in Victoria as a result of what we do today.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me answer several points. First of all, if one goes back over the years one will see that this Bill has always been an omnibus Bill. It has always contained a number of provisions which have ranged across the area of health insurance and benefits. This Bill is no different. I confirmed a moment ago that the proper Bill in which the matter which is being disputed now should be contained is the Bill before the Committee. This is the proper Bill in terms of Government policy and legislation. Any claim that there is a tacking on is to ignore the quality of legislation of this sort over the years. It is to ignore the fact that this legislation always contains a variety of matters-matters such as the one we are now considering and matters related to the regulation of health insurance. Future legislation of this sort will do the same. There is nothing improper in including this material in the legislation before us. As I said yesterday when the question of divisibility came up, I was not arguing the question of divisibility; I was arguing what I thought was the proper approach on this matter.

Certain questions have come up about what will happen if Victoria does not have this excessive and punitive levy in place. First of all, Victoria still has a fee collecting mechanism in place. Uninsured persons, from whom a fee is collectable, are still attending hospitals. There is no reason why Victoria cannot charge the fees which are due to it for out-patients as well as inpatient services. There is no reason why Victoria cannot now put in place the mechanism for collecting fees which was not previously in place. But more than that-and this is what seems to have been missed by honourable senators; I think it has been missed by Senator Chipp-this matter does not just involve a choice between two methods, between a levy proposed by Victoria and a charge on every patient, as was the previous practice. I put it to Senator Chipp that a number of mechanisms are being developed around Australia. In South Australia negotiations between government and the funds are well in progress to try to arrange for the collection of out-patients charges by a form of direct billing. This arrangement may be made for administrative convenience, but at least it will relate the collection to the number of services rendered. There are various ways in which one might be able to collect revenue which might be suitable for a particular hospital system and a particular State and by agreement between the funds.

The Victorian Government, of course, increased its charges very considerably from 1 July. We did our calculations on the charges as they then were. But I just remind honourable senators that the Victorian out-patient fee has gone up from $15 to $20, the multi-bed ward fee from $80 to $110 a day and the single room fee from $110 to $150 a day. Therefore Victoria's revenue raising capacity has gone up considerably as a result of what it has done. It has the staff to collect charges now. It can go back to collecting them. Senator Harradine has proposed that if the Government's provisions remain it will be appropriate for the Senate to seek to have a reference made to the Grants Commission. I would have no objection to following that course. The Government wishes to see these provisions retained. It is early in the afternoon; the Committee will do as it wishes.
Question put:
That the clause stand as printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.
