DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope the Senate will allow me to interpose a matter that was mentioned to the President this morning. The report in question had not been printed at that time. I present the 16th Report of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in relation to Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1982-83, Australian Capital Territory Tax (Vehicle Registration) Amendment Bill 1982, Income Tax Assessment Amendment Bill (No. 5) 1982 and Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Committee, I lay on the table Scrutiny of Bills Digest No. 14 dated 28 October 1982.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —With the consent of the Whips, on behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 199th Report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a short statement in relation to that report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to thank honourable senators for their indulgence in allowing me to table this Report on such a busy day. I regret that there is limited time for this report to be debated in the Senate but the Committee believes that it was more important to make the Report available for the information of senators so that informed discussion might ensue both in this place and elsewhere.

This is a most significant Report which impacts upon the whole of financial administration as it, for the first time, brings to the fore the question of proper standards that should be applied in Government accounting.

The Committee's 199th Report, on the Form and Standard of Financial Statements of Commonwealth Undertakings, is the third in its series of discussion papers on significant issues of accountability and management in the Australian public sector. The previous discussion papers tabled by the Committee were on Internal Audit, and the Collection and Dissemination of Statistics.

In June 1980 a Joint Working Party consisting of officials from the Department of Finance and the Auditor-General's Office published an exposure draft and abridged report on proposed guidelines for the form and standard of financial statements of Commonwealth undertakings. The Joint Working Party asked the Public Accounts Committee to comment on the guidelines and this report provides a substantive response to this request.

The Commonwealth considered that the Joint Working Party's request was timely because it has been apparent for many years that financial statements of many statutory authorities do not reflect the full scope of management accountability which devolves from Government. While acknowledging that reserve powers are usually granted to Ministers under enabling legislation for the creation of authorities, the Committee considers it is management which shapes the destiny of undertakings in everyday affairs and operations.

In such circumstances we cannot support propositions that statements of receipts and payments indicating legal and financial compliance with Statutes and appropriations properly convey adequate disclosure of operations in financial terms. Managers of undertakings should be accountable for the use of all resources over which they exercise control. Acquisitions and depletion of resource must be integrated with operating transactions so that informed decisions about potential solvency and the capacity to undertake objectives of the authority can be made. This theme is central to formation of the guidelines and modern concepts of effective public sector management.

The members of my Committee fully support efforts to increase relevance, uniformity and consistent application of sound accounting methods, so that financial reporting in the public sector will better serve the community and particular parties at interest. We believe that parliamentary support for this undertaking will enhance the commitment of statutory bodies to the proposed guidelines and strengthen co-operation needed for their successful adoption and implementation. The Committee is heartened to learn that the general response to the exposure draft has been favourable and encouraging.

As a result of its deliberations, which have extended over nearly two years, the Committee has formulated several recommendations designed to improve the standard of financial reporting at all levels of government throughout Australia . The major recommendations of the discussion paper are that:

A genuine research effort should be mounted employing resources from both within the accounting profession and outside of it, to systematically construct a relevant theoretical framework for financial reporting by public sector authorities.
Any adoption of private sector accounting standards should be seen as a short term solution.
Cash based accounting should be eliminated as the primary focus for financial reporting by authorities except for extremely small agency situations and accrual accounting should be adopted.
Funds statements of Commonwealth authorities are to adopt a total resources rather than working capital or cash basis of funds and are to be published as part of the formal financial statements.

The Joint Working Party should join with accounting and other interested groups to further evaluate the nature of financial reporting by public sector bodies. Government financial support at Commonwealth and State levels should be sought by a suitably organised proposal from the accounting profession.
Program statements should be prepared by all Government undertakings except where such a statement would disclose necessarily confidential information.
The audited financial statements of all Government organisations should be presented to Parliament within six months of the close of the financial year to which they relate.

An Accounting Standards Review Committee should be established to examine Government accounting and reporting standards, and to make recommendations for improvement. This committee should consist of representatives from the Parliament, the Public Service and the accounting profession.

Discussions should be held between relevant Commonwealth and State Government ministers and officials on the desirability of introducing a uniform set of accounting standards and procedures for public sector authorities at all levels of government throughout Australia. An appropriate mechanism for this issue to be considered would be for a working party to be established by the Premiers Conference.

In considering the question of accounting standards for government, the Committee, by necessity, has had to examine the adequacy of many private sector methods. In its examination of the private sector standard setting process the Committee is concerned only with its relevance to the public sector. No judgments are made on the adequacy of the process or standards for the private sector itself.

In the longer term it may be possible to draw a closer link between private sector and public sector reporting. In the meantime, the Committee observes that differences, including the noticeable tendency of the community to identify operations of statutory bodies with the appropriate Minister rather than with management, are becoming more pronounced. If the control of these bodies is seen as a function of the Westminster system of government then accounting principles based on the separation of ownership and control may need modification. A distinct and rigorous philosphy of accounting in the public sector may need to be formulated.

At an early stage in the preparation of this paper the Committee decided that it was essential for government accountants throughout Australia to discuss and evaluate the issues addressed by the Joint Working Party's Report. To fulfil this requirement the Committee, in association with the Government Accountants Groups of the Australian Society of Accountants, conducted seminars in all State capital cities. These seminars were attended by over 1,000 accountants, which indicates that there is a high degree of professional concern on the issues.

The degree of enthusiasm shown by all sections of the accounting profession to participate in these discussions has impressed the Committee. We are conscious that a strong effort from all professional accounting interests is required if substantial progress is to be made in improving financial reporting in the public sector. The Committee wishes to take this opportunity to thank all those involved in these seminars.

In common with its other discussion papers, the Committee recognises that many of the views expressed are subject to disagreement and debate. We would therefore welcome further contributions or comments from interested individuals or organisations on any aspect of this discussion paper.

The Committee also wishes to express its appreciation to its senior advisor on accounting, Dr Max Aiken, also Mr David Shand, Dr Ian Ball and many others for their considerable assistance and advice in the preparation of this paper. The Committee also wishes to place on record its appreciation for the work of the Sectional Committee, which I was privileged to chair. Other members of the Sectional Committee responsible for the preparation of this paper were Senator George Georges and Mr Jim Bradfield, MP and Mr David Connolly, MP. I commend the report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts, I present the 201st report of the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement relating to the efficiency audit of the administration of bilateral overseas aid , report No. 201.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to thank honourable senators for their indulgence in allowing me to table this report on such a busy day. I regret that there is limited time for this report to be debated in the Senate but the Committee believed that it was more important to make the report available for the information of senators so that informed discussion might ensue both in this place and elsewhere.

Unfortunately, copies of this report are limited at the moment due to constraints in printing, but there will be copies for perusal in the Table Office and the Parliamentary Library. It is expected that there will be sufficient copies for distribution to all senators shortly.

The report has particular significance to the community and the Parliament on three counts. First, bilateral overseas aid is a major item in the Commonwealth Budget. Bilateral aid forms the major part of Australia's official development assistance budget, a budget which totalled $727,207,000 for 1982-83. This is nearly half of one per cent of Australia's gross national product, or over one and a half per cent of total Commonwealth Government outlays; that is, over one and a half per cent of all the moneys expended by the Commonwealth itself on Commonwealth programs and of moneys provided to the States, local government and other agencies to support programs they administer.

Second, the report is significant because it provides a rare opportunity for the Parliament to examine the way in which this enormous sum of money is expended. Such opportunities are unfortunately infrequent and a substantial part of the Committee's report is devoted to a description of the bilateral aid program, to suggestions as to how the aid program could be more effectively examined by the Parliament and, perhaps most importantly, how public and community awareness of the principles which guide the aid program and the resources devoted to it can be increased.

Finally, the report has a significance in that it is the first report of the Public Accounts Committee on an efficiency audit. It treads new ground for the Committee and the Committee had devoted the final chapter of its report to the examination of some of the issues and problems raised by this form of auditing and suggestions as to how efficiency auditing could be made more effective and useful to administrators and the Parliament.

The Committee has divided its conclusions in respect of the bilateral aid program into four. After a brief summary of the Auditor-General's recommendations and the resources devoted to the overseas aid program and its administration, the Committee has focused on four areas where it believes changes to current administrative practices and arrangements will have the greatest beneficial impact on the aid program.

While the report's recommendations form an integrated package designed to improve Australian and overseas perceptions of the 'quality of Australian bilateral overseas aid', I would like to highlight a few of the most significant recommendations and conclusions.

Firstly, the Committee believes that, overall, the Australian aid program is adequately managed within the resources available to it; that it has a high reputation overseas and has provided an important input into development of Third World countries. The Committee believes that there is significant scope for improvement to the quality of the Australian aid in terms of the management of the bilateral aid program.

The Committee considers that the audit report provides a blueprint for efficient and effective aid program administration and that with only limited exceptions, the Auditor-General's recommendations should be pursued.

The Committee does, however, have reservations about the demands that the Auditor-General's suggestions will make on the staffing and physical resources of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau and that the Minister for Foreign Affairs will require special assistance at the parliamentary level to continue to fulfil his parliamentary and ministerial responsibilities. We have therefore recommended that the Department of Foreign Affairs urgently examine, in consultation with the Public Service Board, the staffing and physical resources available to ADAB.

We have also recommended that the Government consider the appointment of a Parliamentary Secretary for Overseas Aid to assist the Minister for Foreign Affairs on overseas aid matters. The Committee believes that this latter recommendation and the recommendation that the Minister for Foreign Affairs issue policy statements to the Parliament, his Department and the public periodically, are essential prerequisites to the development of parliamentary and community debate on the nature and direction of Australia's overseas aid.

Finally, in respect to efficiency audits generally, the Committee has recommended that the Auditor-General prepare guidelines specifying in broad terms the scope of efficiency audits to assist the proposed government review of efficiency auditing and that the report of the Government review be referred to a parliamentary committee for further examination when completed.

The Committee believes that overseas aid plays such a significant role in Australian relations with developing countries and is such a significant proportion of Commonwealth outlays that it is essential that development aid issues should be widely understood and debated in Australia. I commend the report to honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1982CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1982CUSTOMS TARIFF (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 21 October, on motion by Senator Messner:
That the Bills be now read a first time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1982

Mr President, the Customs Tariff Bill 1982 now before the Senate provides for a new Customs Tariff Act to replace the Customs Tariff Act 1966. The requirement for a new Act results from the Government's decision to introduce a simplified tariff based on recommendations made in the Industries Assistance Commission's Report of 30 November 1981 on customs tariff simplification. The recommendations do not substantially affect the assistance afforded to Australian industry. In general the changes in rates of duty do not exceed plus or minus five percentage points with equivalent changes for rates not expressed in ad valorem terms. The bill contains some changes to the IAC's recommendations to take account of Government decisions taken on particular industry reports after the IAC had submitted its simplification report. It was also necessary to make a number of other minor changes in line with the overall simplification objectives. Other variations have been made to take account of obligations under the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), and bilateral trade obligations such as those under the Papua New Guinea-Australia Trade and Commercial Relations Agreement (PATCRA) and the Canada-Australia Trade Agreement (CANATA).

On 13 April, the Government announced its decision to introduce a simplified tariff and indicated that the changes I have just outlined would be made to the IAC recommendations. In addition it was decided that the current tariff structures and rates of duty should continue for the time being. Where goods are covered by an IAC report not implemented at 2 July 1982 or due for report before 1 January 1983. It is intended that the new Act should come into operation on 1 January 1983. Amendments to take account of Government decisions made before then, together with amendments to provide for New Zealand rates and some developing country rates yet to be decided, will be made by gazette notice after proclamation of but before the date of operation. In its announcement earlier this year, the Government recognised that the Australian tariff had become, for the public and private sectors alike, an increasingly difficult document to work with.

This Bill includes a major revision of the sections of the current Act and a reduction in the number of Schedules of rates of duty. Provisions for parts directions and concentrates orders have been eliminated, together with all references to support duties and primage duties. Significant reductions have been made in the number of tariff classifications and the number of different rates of duty contained in the present tariff. As IAC reports not yet finalised or still under consideration are implemented, it can be anticipated there will be further reductions.

In summary, the simplified customs tariff is easier to read with less complex Schedules, and improved precision and clarity in description of goods and rates of duty. I am confident that users will find the new tariff better to work with than the present document. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1982

Mr President, this Bill amends the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975. It is complementary to the Customs Tariff Bill 1982 which I have just introduced. The Bill amends sections 8 and 10 of the principal Act where references are made to Schedules of the Customs Tariff Act which have been renumbered in the Customs Tariff Bill 1982. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
CUSTOMS TARIFF (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982

Mr President, this Bill amends the following Acts: Administrative Decisions ( Judicial Review) Act 1977; Consular Privileges and Immunities Act 1972; Customs Act 1901; Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1935. The Bill is complementary to the Customs Tariff Bill 1982 which I have just introduced. The amendments take account of the redrafting of the sections and renumbering of the Schedules to the Customs Tariff Act to which references are made in the various Acts.

The only change of substance is the redrafting of sections 151 and 151A of the Customs Act 1901. These new sections need to be read in conjunction with the new section 15 of the Customs Tariff Act 1982 when determining the conditions under which certain goods from specified countries are eligible for preferential tariff treatment. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The primary Bill in this package is the Customs Tariff Bill 1982-a very substantial Bill of some 310 pages which, despite its bulk and despite the promise held out by its title, does not really raise the kind of fundamental issues one might expect to be raised about the shape and direction of the Australian economy in the future of manufacturing industry. Far from being an exciting Bill about the future of the economy and manufacturing industry, really it is essentially just a piece of housekeeping legislation aimed at clearing a very significant path through the jungle of provisions and Schedules which have constituted our major tariff legislation. The last time we debated tariff legislation was, I think, on 28 April of this year when we debated the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill, which was particularly notorious for the increased tariff that the Bill imposed on wheelchairs in the face of very strong opposition from the Opposition side of Parliament and indeed from many people in the community as a whole. That Bill was the last, or perhaps the second last, in a long line of Bills which have been amending in one way or another the Customs Tariff Act 1966. The full list of those amending Bills-a very long list indeed-is set out in a Schedule to the Bill before the Senate at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill marks the beginning of a new era for customs tariff legislation insofar as it repeals and completely replaces the 1966 parent legislation and the welter of subsequent amendments to it. This Bill establishes a new and simplified tariff regime which is set out in the Third Schedule of the Bill. It is a rather lengthy Schedule, occupying 264 of the 310 pages in this document. In doing so, the Bill implements the recommendations of the Industries Assistance Commission which, in one of its less controversial documents, reported in November 1981 on the question of customs tariff simplification, a report which was tabled in the Parliament in April of this year.

When I spoke in the Senate in April of this year on the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill to which I earlier referred I made specific reference to the IAC report and, after incorporating in Hansard the summary of the Commission's recommendations, indicated that the Opposition looked forward very much to the advent of the legislative simplification there foreshadowed. In that spirit we now very much welcome the appearance of this Bill. In simplifying and streamlining the classification tables and the duty rates, involving as that streamlining does some marginal changes to the rates imposed in respect of particular goods but with no variation amounting to more than plus or minus 5 per cent and as such not attracting, I understand, much controversy, we see this legislation as going a long way towards eradicating the widespread and perfectly understandable lack of understanding of these matters-a situation which has led to a good deal of confusion and inefficiency and, in the words of the IAC and most importantly, 'a high level of misapplication of the tariff law'. Such administrative improvements, in addition to ensuring that Parliament's intention is in fact implemented, will lead we believe, as does the IAC, to cost benefits and greater productivity with consequent flow-on benefits to consumers and ultimately to the economy generally.

At the same time we make the point that the process of simplification is a continuing one and, now that there is in existence this Bill introducing a simplified tariff, that progress should not be allowed to slip away. We acknowledge the various factors which were well identified by the Opposition's spokesman, Mr Hurford, in speaking on this matter in the other place, and which promote complexity in this kind of legislation. We make the point again that there is a need for continuing vigilance. Specifically, following Mr Hurford's contribution in the other place on 9 September, I urge on behalf of the Opposition that a unit be created within the Bureau of Customs to ensure that in all negotiations of trade agreements due consideration will be given to the implications of this exercise in simplification. Similarly, this unit could ensure that any revisions of tariff would take into account the need to maintain simplicity. It is all too easy in this kind of exercise for the pressures of the moment to result in a wilderness of single instances rather than the kind of broadbanding that is involved in this kind of simplification exercise.

I also repeat the call made by Mr Hurford, the member for Adelaide, for the computerisation of tariff information so that the industry can have accurate and up-to-date information at all times. One would think that that is a simple enough request or demand in this technological era but it is one which so far seems to have been beyond the resources of the Customs authority.

The only other reference I would make specifically to the provisions of this Bill is a quick one to a couple of matters raised by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills when it looked at this legislation, as it does with all Bills, with a view to its civil liberty implications. Points were raised by the Committee in relation to the ministerial discretion conferred in clause 25 of this Bill and also, although less obviously, in clause 9, conferring a particular ministerial power to in fact exercise a delegated legislative authority in a fairly spectacular way. I do not think it is necessary to go into the detail of the matters raised in the fifteenth report of the Committee in relation to these matters except to say that the Committee, of which I am a member, has a continuing concern about ministerial power being exercised in the way that is here drawn attention to. Continuing discussions are going on between that Committee and the relevant Minister to see what can be done about making some changes to the legislation to ensure that that ministerial discretion is not exercised in such a way that it abdicates parliamentary authority in the future, or in such a way as to ensure that there is a lack of avenue for parliamentary scrutiny of the way in which that legislative authority is in fact exercised.

The only remaining matter to which I wish to advert is again the matter of wheelchairs which, as I said, I spoke about, as did many of my colleagues in the other place, when the April amending Bill was going through Parliament. The Opposition's view then was and now remains that it is quite unconscionable for the Government to impose, as it has done, a duty on wheelchairs which amounts, in terms of its dollar implications, to something like $300 per wheelchair and which can and has been having the effect of putting the purchase of wheelchairs beyond the reach of many who need them.

We have taken the view that it is not appropriate for a tariff to apply. As with so many other goods, the better way of doing it would have been to have a bounty or subsidy for local production instead of placing a tax on imports which is the way this operates. The matter was raised by Joan Child in the House of Representatives when speaking to this Bill a few weeks ago. The response of the Minister for the Capital Territory, Mr Hodgman, was that the Government would have a further look at this matter. That was seven weeks ago-in September. We simply ask: What is the answer? We hope that in the ministerial reply on this occasion the wheelchair occupants of the nation will get a slightly better deal and a more sensitive response from the Government than they have had so far.
Debate interrupted.

DEBATE.TITLE: SELECT COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 October, on motion by Senator Harradine:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation was presented to the Senate on Tuesday of this week. For one reason or another a tabling speech was not made then. I now make that tabling speech. The Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 and the Commonwealth Employees (Voluntary Membership of Unions) Bill 1982 were referred to the Select Committee in May of this year. The Committee received 71 submissions and heard 42 witnesses, including the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. Those submissions raised questions about the Bills going to the very heart of the Australian system of conciliation and arbitration. The Senate particularly asked the Committee to report on: Firstly, the desirability or otherwise of encouraging the development of industry-based unions in Australia, and the best methods of providing changes in the structure of the Australian trade union organisation; secondly, whether the provision of voluntary unionism and the removal of power to award preference to unionists will contribute to industrial peace and an improvement of the industrial relations climate and, thirdly, whether the right of employers to stand down employees as a result of industrial action without reference to the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is consistent with modern industrial practices and will contribute to industrial peace.

SPEECH.PARA: The report goes into 119 pages or thereabouts. It is not my intention to dwell at length with the evidence which was presented to us. That evidence forms a body of information and opinion which merits considerable discussion among the industrial relations community and will provide a valuable base for further considerations by the Government. I go directly to the matters to which the Committee was specifically asked to direct its attention. First of all, I deal with industry unions. On this subject conflicting concepts were aired and the desirability of encouraging by legislation the development of industry-based unions was seriously questioned. It was the view of the Committee that union structures do not predominantly determine industrial relations outcomes.

Furthermore, the Committee considered the operation of section 142 of the existing Act, which has served to limit the number of competing unions thus reducing the incidence of demarcation disputes. The Government's proposed legislation provides that this section will have no effect where it might prevent the registration of individual organisations. This section, which is known as the conveniently belong section, has been in the principal Act for a number of years. Evidence indicates that the result of the Government's proposed legislation would be overlapping coverage between new industry unions and existing unions which would lead to further inter-union disputation and the possibility of further proliferation of unions. Evidence taken by the Committee supported the Committee's view that the proposed legislation would increase industrial disputation.

Evidence was also given to the Committee which persuaded it to acknowledge existing difficulties of amalgamation, particularly evidence that was provided to us by the Australian Boot Trades Employees Federation and the Australian Textiles Workers Union. The Committee does not favour uninhibited amalgamations, but considers that these should take place only after a community of interest test has been satisfied. The Committee suggests that in amalgamation ballots 25 per cent of the membership should be required to record a vote and of those voting at least two-thirds should be required to vote in favour. Alternatively, at least 25 per cent of the total membership should vote in favour. For the reasons outlined in the report the Committee recommends that the Senate not pass the provisions of the Conciliation and Arbritration Amendment Bill relating to the encouragement of industry-based unions. The Committee suggests that, in the interests of smooth industrial relations, before any further legislative action is contemplated in this area the Government consult with the National Labour Consultative Council and registered organisations which are likely to be affected.

So far as the second specific matter to which the Senate Select Committee was asked to direct its attention is concerned-that is to say, the abolition of preference-that is dealt with in chapter 4 of the report. Firstly, let me say that although issues of preference and voluntary unionism enjoy a high political profile, the Committee received no substantive evidence from any employee claiming to have been directly aggrieved by the operation of preference clauses despite the widespread public invitations issued for persons to make submissions to the Committee. At least one general submission was received relating to conscientious objection rights of sub-contractors. This was taken up with the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. Honourable senators will recall that the interim report of the Committee was brought into the Senate last month. Since the tabling of that report, which raised serious doubts about proposed section 4B, the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee) has written to the Committee, but the doubts of the Committee have not been resolved.

The Committee noted that the Government intends that its proposed legislation will weaken the power of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to deal with union membership disputes. The Committee shares the view generally expressed by witnesses that the proposed legislation would not be conducive to industrial peace and would further unsettle the industrial relations climate. The Committee again noted that the Government's intention for its legislation was-to use the Government's own words as appeared in the Minister's second reading speech-to provide a better balance in the powers, rights and duties of employers and employees. Clearly, this legislation would fundamentally disturb this balance in favour of employers. The Committee considers that the proposed legislation is an undesirable and unwarranted intervention into the field of industrial relations, particularly at a time when high levels of unemployment have already disturbed this balance. The Committee believes quite firmly that viable unions are essential for the operation of Australia's system of conciliation and arbitration.

The Committee considers that the proposed new section 144A would undermine this viability to an unacceptable extent and it recommends that it not be incorporated in the Act. I emphasise that the Committee considers that the proposed new section 144A would undermine this viability-that is, the viability upon which the system of conciliation and arbitration depends-to an unacceptable extent. I recommend that proposed new section 144A be not included in the Act. For similar reasons the Committee recommends that the existing section 47-that is, the power to award preference-should be retained in the Act. Accordingly, the Committee has recommended that the amendments proposed by clauses 3, 4 (2), 5, 7, 9 and 20 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill 1982 should not be incorporated in the Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment briefly on the report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation. I want to do so in the context of apprising the Senate of the environment in which this legislation was considered. I think the Senate will recall that the legislation was introduced some time ago. I cannot recall the exact date; it is recorded in the report. The legislation was referred to a select committee of the Senate. In a sense the legislation which was referred to the Committee came out of the ministry of Mr Ian Viner as Minister for Industrial Relations. Mr Viner developed a number of views about the Australian industrial relations system upon which he implanted what seemed at the time to be an indelible mark, but it now appears to be washing away. In a sense it was in that context that the Committee had to look at the proposals in the Bill before the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to remind the Senate of the somewhat changed environment in relation to industrial relations considerations which is revealed in a speech of the current Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, Mr Ian Macphee, in a speech he gave to the American Chamber of Commerce in Australia on 24 September this year. On page 4 of that speech Mr Macphee made the point that the industrial relations challenge facing Australia was a major issue for the Australian community in the 1980s. That is something with which I agree. He said:

To come to grips with the issues raised we need to be willing to look at the options available with open minds. We need to be clear-headed about the nature of the industrial relations scene in Australia. We need to recognise that while some objectives might be achievable in the short term others will take some time .
He went on to state:

Consequently, it is essential for employers and governments to have a close working relationship with the union movement, and thereby seek through this process to have the union movement accept the responsibilities that go with its position in society.
He referred to the practical limitations of the industrial relations legislation . At page 7 he went on to state:
On the question of improving the framework--
That is, the framework of industrial relations legislation-

I have asked my Department to undertake a wide ranging review of our existing industrial relations system. I have had discussions with the NLCC on the way this study will be carried out. It will be an internal review, although of course we will be consulting closely with the industry parties because of the comprehensive nature of the exercise. I expect that it will take some time to complete.

The Minister went on to make some fairly favourable comments-I suppose I can describe them as that-about the desirability of having centralised wage fixation in Australia, a view which was quite contrary to the view expressed by Mr Viner last year. I want to make the intial point that the legislation which the Senate Select Committee considered was, in a sense, a brainchild of Minister Viner, a brainchild which was sort of 'euthenased' by the arrival of a new Minister with a somewhat different point of view. There is nothing new about that with respect to this Government and the sort of ad hockery that goes on in this area. It is in that context that this Select Committee report has to be considered. Senator Harradine has dealt-as much as he had time to do-with some of the major issues the report raises. Let me make one or two comment on one or two of these issues.

I believe very strongly that it is desirable that existing institutions in Australia be adapted as much as possible to changing circumstance. I do not believe in their destruction. I believe in continuity of institutions, particularly at the present time because of the very difficult circumstances with which this country is faced. One can look at some of the issues which arose in the context of this report and take what is perhaps the minor issue of the three major issues-the matter of the automatic right of stand down of employees. The suspicions the majority of members of the committee had about this matter are more and more relevant every day as the employment context in Australia becomes more and more difficult. In every day's newspaper one reads about employees in various places being asked to work a four-day week or a three-day week on four days pay or three days pay respectively and so on.

In that sort of economic context the automatic right of stand down by an employer I believe is much more susceptible to abuse than it has been in better economic times. I am not in any sense condemning the approach Senator Hamer and some of his colleagues on the Committee took on this issue. I understand it, but I am saying that I think it is very important that that issue be seen in the context of contemporary times and what are likely to be the times of the immediate future. If one goes back over the history of industrial arbitration in Australia and reads the cases on stand down of employees one sees the reason the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has intervened is that the right of employers to stand down without pay has been abused.

TALK.START.PARA: —So has the right to strike.

—So has the right to strike. I do not disagree with that for a moment. But we did not have referred to us the matter of the right to strike. As I recall, in the time since I came into this Parliament seven pieces of legislation have been introduced by the Fraser Government which have been going to fix up the right to strike and none of them has made any change at all to the problem.
—There were many fewer strikes this year.

—There were fewer strikes this year because Senator Chaney's government has achieved a record level of unemployment in Australia. As long as the Government continues to run unemployment at the level at which it now is, and when it gets worse, there will probably be fewer strikes. The Government will be able to say: 'We have achieved a great thing. We have less strikes because we have half a million people unemployed'. I would not have thought that that is an advance in Government policy. The issue to be grappled is, of course, the strike and stand-down matter. I just make that comment about the stand-down provision because industrial relations is a dynamic thing and is very dependent upon employment in the country generally.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine said something about the matter of preference. I congratulate Senator Harradine on his chairmanship of the Committee because I think he has done a very fine job. I did not agree with all his views and he did not agree with all of mine-none of us agreed on everything. It was a very good working Committee in the sense that I believe all of us learnt something from the experience of being on it, with the possible exception of Senator Walters. We were able to exchange views in a spirit of give and take. Many of the points which were raised by Senator Hamer and Senator Withers, although they have not ultimately agreed with my view in the final report, made an impression on me.

I want to turn finally to the question of industry unionism. So far as I am concerned the report is a little soft on that issue. I am a little keener about the encouragement of the notion of industry unionism than the majority of Committee members. What I would like to have seen happen is for something to have been written into the report-this is a matter for later debate-which would provide that community of interest be a criterion in amalgamations of unions and that unions should not be allowed to amalgamate unless it is a step towards industry unionism.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is in the report, Senator.

—It is not in those terms, Senator Siddons. It is a little softer than that. The other important thing the Committee did was to agree that the present amalgamation provisions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act are too restrictive. I remind honourable senators that that was the subject of a Bill which I introduced into the Senate as a private member's Bill last year and everybody voted against it. I am glad to see that progress is now being made on the Committee on a unanimous basis. Agreement was reached that those provisions should be changed. I commend the other members of the Committee for their work in preparing this report. I hope we will have a further occasion to talk about it. It is a very important document in the context of the remarks of the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations (Mr Macphee).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ten minutes is a very brief time in which to discuss the complex issues which are raised in this report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation.
—It will seem longer.

—Senator Chaney said that it will seem longer. Perhaps it will. Will it be longer for me or for him? I am not quite clear. I would like to make one point at the outset. In my view the Senate refers far too little legislation to our committees for public review. I think the whole system would be greatly improved if more legislation were referred to the Senate committees. I think some honourable senators would be aware that I think all legislation should be referred to such committees although that would require major changes to the structure and procedures of the Senate. What is peculiar about this situation is that on one of the rare occasions when we sent legislation to a committee we referred it to a select committee instead of one of the legislative and standing purpose committees. That is a most peculiar procedure. We have a network of eight legislative committees which are supposed to cover the full range of Government activities. Surely when a piece of legislation needs consideration by a Senate committee it should be referred to one of those committees. I think it was very regrettable-
—Industrial relations is a very important subject, of course.

—Industrial relations is very important. I want to spend some time on another point. In my view, the present structure of those committees does not cover some areas very well. Industrial relations is one such matter. I would be very sorry, for instance, to see it fall into the hands of lawyers and be an extension of the activities of the Senate Standing Committee on Constitutional and Legal Affairs. We would never solve anything. That is a different matter and a matter about which I feel quite strongly. As a member of this Committee I have to go to great pains to show why in one area I agreed with the conclusions of the Committee but why I disagreed with it in two other areas. The fact that I disagreed might be less surprising than the fact that I reached agreement with the Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: I was not happy with the proposals in the Bill regarding industry unions. In particular, I was not happy at the fact that at no stage had an industry union been defined. There was no clear thought by which the Committee could determine exactly what people were talking about when they referred to industry unions. I will give one extreme view. The Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union appeared to have the view that any job that involved metal should be part of an industry union controlled by them. At the other extreme, another group of people in the dry cleaning business thought that there should be a dry cleaning union. If we broke the unions down to that extent we would have thousands of them.

What is needed before we take this matter any further is some discussion, thought and consideration about what we mean by industry unions. Once we define what we mean by industry unions we can start to analyse the advantages, disadvantages and problems. I think that the advantages would be very great. We cannot conceal the fact that there would be problems. I should like to give two or three examples. It would change our present notions of comparative wage justice if we had industry unions. That in many ways would be difficult to apply . There would be problems about how staff and professional people would fit into an industry union. I think there would be problems about the transferability of trade qualifications from one industry to another. People could be doing the same sort of job in different industries. These are some of the problems but I do not think they are insuperable. All these problems have to be thought through . I do not think that we can look at models such as the West German and Swedish ones which are often spoken about. They have very large and complex unions but only a small number. They have less than 20 unions in each case. I cannot see that being a practical solution for Australia. I do not think that the Australian Council of Trade Unions industry groups are genuine industry groups. I understand that they were put together, not from the view of community of interest but in order-

TALK.START.PARA: —Oh yes, community of interest all right.

—It was not for the community of interest of the employer but of the trade union leaders in the particular union concerned. It was done to give some people a good power base. It is not the basis on which I think we should define our own industry unions. I think that if we looked at the structure of industry unions we would probably decide that it was desirable to have something like 60 or 70 unions. That has to be looked at. I have advanced some of the problems but others also have to be looked at. Let me make this point quite clear. This will not be achieved only by amalgamation. If we are to have, say, 60 or 70 unions, there would have to be amalgamations and breakups of unions because many unions now straddle several industries by any possible definition of an industry for union purposes. Therefore, we would have to look at how that would be achieved. In the short term I think that amalgamations, when the community of interest test which Senator Button mentions applies, would be desirable. I think that if we can we should discourage amalgamations which would not help the establishment of future industry unions. The urgent task in my view is for the Government to set in process discussions about what industry unions are, how they would operate, what their problems would be and what their advantages and disadvantages would be. Although the Government, in my view, should not impose industry unions it should give a very strong lead in bringing them about.
—Shouldn't it be involved in consultation with the trade union movement?
—Of course. It should be done through the National Labour Consultative Council. I am talking about consultation.
—Not by imposition or legislation.

—I am sorry. I said just that. I think the Government should lead in this matter. We should not be passive and wait for a miracle to happen in the trade union movement. That is not the way it is going to happen. The Government has to give a very strong lead. I do not think it would be an effective move for the Government to try to impose industry unions against the dominant opposition of the trade union movement.
—It has never been suggested.

—No. Senator Walters says that it has never been suggested. I do not think that is a practical approach. That is not to say that the Government should not and must not give a lead in these very important matters.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to turn briefly to the recommendation of the Committee with which we disagree. I think it is common knowledge that the Committee was divided on a number of matters. The first thing I would like to make clear is that we accept that the whole system of conciliation and arbitration is based on the understanding that unions must adequately represent all employees. Anything that would destroy the ability of unions effectively to represent all employees would be very damaging to our system. I do not believe that that would be done by what the Government proposes. We also have to consider the rights of individuals not to join unions. We have to consider how those rights can be made effective in the current industrial climate. If one could confine union activities to work place matters one could make out a very good case for unionism to be compulsory. I would not find that objectionable, but that is not a practical proposition. There is no reasonable way we would be able to confine union activities to the work place. Therefore, I do not think that is a worthwhile approach. Therefore, as we cannot confine union activities to the work place, we believe that the Government must do all that it can to ensure an individual the right to elect whether to join a union and to ensure that such a decision would have no effect on his ability to work in that particular job. If unions want to have members, what they should do is attract them by the services that they offer to their members.

The second matter on which I dissented, together with other members of the Committee, was the question of automatic stand downs. When the original Conciliation and Arbitration Act was passed in 1904, it was widely believed that there would be an end to strikes. There would be conciliation and, if that failed, there would be arbitration which would be binding on all parties concerned. We all know that that system has not worked. But what the unions appear to be asking for, although they are not prepared to accept it is binding arbitration when they wish to go on strike. They wish to see binding arbitration decisions before employers can stand down employees who cannot usefully be employed. I do not think that is a reasonable distinction. I believe that employers should have equivalent rights to stand down workmen who cannot usefully be employed because of strike action as those same unionists have to go on strike.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate will recall that, when we first debated the Conciliation and Arbitration Amendment Bill, I described it in these terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Potentially the most dangerous, inflamatory and repressive piece of legislation introduced into this place in my term.

Despite the passage of five more very interesting months, during which time many pieces of legislation have been passed through the Senate, some of them with quite odious aspects, I believe that the original statement that I made about the industrial relations Bills is still broadly true.

Since we have very little time to debate this matter, I will be brief. Honourable senators will recall that, when the industrial relations Bills were originally debated, the Australian Democrats introduced a package of amendments which were designed to make the legislation more creative and more acceptable. We also supported the reference of this legislation to a committee, if that reference could be treated as a matter of urgency. I am pleased to say that many of the principles that we put forward at that time and a great deal of the detail set out in those amendments has been agreed to and incorporated in the report of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation.

Let me go briefly through three contentious areas of the report. One of the major purposes of the Bill was, so it was said, to encourage industry unions. Honourable senators will recall that the Government wanted originally to create a legislative environment in which it was possible for enterprise unions also to be registered. But, after a great deal of debate and criticism, the proposal in relation to enterprise unions was withdrawn by the Government. I have on many occasions advocated the importance of industry unions, if for no other reason than that I believe that to have fewer unions in this country was a very important step in the right direction. The Committee decided that the legislation in connection with industry unions, as now drafted, should not pass the Senate for the simple reason that it was not clear what was meant by the term 'industry union'. It was felt also that the net effect of the legislation could be to encourage more unions rather than fewer unions. That does not mean, nevertheless, that there is nothing we can do about encouraging fewer unions.

Much of the evidence that the Committee heard made it very clear what difficulties existed in attempting union amalgamation. I think every member of the Committee learnt a great deal in this respect. It was of great benefit generally, and I hope to the Parliament, that the Committee was able to agree to the original recommendation of the National Labour Consultative Council that in the first instance the unions should be allowed to amalgamate on a community of interests basis and that the barriers to amalgamation should be lowered so that only a ballot consisting of 25 per cent of the membership was necessary and that , providing that two-thirds of those voting agreed, an amalgamation should take place. That recommendation of the Committee is, I believe, a very important one and a step forward.

The second major aspect of the legislation was the protection of the rights of the individual to join or not to join a union. The legislation attempted to achieve this by the introduction of a draconian proposed new section 144A. That was considered and commented on at length by most of the organisations giving evidence before the Committee. It was generally condemned as a section that would cause additional industrial disputation. The Committee has been quite unequivocal in recommending that that draconian proposed new section 144A be objected to.

The question raised as to whether people should be encouraged to join a union or whether there should be a free choice is very delicate. It was one that the Australian Democrats addressed at its formation. We set out a detailed policy on this matter. Our policy paper states:

We are aware of the union principle from the past that 100 per cent membership was essential for effectiveness. We are also aware of Item 20 (2) in the United Nations Declaration of Human Rights which states 'No one may be compelled to belong to an association'. We know too that many workers have accepted the benefits of unionism without paying dues. We will therefore legislate go give every union the right to impose a 'fee for service' on those workers who do not choose to join it but are working under wages and conditions which the union has achieved.

The Committee recommended that the original clause relating to conscientious objection should be retained in the Conciliation and Arbitration Act. But it recommended also that an additional clause, based on the conscientious objection clause, should be included to allow people to object to joining a union if they had an objection in principle or a belief. The Committee recommended that in this case such people would be allowed to apply to the industrial registrar for a certificate exempting them from joining the union. Such a certificate should be forthcoming on the payment to the appropriate union of a fee not less than 10 per cent of the total union membership fee. That fee should be directed by the unions towards industrial matters only and not towards things such as donations to political parties. So, the fee for service in effect has now been recommended by the Committee for the attention of the Government.

The final point related to the right to stand down employees. This is a very major matter. The Committee recommended that the right to stand down should remain as a matter that has to be referred to the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It has been a major tenet of Australian industrial practice for over a century that people have the right to work on a weekly basis. That was very largely what the major fight about industrial relations was in the 19th century and even later. It is simply unacceptable that in the 20th century people can be put in a position where they can be hired and stood down on an hourly basis. Nevertheless, we took on board the objection to delays in granting stand down clauses to employers where they were requested. The Committee has recommended that stand-down applications should be heard within a two-day peiod. The Committee suggested that many of its recommendations should be referred to the National Labour Consultative Council. The Committee felt that there was an urgent need for consensus in this area. That is important.

Finally, as time presses, let me say that I believe that the work of the Committee was constructive. It was a pleasure to work on the Committee. I commend the report as one that has many interesting comments to make on the Australian industrial relations scene. It outlines the basis of our system of conciliation and arbitration. Our 80-year-old piece of legislation has withstood yet another test of its continuation as one of the basic ways in which we fix wages.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I start by saying that Senator Harradine misunderstood the amount of time that had been allocated to him and asked me, as a member of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation, to thank, on his behalf, Richard Tracey, the adviser to the Committee, Ron Wiber and Elton Humphrey. Richard Tracey came to the Committee at its beginning and did a tremendous amount of work for it. The Committee is very indebted to him for all the work that he undertook for it and for his professional advice. As has already been indicated, three main areas were looked at-industry-based unions, automatic stand-downs and voluntary unionism. The area of industry-based unions was the area in which the Committee agreed unanimously. I congratulate Senator Harradine for his chairing of the Committee and for being able to juggle us all around, as he did so well, and come up with one area--
—I did not notice that, Senator.
—I noticed that considerably. Senator Harradine juggled us around remarkably to come up with one area of unanimity. I congratulate him for that.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to concentrate on the minority report. In the media coverage that we got, we did not get any coverage of the minority report. It is important for the population to understand that this report was not unanimous. First, I deal with automatic stand-downs. As has been indicated by Senator Hamer, if the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission worked as it was intended to work, we would have no problems of the sort that we have today. Indeed, the Committee would not have had to sit. The point is that it was intended originally that the decisions of that Commission should be binding on both parties. That is not as it works. The unions have a right to strike as they see fit. I would not take that from them. But if they do not like the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decision, they still say that their right to strike against that decision and not abide by it is very justified. But the employers, once the awards are made, must abide by them. Indeed, action is taken if they do not do so.

Bearing in mind that there is this undisputed one-sidedness on the part of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission's decisions, we must even that up somewhat in the legislation and allow employers who, part of their work force being on strike, are unable to employ the rest of the work force, to stand-down immediately those people whom they are unable to employ. Senator Button said that in the present difficult climate that would not be possible. In this difficult climate, it should be all the more necessary, because if a small business is unable to stand-down people immediately but must employ them for several days-we found on our Committee that the average was 48 hours or it will be at a great disadvantage financially. If an employer is employing a large number of people in his work force and if only a few of them are on strike and those few on strike render the majority unable to perform their tasks, he will be at great disadvantage financially. We must recognise that profit is not a dirty word and that, unless the employer is making a profit, more people will be stood down. The employer must be protected against wilful strike action by a minority, a very small group, who know only too well that they can create a situation in which no work is available for the rest of the business. Senator Button said that he did not think that I had learned anything on the Committee. I certainly learned to live with Senator Button on a committee. Indeed, he even agreed with me, as he said-for which I give due credit to Senator Harradine- about industry-based unions.

I turn now to voluntary unionism. I mentioned this several times, and I nearly drove Senator Harradine to distraction every time I did so. I mentioned the report on 3 July this year, and again in August this year, of an opinion poll which indicated that 73 per cent of Australians believed that there should not be compulsory unionism. The question asked was: Should it be compulsory or not compulsory for workers to join a trade union? Of the replies, 73 per cent said that it should not be compulsory. It was argued before the Committee that we did not have compulsory unionism in this country, that really it was voluntary and that because it was voluntary there was no need for the Government to introduce the legislation. We also heard in evidence from the trade union movement that the employers made an agreement with their particular union and the result of that agreement was that if one did not join the trade union one did not work.

For some reason, members of the Committee still seemed to call that voluntary unionism. To me that is compulsory unionism-no membership, no work. Indeed, I pointed out that in the State of Tasmania, even though it is against the rules and against the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, the Transport Workers Union of Australia signs up the owner-drivers. I assure the Senate that it is compulsory. Everyone in this place will know that that is against the decision of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It is against the union rules. It has been written out of the award. There is no way that it should be signing up the owner-drivers. But it is compulsory, because an owner-driver will not get his truck unloaded if he has not joined the Transport Workers Union.

Let us not forget that 73 per cent of Australians want voluntary unionism, not compulsory unionism, and that 77 per cent of Australian Democrat voters, 86 per cent of Liberal voters and 58 per cent of Labor voters want that. Once this country accepts that there should be voluntary unionism, we shall not have these minority unions, such as the transport union in my State, being able to get away with forcing owner-drivers to become members of their union. Senator Siddons said-he will correct me if I am wrong-that we needed viable unions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I said that.

—He said he believed that voluntary unionism would undermine the viable unions in the country. I do not believe it would undermine them at all. But if he does believe that, he can only believe the majority of unionists do not want to join unions. If he believes that giving them a chance not to join their union means that they would take that chance, then they would get away from the union and no longer be members. We can only presume that the majority of unionists in this country, in Senator Siddons's opinion anyway, would not be members of that union. I believe unions should make themselves attractive to their members and encourage people to join.
—Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

TALK.START.PARA: — I wish to speak to this report having been a member of the Senate Select Committee on Industrial Relations Legislation from 22 September 1982, at which time Senator Mulvihill had to resign because of other parliamentary duties. As Senator Button mentioned earlier, this legislation came before the Senate on an earlier date when it was introduced by a previous Minister for Industrial Relations, Mr Viner. It now seems as though the Government is having a rethink in the whole of the industrial relations area . The main lesson to be learnt from the operation of this Committee in considering this legislation is that the legislation should have been reviewed and the review process should continue. The legislation is effectively a monument to the incompetence of the previous Minister, Mr Viner, and to his lack of understanding of the field of industrial relations. It was a rejection and an abuse of the consultative process that had been continuing at the level of the National Labour Consultative Council. In fact recommendations of that Council between 1978 and 1980 were disregarded by the Government in its formulation of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset I wish to acknowledge the work done on the Committee by the secretariat, together with the Chairman. As Senator Walters said, he did juggle the Committee, and did so quite effectively. Having said that I wish to turn to the three major areas in the short time I have available. The area of stand downs was one that was discussed quite deeply in evidence before the Committee. There were a number of problems with the legislation as it was put to the Senate in initial form. The first one was, of course, whether there was a need for this . In this respect I turn to no other authority than the Confederation of Australian Industry. Its representative before the Committee, Mr Polites, expressed the attitude of the CAI and said:

It is almost unique. We have 37 per cent of awards with stand-down clauses in them now and 67 per cent of them are in terms of the metal trades provisions, which say that you are entitled to stand-down anybody who cannot be usefully employed on any day because of an industrial dispute. Our experience is that in those awards those clauses are operative and effective.

So there is an acceptance to a certain extent by the CAI. There is also the problem under this legislation, which was recognised even by honourable senators on the Government side. One particular person who recognised that was Senator Hamer. In questioning Mr Polites on 28 July 1982-this is found at page 1119 of the transcript-he said:
On the other hand, there are certain safeguards against unfair use. As this Bill stands, it gives the power without the safeguards. I am asking you: Do you think there should be safeguards?

Senator Hamer acknowledged that the Bill, as it was presented, did not have adequate safeguards. What are the safeguards that we, as the Opposition, raised for consideration and which were accepted by the majority of the Committee? As it now stands the legislation would not acknowledge the fault of an employer in the process before stand downs. It is quite opportune that in the Senate yesterday the Government produced to me details of industrial disputes caused by managerial policy. Last year over one thousand disputes were caused by managerial policy, as assessed by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. In all those disputes under the Government's provisions the employees would have not right of recourse. That is a particular problem that we, as a Committee, found should not be allowed to continue. We should not have such a situation without a fair trial of the parties involved in terms of the desirability of a particular stand down. We also have to take note of the dishonesty of the Government in preparing the legislation. Let us look at the catch-22 situation in which the Government put the industrial relations community. In introducing the Commonwealth Employees (Employment Provisions) Act Mr Sinclair said:
Every private employer in this country has an ability to stand down his employees.

That statement is totally inconsistent with what Mr Viner said in introducing this legislation, which he justified as giving private employers the same basic right as the Government had given itself. Mr Sinclair said that that right already existed. Mr Viner said that because of the legislation Mr Sinclair had introduced there was a need to make the provisions uniform. It is a dishonest portrayal of the provisions. I turn very briefly to the situation of industry unions, where the Committee found unanimity of thought. There seems to be some strange inconsistency between the Government's stated intention, as presented in this legislation, and the utterances of the Government and the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Street) in respect of the dissolution of Solidarity. In Poland Solidarity is being reorganised and restructured by government authority. We have a situation under this piece of legislation where the direct effect and result of pursuing the legislation would be to restructure and undermine the trade union movement as it exists in Australia. The Government has shown no inconsistency at all. In introducing the legislation Mr Viner said:
The Bill will provide a better balance in the powers, rights and duties of employers and employees.

That means that the Bill will deprive the union movement of some of its long held and existing powers. The direct effect will be to set up industry unions that are in many instances company based and in fact could very well lead to the preponderance of scab unions. The other problem with this legislation is that not only would it increase the number of unions but also, in conjunction with the Government's provisions in respect of preference-which I will come to next- there will be an increase in the number of unions and an arbitration machinery which is not geared and not allowed by government decision to handle the problems that will arise. Once again let us look at this aspect. Senator Hamer as recorded on page 1148 of the transcript of 28 July said:

It was troubling me that the Confederation of Australian Industry had come out in favour of industry unions but you were not prepared at all to say what you meant by an industry or how many you thought there might be. Is it correct to say that what you seek is employers to deal with as few unions as possible, preferably one, and that your only other requirement is that the union they deal with should be competently managed and of sufficient size to be efficient . . .
Mr Polites replied:
That is right. That is essentially the position.

When one looks at the expression of opinion of the CAI together with the expression of opinion by the National Labour Consultative Council and the proposals put forward by that Council at an earlier date, one finds that the Government has disregarded those stated intentions.

I will turn briefly to the position of preference. By this legislation and by both the intended and unintended consequences of it the Government is essentially striking at the system of conciliation and arbitration as it now exists. Section 2(e) of the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provides:
That the policy of the Act will be to encourage the organisation of representative bodies and employers and employees and their registration under this Act.

This piece of legislation would strike very much at the core of that. I refer to the opinion of Mr Frank Cawthorne, a commissioner in South Australia, the ex- advocate of the South Australian Chamber of Manufactures, of the Metal Industries Association of South Australia and so on. In a review of the South Australian provisions which the State Minister in South Australia, Dean Brown, was pushing through Parliament, he said:

However, all things considered, it is suggested that unless one views unions and unionism in an entirely negative way-which is totally inappropriate-it can be fairly argued that industrial commissions should have within the discretionary armoury the power to award preference.

I have only seconds left in which to speak. I return to my initial point. This legislation was ill-conceived. It was presented to this Parliament by a Minister in an attempt to destroy the trade union movement and the rights of the workers in this country. The review of the Senate Committee shows both the intended and the unintended shortfalls and dangers of the legislation.
Debate interrupted.
