DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE FOR THE SCRUTINY OF BILLS

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 19 August, or motion by Senator Missen:
That the report be adopted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter because I voted in favour of the amendment and motion moved by my colleagues Senators Hamer and Missen respectively last November to set up the Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on a trial basis. Secondly, I wish to speak because, as a member of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee, I have been able to make a contribution to the workings of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. Members of the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Committee have, of course, carried out their role as members of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee for a 6 months period.

SPEECH.PARA: It appeared to me back in November that the experiment of having a bipartisan Senate committee to look at Bills for provisions that would trespass unduly on personal rights and liberties, make rights, liberties and obligations unduly dependent upon insufficiently defined administrative powers or non-reviewable administrative decisions or inappropriately delegate legislative power or insufficiently subject its exercise to parliamentary scrutiny would be a worthwhile experiment in extending the review role of the Senate. I was comforted by the fact that the Committee was not to have the power to impede or disallow but only to scrutinise and publicise. Thus, it was simply to be a watchdog to draw to the attention of honourable senators provisions of Bills that might be potentially undesirable from an interference with civil liberties angle. It appeared to me that it would give the Senate the opportunity to act more effectively.

I was surprised at that time that the Government chose to oppose the motion, particularly in view of the amendment providing that it be simply set up for a trial period. The arguments put by the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) on behalf of the Government appeared to me to be extremely vulnerable. In particular, his argument that the Committee might hinder the progress of legislation was vulnerable in that, as the Committee was simply to be set up for a trial period, that would in fact be put to the test. Similarly, the argument that the Committee would have difficulty in distinguishing invasion of personal rights and civil liberties that are justified by the policy and social purpose of the Bill appeared to fail to appreciate that the responsibility of the Committee was simply to bring these matters to the attention of the Senate which would, of course, remain the only determining body.

Other arguments, such as the assertion that the existing committees of the Parliament were adequately fulfilling the role, appeared to me, even after my short time in this place, to be not well founded. The schedule of Acts with questionable provisions tabled by Senator Missen on 17 November confirmed in my mind the impression that I was rapidly forming. The argument that the motion to set up the Committee would mean that questions of human rights and civil liberties would become the concern of only one small group of the Senate similarly appeared to indicate a failure by the Government to appreciate what was proposed. That failure appeared to me to be even more surprising in that the credit for the concept has been given to the now Minister for Social Security, Senator Chaney. Thus, I was quite satisfied at the time in my own mind that I was making the right decision to support the trial of this reform.

I feel I have now had enough opportunity from the inside to assess the worth of the Committee in the total parliamentary process. It is an additional committee in a Senate which appears to be overburdened with committees. At the time of the debate the number was 37. It thus imposes a further burden on the staff of the Senate and on the time of senators who constitute the Committee. Additionally, it imposes a further cost burden in relation to professional and secretarial assistance. In such circumstances, it appears to me that the worth of the Committee and the justification for extra expense and effort require particular consideration.

Before attempting to evaluate the Committee's contribution, I wish briefly to reflect upon how the Government's arguments have stood the test of practical application. I know of no case in which the Committee hindered or delayed passage of legislation. This point has now been conceded by the Government. Secondly, the Committee has been at pains to point out that a particular invasion of rights or liberties may well be consistent with policy objective whenever that has been apparent from a Minister's second reading speech or from a Bill. Not having to make the final value judgment has meant that the Committe has had little difficulty in this regard. Thirdly, the practice of the Committee to report to the Senate whenever possible before a second reading debate has meant that the province for consideration of human rights and civil liberties has become a subject of wider consideration in the Senate rather than the preserve of a few members of the Committee. It appears, therefore, that the concerns of the Government were not well founded. I am pleased that that has now been conceded by the Government's report. This, therefore, allows an unemotional bipartisan consideration of the value of the Committee as a tool of the Senate and the Parliament against the cost, financial and in time, of its maintenance.

As set out in the report, in the first six months the Committee reported to the Senate under its terms of reference on clauses of 27 Bills. Of those, nine were subsequently amended. In the case of another, a further Bill was introduced to overcome a difficulty perceived by the Committee. Amendments were foreshadowed by the Government in a number of other cases. Those figures appear at face value to be quite dramatic. It may be argued that the amendments would in any event have come about through the parliamentary process, but there must be considerable doubt in that regard. The Committee appears to be building up a good working relationship with Ministers, who are now comprehensively answering matters raised by the Committee in its Bills Digest and on some occasions even thanking the Committee for bringing such matters to their attention. In turn, this has enabled the Committee in its report to indicate justification that may be advanced by Ministers for particular provisions that might otherwise violate the Committee's terms of reference.

The Committee has noted acceptance of its work by private organisations. This appears to be indicated by a slowly increasing number of submissions as the existence of the Committee becomes better known. One such submission, as mentioned in the report, resulted in an amendment to a specific Bill to overcome a difficulty publicly identified by the Committee as a result of the submission. The Committee has also noted favourable comment in debate by Ministers and senators. Additionally, there is evidence that draftsmen and departments are now giving closer attention to the provisions of their work which may fall within the scrutiny of the Committee under its terms of reference. I refer particularly to Drafting Instruction No. 5 of 1982 given by the Office of Parliamentary Counsel on the subject of reports of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. Media support for the Committee and its work is also noted. In particular, the editorial of the Canberra Times dated 15 September 1982 said:

The Senate regulations committee and its scrutiny of Bills Committee are particularly worth while, examining the effects of parliamentary measures on civil liberties, with the help of professional legal consultants, retained and paid for their advice.

Indeed, all these committees give members of Parliament a deserved sense of their value to electors which would be difficult to feel if their work were confined to the chambers. As members of committees honourable members and senators tend to work primarily as members of Parliament whatever their party affiliations; this gives them a fine, traditional purpose, which the people really need. Thus, it appears that the Committee is achieving what it set out to do. If, therefore, its task is worth while its existence is worth while. The Attorney-General (Senator Durack), in his contribution to the debate on 19 November, said:

I think we would all agree that the question of legislation infringing basic human rights or civil liberties is a most important one that should be in the minds of all members of Parliament when they consider legislation.

I for one certainly agree and therefore argue that the Committee is worth while and should be retained. As to the specific recommendations, I agree with the Committee's report that it should now be established as a separate and distinct Committee in terms of the proposed new Standing Order. There does not appear to be scope for its absorption either within the Constitutional and Legal Affairs Standing Committee or the Regulations and Ordinances Standing Committee. To refer Bills to relevant legislative Standing Committee would be administratively inefficient, apart from the difficulty that such Committees do not cover the field, as was mentioned earlier today. Therefore, I believe that the experiment has proved successful and the existence of the Committee should be endorsed as a continuing tool for senators to fulfil more efficiently and effectively their review function in an area of great importance. That the Committee has been able to justify itself and to be an efficiently operating body within such a short period is in no small measure due to the contribution of its secretary during the period, Anne Lynch, and its consultant, Professor Dennys Pearce. Their efforts must be particularly acknowledged.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-In view of what my colleague has said in summary of the work of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, I say merely that I certainly hope that the motion to adopt the report will be carried and the Committee put on a permanent basis. We stand by the record of the Committee over the last nine months. We have compiled some six reports since the ninth report which is the subject of adoption now. The result of the adoption this motion will be that the Committee will be put on a permanent basis .

SPEECH.PARA: The proposed Standing Order will go to the Standing Orders Committee for vetting and, when that requirement is satisfied, I trust that the permanent complement of the Committee will be set up. I trust that will be done before the rising of the Senate so that the Committee may continue its work into the new year. I thank the Ministers and my colleagues for the support which they have given in this trial period for the Committee. It has been delightful to work with them and the co-operation shown by Ministers and others involved with the Committee has been excellent. I hope that the motion will be carried.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 19 August 1982.
Clause 1 (Short Title).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take the opportunity presented by the name of the Bill in clause 1 to make a couple of general comments which may be of at least partial assistance in the conduct of this debate. I say at the outset that this is rather the sort of debate that one needs to warm up for by having perhaps a day or two of total immersion in the materials. One almost wishes that one was an academic again, having those sorts of ample days at one's disposal, rather than having to contend as we do with matters being brought on at relatively short notice after a lapse of some months.

SPEECH.PARA: But it may be of assistance if I draw to the attention of honourable senators just what documents they have before them and how, as a result, we might expeditiously proceed through the Committee stage of this Bill. There are, in fact, four printed documents that have been re-circulated to honourable senators today. Firstly, there is the original Bill, as introduced on 11 November 1981. Secondly, there is a five page document entitled 'Amendments to be moved by Senator Evans'. They are, of course, the amendments that are proposed to the original Bill and were foreshadowed in the Senate on 18 March and first circulated to honourable senators on 6 May of this year, some considerable time ago. There is a single page document also headed 'Amendments to be moved by Senator Evans', which simply corrects some typographical errors on page 4 of the amendments booklet. There is nothing of any particular substance on that single page document. It is simply to make typographical corrections and is circulated for the record rather than because of its substantive significance. The final printed document that honourable senators should have in front of them is an explanatory memo, circulated by me at the conclusion of the second reading debate, which sets out the provisions of the Constitution as they would appear if the Bill were passed with the amendments that I propose to move today. I suggest that it might suit the convenience of the Senate were our primary attention in the course of this debate devoted to that explanatory memorandum rather than to the text of the Bill and to the amendment sheets.

The only other general thing that I want to refer to in regard to this clause is to draw attention to what is an extraordinary circumstance. When last we debated this Bill, in August, there was intense speculation about an early election. One could hardly forbear at that time from suggesting that one way of coping with the manifest instability to which that speculation was giving rise in the political systems was to adopt this Bill. Once again we have a situation in which there is a fever of speculation about an early election. Whether it has been put to rest in the last half hour or whether it is to be set running again in the next half hour I am not quite sure. It is made possible, of course, by the fact that--

TALK.START.PARA: —The point is not really relevant, Senator. There could still be speculation about a double dissolution.

—Speculation is still rampant around the place. It is, of course, the kind of speculation that would, except in the context of a possible double dissolution as Senator Hamer points out and in the other circumstance that is provided for in this Bill, be impossible if this legislation were passed. Although the circumstance of a double dissolution would not entirely be ruled out under this Bill, it is provided for in one of the amendments to be moved today; namely, that any double dissolution would produce a new parliament only for the duration of the term remaining to be served out by the old one. With a mere 12 months of the Government's original term left, one suspects that it would be rather unlikely that under those circumstances the speculation about an early election would be as feverish as it now is. I am indebted to Senator Hamer for drawing attention to what is a central argument in regard to this Bill; we will come to it later.

SPEECH.PARA: I make the point at the outset of the debate that while I do not know whether the Prime Minister, Malcolm Fraser, prays any more or whether, if he does, there is anyone up there any longer listening to him, I cannot help suggesting that if he were really concerned about instability and destabilisation in the present political system, about the overweening power of this particular institution, the Senate, to create that climate of instability and make life difficult for the government of the day he would, of course, accept rapidly and with open arms the invitation being proffered to him by this legislation to change the constitutional system once and for all and make the kind of climate that we have seen over the last few months impossible of repetition. I hope that it will be possible for us to proceed expeditiously, at least in regard to most of the complexities involved, in getting this legislation through the Committee stage today. I suggest that if we devote our attention to dealing with the Bill clause by clause, referring primarily in the process to the printed explanatory memorandum, that may not be too difficult a task.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Evans, I take the opportunity of speaking at this stage on clause 1 of the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Bill 1981. Although I shall not move an amendment to the name of the Bill, I would like to move such an amendment, perhaps seeking to call it the Senate (Disembowelling) Bill or some such term. Although I shall not do that, I take the opportunity to respond to a challenge which was made to me the last time when this Bill came before the Senate. During that debate, I stated that, as a result of the Watergate affair in the United States of America, experts in that country had been critically examining the fixed term provisions of the United States Constitution and had advocated more flexible arrangements. Both Senators Evans and Macklin challenged me to produce some of those experts and I undertook to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1974, Congressman Henry Reuss of Wisconsin sponsored a Bill to amend the Constitution to provide that Congress could turn the President out of office and bring about a presidential election, the condition of this power being that the whole of both Houses go to an election also. That was one matter. I now draw attention to an article entitled 'Britain and America: The Institutionalization of Accountability' by William S. Livingston in the Journal of Politics, volume 38, 1976.

TALK.START.PARA: —Another name on everyone's lips.

—I understand Senator Evans's interjection. Of course it is not a name on everyone's lips but when I said that there were experts in the United States who were concerned about the United States provisions he challenged me to produce those experts and indicated that in his view there were no such experts. So I am afraid I shall have to explain to the Senate who those experts were and what some of them said. For example, this fellow, Mr Livingston, in a Presidential Address delivered to the annual meeting of the Southern Political Science Association held in Nashville, Tennessee, in November 1975, said:

SPEECH.PARA: In the past few years, there has been a spate of proposals suggesting that various elements of the British system should be grafted onto our own, as a means of preventing any recurrence of that mixed bag of evils we lump together and call ''Watergate''.
So, he considered that there was a spate of proposals. He went on to say:

In the aftermath of Watergate, this admiration for the British system seems to be intensified, and many who believe that the solution to the problems posed by Watergate lies in institutional reform summon us again to adopt various elements of the British system.

To many Americans from Woodrow Wilson on, that device has offered the ultimate solution to the problem of irresponsible government in America. In the old days, we had the testimony of William Y. Elliot and Thomas K. Finletter. Nowadays similar proposals come to us from Morley Ayearst, James L. Sundquist, and indeed from Senator Edward Kennedy.
We have finally found a name that Senator Evans will be able to remember. He continues:
If Americans would only give Congress the power to expel a president by an adverse vote of various sizes, the problems of the irresponsible executive would be solved.
Again, in this article, he states:

The Watergate revelations have provoked a rash of reform proposals, many of which are drastic in character and extent. Some critics, like Leland Baldwin and James L. Sundquist would subject the President to a vote of no-confidence. Others--

He then goes on to quote two or three others with other proposals. I am not putting forward this information as any argument in favour of my argument. I am putting it forward in response to the challenge which was made to me, during the debate on this subject, to show that there were Americans who were so concerned about Watergate that they realised that the problems of a fixed term parliament were quite desperate. I have not finished yet by a long shot. Let me refer to an article entitled 'Doing Away With Presidential Impeachment: The Advantages of Parliamentary Government' by one Harold C. Havighurst-they have incredible names , some of the United States people-who is apparently Professor of Law, Emeritus, Northwestern University, wherever that is--

TALK.START.PARA: —Disneyland.

—In Ohio. Senator Robert Ray said 'Disneyland' but I would be proud of being a Doctor of Laws of Harvard University and a Bachelor of Laws of Ohio University and I would be quite proud of being able to write such an article as this. In any event, this gentleman said:

SPEECH.PARA: Since the emergence of Watergate, I have heard or read expressions by a number of people in this country to the effect that what is now happening in and to our Government could not happen under a parliamentary system.
We must start with the recognition that . . . Once a president is elected, he continues to exercise those powers for a period of 4 years.
He then goes on to consider the problems of the American Constitution and, in the course of this consideration, he says:
Basic parliamentary principles require that when differences develop, either the legislature or the executive may at any time force a general election.
I just draw the Senate'e attention to those words:
when differences develop either the legislature or the executive may at any time force a general election.
He is saying that when differences develop between the legislature and the Executive either the legislature or the Executive may at any time force a general election. He then goes on to say:

This is to be contrasted with our present system where the time of the next Presidential election is definitely known. Efforts to remain in office can be concentrated and pointed well in advance to a known date.

I would also draw attention to two other works, one entitled Reframing the Constitution: An Imperative for Modern America by a fellow named Leland D. Baldwin, published in 1972 and 'Needed: A Workable Check on the Presidency' by James L. Sundquist, whose name I have read out two or three times before, in The Brookings Bulletin, volume 10, No. 4, page 7.
Finally, on this matter, let me refer to an editorial in New Republic of 20 July 1974 entitled 'Turbulence Ahead' when these words were used:

With a parliamentary system like Canada's, the United States could have dealt with Watergate two months after it was discovered. With our rigid government we have instead reached a point of public helplessness.
Finally, the last quote I will make is from Mr James Sundquist who in this same editorial is quoted as saying:
Under our system, a Neville Chamberlain would stay in office for his full term even if that meant losing a war, and the very freedom of the nation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that the question is that clause 1 stand as printed. Clause 1 deals with the short title.

—I wish to comment on a couple of points in the very interesting address by Senator Lewis. I draw attention to the fact that what he was talking about and what was being talked about in those articles was the old argument between responsible government and presidential government. There are many arguments on both sides. None of those people was seriously addressing the issue of a fixed term for the legislature, which is the matter which this title covers and which is the matter before us. There is a great deal of argument, and I personally much prefer the Executive to be responsible to the legislature as it is in the Westminster system. The American system of separation of powers is in my view inappropriate, too rigid and unwork- able. All those people were addressing their remarks to that issue. It was a very interesting address but I submit that it was irrelevant to the matter before the Committee.

—I will address myself to the clause which concerns the short title. The short title of the Bill refers to the Constitution Alteration (Fixed Term Parliaments) Act. I believe the short title ought to be substituted for the long title, which involves not only the duration of the House of Representatives but also the holding of elections for the Senate and House of Representatives, disagreement between the Houses with respect to proposed laws, and the appointment and termination of the appointment of Ministers of state.
—The long title should be substituted for the short title.

—The short title ought to be substituted for the long title as the long title as well as the short title. In other words, the only items that should be left in this Bill are the items in relation to fixed term parliaments. While there may be support for other aspects of this Bill and they may be worth arguing about, I think it is probably preferable, given the previous debate, that we do not seek to present a Bill which has anything more than one item in it. Therefore, I will propose as we go through succeeding clauses that those clauses which do not bear directly on the item of fixed term parliaments ought to be defeated.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take this opportunity to rise again and say that I suport what Senator Macklin has put forward. There is some merit in the fixed term concept in relation to the Senate and the House of Representatives-in other words, the legislature-but Senator Hamer, in his response to the remarks I made earlier, failed to understand the significant defect which the fixed term concept has in relation to the Executive; that is, it takes away from a Prime Minister the right to go to the Governor-General and advise an election. That is the fundamental defect with fixed terms.

SPEECH.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —I can hear honourable senators on the other side of the chamber protesting. If those honourable senators had been in West Germany recently and found that the leader who represented their point of view in the West German Parliament was unable to organise an election in West Germany, notwithstanding his desperate desire to do so, I am sure they would be arguing strongly in favour of what I am saying at the present time. There is a fundamental defect in the fixed term concept-that is, that the Prime Minister of the day is unable to go to the Governor-General and advise an election. It may be that under our system at the present moment the Prime Minister's advice will not be accepted by the Governor-General. I am sure that Senator Evans would argue against that. As I understand it, in 1975 the Australian Labor Party said that the Prime Minister 's advice should be accepted by the Governor-General.

SPEECH.PARA: As things stand at present the Governor-General may not accept the advice. Therefore, when the Prime Minister of the day loses the confidence of the Parliament he has a number of choices. He can accept the decision of the Parliament to allow another government to take his government's place or he may go to the Governor-General and say: 'I have lost the confidence of the Parliament but I am sure that I have the confidence of the people. Let us have an election to decide this political issue'. If the Governor-General accepts that and the Prime Minister calls an election, the people of the nation are entitled to make the decision as to which party shall be the government of the day and who will be the members of parliament to represent them, not some members of parliament who just happen to have changed their point of view in relation to who they will support as Prime Minister in the House of Representatives. That is the fundamental defect of the fixed term system which, with all due respect, my colleagues behind me and Senator Evans opposite seem to fail to understand.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to Senator Lewis's point. The treatment of the clauses is getting beyond a joke. Senator Lewis's remarks were perfectly appropriate to clause 2 of the Bill, bearing as they did on the circumstances in which the House of Representatives could be dissolved, but they hardly bear upon the subject matter of the title at large, except in the context of a second reading debate. Might I suggest that the time for introductory florid remarks is over and we ought to get down to the substance of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for the first time in this debate because my speech at the second reading stage was incorporated in Hansard on 25 March 1982 and I was absent thereafter. I stand by everything I said in that speech, which is there for honourable senators to read. This is the first time that I have had a chance to say anything on this Bill. I agree entirely with Senator Macklin that this Bill is a fixed terms Bill and that it ought to stay that way. I hope that we will delete, in particular, clauses 8 and 9 when we get to them so that the Bill will be confined to this subject-a subject which then might have some chance of getting through in a referendum because it does not include extraneous subjects, such as the Supply question, which is very controversial. From that point of view I think that Senator Macklin is right.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Lewis, in his speech today, made the point that the taking away of the prime ministerial right to go to a Governor-General and advise an early election is a defect in the Bill. To my mind it enshrines the real principle of the Bill. Surely it could not be more appropriate than at the present time to say that we do not need in this country the destabilising situation whereby a Prime Minister may or may not go at some early stage to the Governor-General and obtain an election. The removal of that provision is very timely indeed. This Bill is a very suitable method of ensuring that that is done. Today's Age states:
The Prime Minister also said he was considering a new referendum to make it compulsory for elections for the House of Representatives and the Senate to be held at the same time.
He said he was ''seriously thinking'' of proposing to his colleagues that this referendum, which was lost by the Government in 1977, should again be put to the people.
''That would prevent the Senate and the House of Representatives getting out of line'', said Mr Fraser.
As one who supported the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) very strongly throughout the 1977 referendum--

TALK.START.PARA: —You lost it though.

—We won only 62 per cent of the vote. In the honourable senator's democratic sense he would call that a loss. Having strongly supported that campaign and having seen the difficulties because some of the peripheral States are difficult to satisfy, I would not advise the Prime Minister to adopt this course. I believe it would raise opposition again. I think that honourable senators should hear me out on this. I am not advocating that this should be done. I am saying to the Prime Minister and others that there is a danger that a series of short parliaments will come one after another. The Senate could be cleared out quite quickly by that means. I have never thought it to be a real possibility but it is a possibility that that could be done by a government, perhaps an unscrupulous government. We want to get away from that situation of short parliaments and of uncertainties as to the terms of parliaments. The essential principle of this Bill is incorporated in the fixed term concept. I hope that with the removal of the surplus we will be able to do a by-pass operation. We will enable the heart of this country to operate better if we pass the Bill with its essence and get rid of the excesses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was a bit surprised at Senator Evans's intervention in the debate. He complained about the contribution of Senator Lewis when he himself ranged rather widely in his contribution regarding the short title. I will try to avoid the same temptation and restrict myself to the short title. I was a little puzzled by the contribution from the Australian Democrats. It seems to me that the long title at least attempted to get across the rather varied provisions of the Bill, whereas the short title deals with one narrow aspect of it, albeit the aspect seen as the most important by some honourable senators and apparently by the Australian Democrats. I take the view that the short title should be amended to make it more aptly reflect the total contents of the Bill, but I can see the point which is made by the Australian Democrats when they suggest that if everything is removed from the Bill but those provisions which relate to fixed terms it becomes an appropriate short title. On that basis, and on that basis only, I would agree that clause 1 is in a satisfactory form. I would have thought that there would be government support-without knowing the detail of the Democrats moves-for the sorts of changes which would refine the Bill. I am sure that with those additional elements removed, whilst it might still not be acceptable to the Government, it would be in a form which was less unacceptable. My comments on the first clause of the Bill are simply that I agree with those speakers who have suggested that it is inapt. I note that amendments are to be put forward which might render it apt.

SPEECH.PARA: I also think that I would agree with Senator Lewis rather than with Senator Hamer on the relevance of Senator Lewis's comments. I think the whole concept of having fixed terms of the Australian Parliament-indeed, that is a concept which is not followed through in the Bill because, in fact, the terms can be foreshortened in circumstances which are indicated in the Bill-flies in the face of the concept of responsible government. I really do not see that Senator Hamer can have it both ways. I do not think he can be a wholehearted supporter of responsible government, as he professed himself to be, and a supporter of fixed term parliaments. That is clearly a view on which there are some differences of opinion among Government senators. My own view of the logic of the situation is that Senator Lewis was, in fact, quite in order and relevant in raising the broader considerations he raised for the reason I have just mentioned.

I also thought there was a great deal of force in Senator Lewis's comments when he referred to various American authorities. In politics there is a tendency to see the grass as being greener on the other side of the fence. In Australia it is very easy to look to the virtue of a non-parliamentary Executive, to look at the virtues of fixed terms, and to say that they avoid some of the problems of Australian politics. It is also true that many American commentators are quite respectable. I think many of them are men of distinction. I did not quite understand the giggles that came from some parts of the benches opposite at the mention of people who I suspect are at least as notable authorities on constitutional matters as anyone in this chamber, although I am sure Senator Evans's name is on the lips of every serious constitutional commentator in the United States. I suggest that the authorities quoted by Senator Lewis are quite respectable.

I would like to refer to one authority with some risk because I am not absolutely sure that I remember the name exactly. I think it was Representative Boland, who was a very experienced member of the House of Representatives and who was narrowly defeated in the election of Speaker of the House by Representative O'Neill. He wrote a couple of books about the American political system which were a very good example of Americans looking to our system and seeing its virtues as against the vices of their own system. I think those books were lent to me by the present Clerk of the Senate. I will not even guess at the titles, but I advise all those who are interested in Americans looking over the fence to see the Clerk and borrow the books.

Representative Boland pointed out that one of the besetting sins of the American political system was something we tend to look on as a problem in Australia-namely, the American absence of a caucus system. It was pointed out that the lack of any party discipline and unity in the United States had effectively slowed down the operation of democratic government in that country and had meant that electoral programs were seldom actually translated into enactments. It was a most convincing argument on why we should change very little in the Australian political system-otherwise we will pick up all the vices of the American political system. I thank Senator Lewis for his contribution to clause 1 and I share the misgivings that have been expressed about it.

Ultimately the Committee will go back and consider the title of the Bill. The procedure is set out under Standing Order 199. At this stage we will be dealing with the clauses of the Bill.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman.

DEBATE.TITLE: CUSTOMS TARIFF BILL 1982CUSTOMS TARIFF (ANTI-DUMPING) AMENDMENT BILL 1982CUSTOMS TARIFF (MISCELLANEOUS AMENDMENTS) BILL 1982

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are continuing this cognate debate on these Bills. The principal Bill is the Customs Tariff Bill 1982 which replaces the Customs Tariff Act 1966. One of the objectives of the Government's industry policy has been the development of a simpler and more stable tariff structure. The decision the Government has taken in this Bill is a significant step towards achieving that objective. The whole purpose of the legislation is to try to save a great deal of time and effort in determining the rate of duty applicable to imported goods. This will help not only the government sector but also private enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is significant that the provisions basically follow the recommendations in the report of the Industries Assistance Commission. The reference was given to the Commission in 1978. It reported in 1981. The commencement date of these pieces of legislation will be 1 January 1983. One of the difficulties is that the Australian tariff has become increasingly difficult to work with for both the public sector and private enterprise. It has been proposed, and it will be implemented by this Bill, that the number of classifications be reduced from something like 2,500 to 2,000 and that the number of different rates of duty be reduced from about 700 to 250.

This IAC inquiry, which commenced in 1978, was different from most other sorts of inquiries in relation to the tariff in that it tended to cover the whole of the tariff and, therefore, all imported goods. But it did not involve a review of the level of assistance. In fact, we are told that the recommendations do not substantially affect assistance afforded to Australian industry and that the rates do not exceed plus or minus five percentage points with equivalent changes for rates not expressed in ad valorem rates. The 1966 Act was an extremely fragmented and complex document constituting five schedules divided into 16 operative sections and three inoperative parts, together with some covering provisions. Therefore, in the main Schedule alone, there were these 2,500 classifications to which I referred earlier.

The whole objective of the IAC report was to try to make the Customs Bill a very much simpler document. Unfortunately, some of the problems with classification were that the use of the language was formerly fairly obscure or often vague and ambiguous. It covered a lot of commodities which were not actually intended to be covered. This Bill tends to obviate that particular problem. Further, the definitions of the commodities were in such terms that they did not really correspond to general commercial use. Honourable senators can see the difficulties that would apply in such a situation. The definition of the commodities made evaluation uncertain and sometimes fairly difficult. The setting of different rates of duty for commodities which would otherwise not be separated on commercial documents was a problem we had to face. That was the general scenario which we tried to overcome.

I should like briefly to trace the history of tariff protection which we have had since Federation. In 1901 there were only about 300 sorts of classifications . Most of them were designed to provide a revenue base and to provide revenue. The next significant change came about in 1932 with the Ottowa agreement which gave tariff preference to British goods. While I am talking about preference I think I should emphasise the wide ambit of preference that is given but which is not generally recognised in Australia. Clause 19 of the Customs Tariff Bill 1982 gives preference to New Zealand, Papua New Guinea, Forum Island countries, declared preference countries, developing countries and Canada. We have six groupings whereby substantial concessional rates are granted to those particular areas. For example, the Forum Island countries are not generally known. They include such places as the Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, Nauru, Solomon Islands, Tonga, Tuvalu, Western Samoa and Vanuatu. In addition, we have declared preference countries. These comprise some 30 additional countries to which preference is given-such as Malaysia, Singapore, Sri Lanka and so on. In addition, there are places which are treated as declared preference countries. Another 14 countries are listed as declared preference countries. A further 100 countries are declared as developing countries. They receive special concessions . Finally, there are places that are not developing countries but that are treated as developing countries. In this category we have another 16 countries.

When we talk about the problems of Australian tariffs and keeping out goods from the rest of the world I think we have to recognise that there is a tremendous number of concessions. I wonder whether the time is right now for us to start looking at our whole tariff structure in the light of the tremendous unemployment in Australia at the moment. Perhaps the time is appropriate for us to review the question of Australian government preference. Following the Commonwealth Heads of Government Regional Meeting and the so-called North-South dialogue this preference was lost. A lot of Australian manufacturing business has been lost to other countries as a result of action taken by the Australian Government to do away with preference to Australian manufacturers.

In view of the high unemployment in Australia at present I think that is the first step we should take to try to ensure that more business is done in Australia as a result of Commonwealth work. In other words, I think it is a tragedy that not only the Commonwealth but also the State of New South Wales currently is putting business outside Australia when thousands of manufacturing jobs are at risk and thousands of people are out of work. I think that is certainly an area at which we should be looking. I wish to refer also to clause 25 of the Bill. It is an important part of the Customs tariff legislation. It states:
The Minister may, by notice published in the Gazette-
(a) declare that he is of opinion that goods of a kind specified in the notice-
(i) are a substitute for goods of another kind specified in the notice;
(ii) are intended to be or can be used as a substitute for goods of another kind specified in the notice;
(iii) can be used for any purpose for which goods of another kind specified in the notice can be used; or
(iv) are an imitation of goods of another kind specified in the notice; and
(b) direct that the duty in respect of goods of that first-mentioned kind is the duty that would be applicable in respect of them if they were goods of that other kind.

The whole purpose of this provision is to prevent an importer using the by-law type operation or bringing in goods of a similar kind but at a lower rate of duty, thereby undercutting the Australian manufacturer. We have seen plenty of examples of this. Although the words 'are intended to be or can be used as a substitute' are faily specific, in practice manufacturers have a great deal of difficulty with the Department. They have difficulty in proving that the goods are substitute goods, despite the fact that in the Queen's English the intention , the purpose, is particularly clear. I point to a recent example. Printed cloth was imported but after it had been washed a couple of times the print was effectively washed out. Although the importers are protected because it is printed cloth, the effect is that the cloth competes with an existing Australian product as a substitute product. These are the sorts of techniques that importers adopt to try to overcome the provisions of the legislation.

I think that somehow we have to implement much more fairly the purpose and intent of clause 25, particularly at a time of high unemployment in Australia. Manufacturers complain daily about the problems of the operation of this legislation. The words are fairly clear but in practice it does not seem to be working very well. I note that the fifteenth report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills dated 20 October 1982 made reference to the ministerial discretion in this Bill. I seek to incorporate in Hansard page 5 of that report which deals with clause 25, ministerial discretion. I think it has a great deal of relevance, particularly in the light of the amendment which will be moved later, a copy of which was put before us a few minutes ago.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Clause 25-Ministerial discretion

In its original comments on this clause in Alert Digest No. 11 and the Thirteenth Report of 23 September 1982, the Committee noted that the effect of this provision is to allow the Minister to amend the Schedule. This clause empowers the Minister to direct that goods, which he determines to be substitutes for or imitations of other goods already specified in the Schedule, shall be dutiable at the rate of the Scheduled goods. The Minister is to exercise his discretion by notice published in the Gazette.

In a subsequent letter to the Committee, the Minister Assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce states that the provision for Gazette Substitution and Imitation Notices ''is not new, and is presently contained in section 23 of the Customs Tariff Act 1966''. However, the Minister also stated that the current Government policy was that ''the provision for such Notices should remain, but that as normal practice, such Notices [shall] be viewed as temporary measures pending inquiry and report by the I.A.C. It is not planned that any Notice will be operative as at 1 January 1983, the intended date of the operation of the new Tariff Act.''
The Minister went on to invite the Committee to consider the following modification of the provision:

''If it were to be considered essential, provisions similar to those in clause 26 (7) could be made in clause 25. In that event, rather than delay passage of the Bill, I am prepared to give an undertaking to amend the Act before it becomes operative. This could be achieved by a Notice of Intention to Propose Customs tariff alteration by Gazette Notice in pursuance of section 273EA of the Customs Act 1901.''

Although the Committee welcomes the Minister's intention to amend the Bill, it is concerned that the proposed amending mechanism is itself an example of a '' Henry VIII'' provision, to which the Committee has an in principle objection. The Committee would prefer to see the Bill improved by a substantive amendment before Parliament passes the Bill. The Minister's proposal attempts to correct one defective legislative provision by resort to a similar one in the Principal Act which, unfortunately, is not before the Committee. The Committee remains concerned that the unamended provision in clause 25 allows the Minister to amend the Schedule, and it draws this to the attention of the Senate under principle 1 (a) (iv) in that it might be regarded as imappropriately delegating legislative power, and under principle 1 (a) (v) in that it might be regarded as insufficiently subjecting the exercise of delegated legislative power to parliamentary scrutiny.

TALK.START.PARA: —We can see the difficulty of this legislation so far as civil liberties are concerned. I think this was described as an Henry VIII provision. As I understand the amendment which will be moved later, its purpose is to have the declaration tabled as if it were a regulation. I believe that will tend to overcome some of the problems. I have been asked to keep my remarks brief in view of the fact that this Bill must be returned to the House of Representatives in the next half hour. I conclude with these remarks: I would like to see an early restoration of Commonwealth preference in relation to buying Australian rather than overseas goods. I am concerned about the application of by-laws. I believe that, at a time of high unemployment, we have to look much more closely at the issue of quota. I should like the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner) to examine further the problems caused by this concept of broad banding , particularly in relation to the clothing industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Siddons Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Customs tariff legislation. This package of Bills replaces the Customs Tariff Act 1966 with a simplified tariff based on the recommendations made in the report of the Industries Assistance Commission of November 1981. It will take effect from 1 January 1982. The existing Customs legislation is amongst the most complex on the statute books. Since it was enacted a great deal has changed in the world, especially amongst Australia's trading partners. Britain has entered the European Economic Community and the gradual rise of Japan as one of our largest trading partners is perhaps the most significant trend in our trade relations.

SPEECH.PARA: The other major change which has occurred in the last 16 years relevant to the Customs legislation is that there has been a gradual change in the nature of goods being imported. A whole range of new products in our modern world- electronic and other-are now in existence which were not even thought of in 1966 . The Bureau of Customs and the Australian Taxation Office have had great difficulty in reconciling these new goods with the old legislation. In fact, the Government has only recently recognised, with the announcement of a reference on computers and related materials to the IAC, that there is a need to move in this direction in relation to new products. I believe that this piece of legislation is probably one of the most loved pieces of legislation to enter this chamber. It is long overdue. It replaces a piece of legislation which is probably the most tortuous on our statute books. We support the Bills wholeheartedly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply -I rise to thank the Senate for its support of the legislation and to mention one item that was raised in relation to wheelchairs by Senator Evans during his speech. He spoke of the problem of import duty being applied to imported wheelchairs. I want to make the same point that I made during the debate on a similar Bill some six months ago when this matter was raised. The legislation then envisaged reduced, on a phased down basis, the import duty then applying from 36 per cent to a long term rate of 20 per cent. So in fact there has been a significant downturn in the amount of duty being applied.

SPEECH.PARA: The question of a bounty in respect of locally manufactured wheelchairs was considered but was discarded on the grounds of administrative difficulty. It is, of course, to be acknowledged that the proper way in which to address care for the unfortunate handicapped people who find the need to buy wheelchairs is through the social security system. That is the way in which the Government would be endeavouring to help people in that unfortunate situation. I wish the Bills a speedy passage.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

—We support the request and commend the Government for taking up the suggestion of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills.

Clauses 2 to 4-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise simply to make it clear that I am opposed to the clauses. I simply say to those who have spoken in relation to clause 1, other than Senator Chaney, that with all due respect I believe that their minds are pre-occupied with the calling of early elections for politically expedient reasons. It seems to me that at some time in their careers they have believed that some Prime Ministers have misused this power and their minds are so pre- occupied with those problems that they have failed to give consideration to those occasions when it may very well be necessary for the future of the nation to have an early election. I referred earlier to Neville Chamberlain being Prime Minister of Great Britain and perhaps the people of Great Britain being able to get rid of him.
—They did not have an election.
—I am just giving examples of when it may be necessary to have an election.
—To replace a Prime Minister, but not to have an election.

—I sincerely put it to some honourable senators that they have failed to give any consideration to the arguments against fixed terms because, for reasons of political expediency, they have tunnel vision on the question of calling early elections. I shall be opposing these clauses although, in view of the time, I shall not be calling for a division.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The preoccupation of Senator Lewis with the desirability of there being an early election in the event of a government of the day losing the confidence of the lower House-a point that he has made today as he has made on the second reading and as he has made on numerous other occasions-seems to display a lack of appreciation on his part of one of the most fundamental principles of the system of responsible government that we have inherited. That is that the composition of the government of the day should depend upon the confidence of the lower House, the directly elected popular House, and the government of the day should be determined by reference to whom it is that the lower House, at any given time, is prepared to vest confidence in . It has been entirely consistent with the history of the United Kingdom, as was demonstrated by the very example of Neville Chamberlain which Senator Lewis gave , because Chamberlain's replacement was accomplished without there being the necessity of an election but just simply by the vote of the House of Commons. Manifestly that was a sequence of events that was very much perceived to be in the national interest at the time.

SPEECH.PARA: Not only has it happened in the United Kingdom, but also it has happened, on my calculations, at least eight times in the history of Australia, federally. It happened in 1903 with the replacement of the Deakin Ministry with that of Barton . It happened in 1904 when Deakin gave way to Watson. It happened again in 1904, in June, when Watson gave way to Reid. It happened in 1905 when Reid gave way to Deakin. It happened in 1908 when Deakin gave way to Fisher. It happened in 1909 when Fisher gave way to Deakin. It happened in 1917 when Hughes, wearing his Labor Party hat, gave way to himself in another capacity and with a differently constituted party behind him. It happened in 1941 with the defection of Coles and Wilson to the Labor Party, enabling the creation, at a time of national emergency when arguably an election would have been quite inappropriate, of a Labor Government commanding the confidence of the lower House.

It may be that those examples do not impress Senator Lewis as having any relevance, but they are a demonstration that the system is capable of responding flexibly to an environment in which party allegiances shift and change. Mercifully, there have not been many examples of that in recent decades. With all due respect to the representatives of minority parties present in our midst, it is to be hoped that that is not a situation that will recur in the foreseeable future as far as the lower House here is concerned. But to the extent that it occurs, the system is perfectly capable of dealing with it, and the proposals embodied in these clauses to enable Parliament to continue its term even though a lack of confidence has been expressed in a particular Ministry-provided that a vote of confidence is expressed in someone else-are perfectly workable and perfectly consistent with the principles of responsible government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —One point seems to have affected the judgment of those who oppose the Bill. Some of them seem to have the idea that in our present system a Prime Minister defeated in the House of Representatives has an automatic right to call an election. That is not true. There is no question of it being true. The precedents are utterly clear. In 1903, when Watson was defeated on a vote of confidence in the House of Representatives, he asked the Governor-General for an election. The Governor-General said that it was his duty to see whether someone else could form a government. A new government was formed and there was no election. In 1941, when Fadden was beaten by the defection of two on his own side who voted against him, a new government was formed. There was no election. The only instance when a Prime Minister defeated in the House of Representatives on a crucial issue has been able to go to an election was Bruce in 1929, when no alternative government could be formed.

SPEECH.PARA: That is exactly what would be achieved by these procedures. If a government can be formed, having the confidence of the House, that government takes over. That is entirely appropriate. It is what happens now. If no government can be formed, what happens now is that there is an election, and that is the procedure in the Bill. That argument is based, I regret to say, on a total constitutional misconception.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am now forced to respond to Senator Hamer because I did not say any such thing as that of which he accuses me. It is very easy to set up a patsy and then knock it down. I said no such thing. I do not believe that those who are opposed to the fixed term concept are putting forward any such proposal. What we have said is very clear. It is that the proposal deprives the Prime Minister of the right to advise the Governor-General to call an election because he has lost the confidence of the Parliament. The Governor- General may very well not accept that advice. The Prime Minister may decide not to go to the Governor-General and advise an election. But what this proposal does is to take away from the so-called elected government, about which we hear so much from the Opposition-I do not believe that there is any such concept as an 'elected' government, but the Opposition is always talking about 'the elected government' being sacked-the right of that elected government, which is, in other words, the Prime Minister of the day, any right to say to the Governor- General: 'I have lost the confidence of the House. Let the people decide'.
—The Governor-General would certainly say no.

—With all due respect, Senator Hamer, I say that, if the Governor- General were to take the advice of people such as Senator Evans, who would say that the Governor-General should always accept the advice of his Ministers, the Governor-General would say yes. Clearly this is a controversy about which we could all agree to have a good argument and a high school debate. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that clause 5 in the original Bill deals with sections 12 and 13 of the Constitution. As regards the proposed amendment to section 13 of the Constitution, it is now proposed by me to amend the original terms of our Bill. The amendment has been circulated for about six months and I think that its content is familiar to honourable senators. The effect of section 13 as it stands-and it can really only be understood when read together with the proposed new section 28 dealing specifically with the duration of the House of Representatives-is to ensure, first, that the normal term of a senator remains the present six years, subject only to an earlier double dissolution. It is further provided that, in the event of an extraordinarily early election caused by the defeat of the Government in the House of Representatives, only the House of Representatives will be dissolved. In the original version of this amendment to section 13 the Senate went out too when the House of Representatives was dissolved by virtue of a no confidence motion. Now it is proposed, as becomes clear when one reads the proposed new section 13 together with the proposed new section 28, that a dissolution of the House of Representatives alone following a no confidence vote and the inability to form another government will have no effect on the terms of senators. We will go on as before. The reason that is possible is that, as I have indicated, the proposal now is that, in the event of an early dissolution of the House of Representatives, the House of Representatives when newly elected will see out the term that it would otherwise have done rather than commence a new three-year term. So it is still possible for the House of Representatives and Senate elections to remain synchronised.

To summarise further, section 13 ensures that to avoid unnecessary multiplication of elections where there is such an extraordinary dissolution of the House of Representatives less than three months before the scheduled fixed term election date, the ordinary election for the half Senate is to be held at the same time. So there is some modification of the existing rule in relation to half Senate elections in section 13 to accommodate that eventuality. Furthermore there is a provision built into section 13 that in the event of a double dissolution the newly elected Senate would divide into two classes, as is the case at the moment, with the so-called short term senators becoming due for re- election at the next scheduled ordinary House of Representatives-cum-half Senate election. There is a further provision there of appropriate transitional provisions. I do not understand any of these provisions to be controversial as between those who are keen on the fixed term concept. These provisions are controversial for those who oppose the fixed term concept, but for those who support it they are simply an improved, streamlined and more workable version of the concept contained in the original Bill. Accordingly, I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the amendment in the version Senator Evans has now put forward. I believe this is a much more workable way in which to provide for a fixed term. I think it would probably lead also to some lack of venture in the House of Representatives as those who would seek to divide parties, to force an election, to get rid of a Prime Minister and so forth would know that they are only taking up the period of the fixed term and therefore would have to face the electors at a later date. I think this amendment makes for stability as well. I believe it is desirable that as far as possible we keep to the fixed terms, as this amendment does, so that people will know from year to year when elections will take place and there is the same fairness and certainty for all parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The version that we now have of a fixed term parliament is, I think, far more satisfactory than the one which appeared in the Bill originally presented by Senator Evans. The defects of the original proposal were, I think, obvious when one attempted to suggest a particular hard case for presentation in relation to that proposal. The original notion was virtually a version of the rolling triennium idea in a sense in that there was not a fixed beginning or end but there was always three years in between. But that is almost precisely the current convention-that we ought to have a three-year space between elections. The original legislation sought to enforce that except under conditions which are almost identical to the propositions today. The amendment Senator Evans has moved is one which he has developed from the initial point I put to him in discussion. I think the development of that has now presented us with a very useful device.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a device which does not impinge on the ability of a government to seek a mandate under conditions already described in the previous clauses. If that government lacks the confidence of the lower House and seeks and gains from the Governor-General permission to hold an election for the House of Representatives alone, it can do so. But it would do so under this amendment with the proviso that it has only the rest of its term to serve. In other words, while it is open to a government to seek that mandate it has pressure upon it to think excessively carefully about it. I believe that is probably about as far as we are able to go with the parliamentary system we have. We are not able to go to the extent of the American system. It would be totally unworkable in a parliamentary system where the Executive is within the legislature.

I believe this amendment simply says to a government which is seeking a new mandate and calls an election today or tomorrow, for example, that the incoming government would have only to the end of the next year in which to serve. I believe that would put enormous pressures on the government to think again about calling an election merely because the time is opportune or calling an election which is unnecessary in terms of the interests of the country. If it were obviously in the interests of the country and if the government held it to be so , the government could go with confidence to the people. That is an essential element that we must not lose sight of.

Under this amendment the government may go to the people and seek a renewal of its mandate. The only problem is that that mandate would be limited in terms of the duration of the three-year cycle. That would mean that the Senate's term would be unimpeded. The Senate would go almost invariably for a fixed six-year term. The only case in which that would not occur would be under a double dissolution, and it would be most unlikely that a double dissolution would occur . In a sense, while leaving the Senate alone, this provision is able to put pressure on the House of Representatives to look again at using an election as a totally political device rather than as an expression of the will of the people.

I think this is a useful amendment. It does not impede in any way the government from seeking an election and if the Governor-General agrees it would then be able to seek again a mandate from the people, but it does restrict it. This provision is one which operates in other constitutions. It seems to be one which is workable. It is one which I believe is certainly worth putting to the people of this country for their consideration. I again draw the attention of honourable senators to the fact that that is what we are talking about today. We are not talking about passing a Bill; we are talking about putting to the people for their consideration a proposal about fixed terms for the Parliament, which I believe is part of our democratic process. If the people reject it, that is their right. But I believe they ought to have put to them a good, workable proposal to see whether they want it. That is why I support this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to draw attention to one point. I am not moving this as an amendment as we are really producing a discussion document. 'Transitional

This amendment sets out, so far as the duration of the House of Representatives is concerned, the basic fixed term rule in its proposed new modified form. Indeed, it perhaps sets it out rather more clearly than was the case in section 13 where the debate on the proposed new modified fixed term rule in fact largely already occurred. I simply say that the effect of the new section 28 draft will be as follows: In the event of the House expiring in the ordinary way, after seeing out its full three-year term, the House is dissolved on the last Thursday in October and the election is held on the third Saturday in November. In the event of the House being prematurely dissolved as a result of the defeat of the Government in the House of Representatives and the inability of any alternative government to command a majority, the provision is that the newly elected House does not, unless the extraordinary election occurs within three months of the ordinary scheduled date, commence a new three-year cycle but merely serves out the remainder of the original term.

This revised version of section 28 further provides that in the event of a double dissolution which, of course, cannot by virtue of section 57 of the Constitution, which it is proposed should not be altered in this respect, occur within the last six months of the Government's term, the newly elected House of Representatives merely serves out again the remainder of the original term.

Finally, I draw the Committee's attention to the existence of complicated, but I assure the Committee, appropriate transitional provisions to cover the initial implementation of these provisions. I think that the debate on this clause is essentially exactly the same debate we have had in the context of section 13-the concept of the restoration of the cycle that is here involved. I commend the amendment to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Might I suggest that it would suit the convenience of the Senate if clauses 8 and 9 and amendments No. 3, 4 and 5 were treated together. Essentially, what is involved here is a proposed concept of the Senate's money power under section 53 of the Constitution. —It has been drawn to my attention that Senator Macklin proposes moving an amendment to one of your amendments. In that respect it might be preferable if the clauses were dealt with separately.
