SPEECH.PARA: I move amendment No. 3 circulated in my name:
(3) Page 5, clause 8, lines 10 and 11, leave out 'appropriating revenue or moneys or imposing taxation', substitute 'to which the seventh paragraph of this section applies'.

The effect of the amendment is as follows: The original proposal was, to put it bluntly, that the powers of the Senate with respect to all classes of money Bill -taxation and appropriation Bills-should be removed; that the Senate have no power at all to reject or in any other way block or obstruct the passage of such Bills. Of course, that is consistent with the philosophy of the Labor Party concerning the role of this place. I do not in any way seek to withdraw from that basic philosophy. However, upon mature reflection it seemed that the prospects for a successful passage of this measure might be enhanced if some modification of that original stance occurred. Therefore the proposal, as it is now put to the Senate, provides that only a relatively moderate further limitation be placed on the Senate's existing, already somewhat limited, money powers.

It is proposed that the limits imposed be, first of all, in respect of proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government-which means in practice appropriations of the kind contained in our present Budget Appropriation Bill (No. 1), the supplementary Appropriation Bill (No. 3) and Supply Bill (No. 1), which recur each year. I believe that the concept of ordinary annual services is sufficiently familiar to honourable senators as not to require any more elaborate treatment than saying that.

It is further provided by the proposed amendment to clause 8, in other words to section 53 of the Constitution, that a limitation shall be imposed on the capacity of the Senate in respect of those tax laws which are certified by the Governor-General in Council to be necessary for the purpose of raising revenue for the ordinary annual services of the Government. But rather than that being a provision at large, which would in fact limit the capacity of the Senate to deal adversely with, in effect, any tax measure that could be so described, it is provided that only one such message can be given by the Governor-General each year.

The practical expectation is that such a message would be given in respect of the annual package of Budget tax measures. What this is all about, when stripped back to plain language, is a proposal that the Senate's money Bill power should be limited in respect of the basic Supply Bills on which the survival of the Government depends; also, that the Senate's money powers should be further amended in respect of those money raising measures which are, in turn, necessary for the survival of the government of the day. What this proposal, if passed, would guarantee is that the Government's Budget package of Bills each year would survive the depredations of the Senate quite unscathed. This measure, which I presume would appeal to the present Government-and I would be interested to hear any view that Senator Chaney has on it-would further guarantee that the basic Supply or Appropriation Bills each year, those passed in May, October and November, after the presentation of the Budget and supplementary appropriations respectively, would also survive unscathed. To that extent, this measure is one which, unashamedly, seeks to limit one aspect at least of this Senate's power, a power that in 1974 was asserted in spectacular circumstances for the first time in our history and again was asserted in even more spectacular circumstances, and more controversially, in 1975.

The measure, for reasons which I think it is necessary for me to explain, is very much a part of the fixed term concept. It might be thought at first blush that measures of this kind have nothing to do with bringing about fixed term parliaments. But of course, as I have said quite unashamedly right from the outset of this debate, I see fixed term parliaments as having not just one but two rationales. One obviously is to introduce a greater degree of stability, less uncertainty, into the election cycle and remove the capacity of the Prime Minister of the day to call elections according to his own opportunistic whim, but I and the Labor Party have also said from the outset that there is another cognate motivation for proposing this measure. That is, that it would solve the problems of 1975 which, in our calmer and saner moments, we readily concede to each other are still with us. We concede to each other, often only regrettably, off the record, that there are problems in the way in which the Constitution is structured, problems which can bring home serious consequences for governments of both political colours if matters should continue to proceed along the path that was mapped out in 1975.

So the fixed term parliament concept has all along been motivated, at least partially, by a desire to find a solution of this particular aspect of the problem, which most people would agree to be one of Senate power. To an extent it can be argued that having a fixed term system in place creates a set of dynamics which will operate against the Senate exercising these particular Supply blocking types of powers, without the necessity to change the language of section 53 itself.

That argument has been put to me by many right from the outset, including even those who are quite sympathetic to the desire to limit the effective capacity of the Senate to block Supply. It has been said, and I have taken the point myself, that if the Constitution effectively prohibits an early election being called there is no point in the Senate exercising its Supply blocking powers to force to the polls a government that it does not like-there is a constitutional prohibition on that actually occurring.

The difficulty about that argument is several-fold. One concerns the particular qualified model of a fixed term parliament for which we have opted. It might be a very strong argument in the context of a totally unqualified fixed term system , but that is not the model that, for a whole variety of other reasons which we have debated at other times, we propose. As a result, there are weaknesses in that scenario. For a start, if the pre-conditions for a double dissolution are there, if the trigger mechanism is in place by virtue of some prior rejection by the Senate of a House of Representatives measure, it is of course possible, as occurred in both 1974 and 1975, for the Senate to block Supply and in effect hold the gun at the head of the Government, saying: 'The pre-conditions for double dissolution are satisfied. You can go to an election technically right now without waiting for three months to elapse pursuant to section 57 as a result of our blocking of supply, and you must go.' So if the trigger is cocked in that way it will still be possible for the Senate to exercise that role. The second problem which arises is based upon the other qualification to the fixed term principle, and that is that an early election can take place, as we have agreed, where a government is the subject of a no-confidence resolution in the House of Representatives.

Accordingly, it can be argued and has been argued that a Senate bent upon the destruction of the government of the day, even in the absence of a double dissolution trigger mechanism being in place, could say to the government of the day: 'We are blocking Supply. You must go to the polls.' To the answer from that government that the Constitution does not allow it to go to the polls, the Senate could then say: 'Well, you pass a resolution of no confidence in yourself .' That point has been made by Senator Lewis and others who have claimed that this was in fact a weakness of the fixed term system because it would always be possible for a government of the day to beat the system by passing a vote of no confidence in itself. Whilst it is difficult to imagine any sane government doing that of its motion, it is perhaps not difficult to imagine a government doing that in the context of a threat of national disarray and disruption of the kind that could be created by the Senate's blocking Supply. So there is that possibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have done it repeatedly in West Germany, haven't they?

—They have not done it repeatedly in West Germany. That is about as good as Senator Lewis's other examples from the United States. If he is going to quote some exotic German professors from the University of Heidelberg or elsewhere I will be delighted to hear him before this particular debate is over.
—What about Willy Brandt in 1972? Isn't that what he did, effectively?

—We are getting away from the basic argument which I would love to debate but this is not the occasion to do so about what the Senate can force the House of Representatives to do and not what the House of Representatives might be minded to do if it thought it could persuade the electorate that it was behaving rationally in so doing. So if we approach this issue from the point of view of seeking to find a mechanism to reduce the possibility of utterly disruptive 1975-type conflict, then there are weaknesses in the capacity of this Bill, in the absence of a section 53 provision of the kind I am proposing to secure that result. Of course, if one approaches this from the perspective of Senator Lewis, Senator Chaney and others who think that what happened in 1975 was terrific and would be only too delighted to have the opportunity to do it again, of course none of the argument, I am making will appeal very much to them ; nor perhaps will the further argument I make, which worries me a little, about a fixed term system coming into existence in the absence of a change to section 53. That is the argument that, far from weakening the powers of the Senate in a fixed term system, without some such modification to section 53 as I am proposing, may in fact strengthen the powers of the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: The way this would occur would be in the context of Budget negotiations where it is suggested that we might move to something like the United States scenario where the Budget would be initiated in the House of Representatives, come up to the Senate and the Senate would simply dig in its toes and refuse to pass the Budget, wanting thereby not to force the Government to the polls but to force changes in the composition of the Budget. The fact that the Constitution did not allow for an early election, and the fact that simultaneously the Constitution allowed the Senate to dig in its heels in this particular way, would create a situation that arguably could then be resolved only by negotiation over time. We would have a Mexican stand-off over the Budget with the Senate's insisting on its amendments, the House of Representatives refusing them, everyone knowing that time was ticking by and that ultimately the Budget would have to be passed in the interests of the nation, and ultimately some compromise being wrought, which is of course the thing that happens every year in the United States with the Budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why could that not happen now?

—I am making the point, Senator Hamer, that in the Australian context it is highly unlikely to happen now as the conventions such as they are left operate. But if we do introduce a fixed term system without at the same time limiting by amendments to section 53 the capacity of the Senate to interfere with the Budget, to stop the supply of money or to stop the capacity of a government to raise taxes, we are possibly letting ourselves in for that kind of longer term scenario. It might take some time to develop but it is something that we have to take seriously. Again, the Senate chauvinists in our midst will say 'whacko, that is a further development in the historical process of over-weening power being vested in the Senate and a further wholly desirable change in the direction of currupting the equality of Australian democracy'. I would hope that the saner heads in the Senate, among whom I hope Senator Missen counts himself, along with Senator Martin and Senator Bonner-there is no doubt at all about Senator Hamer-would reflect upon the point I am making and appreciate that really one does need some amendment modification to section 53 if we are to have a fixed term system in place which does not create potentially greater difficulties for this nation than even we arguably experienced in 1975. For all those reasons, I commend this amendment to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose this clause and clause 9 because the two arguments are linked.
—We are dealing only with clause 8 at the moment.

—I am merely foreshadowing my opposition. I will not speak on it. The two things are linked together. There is some force in the argument that Senator Evans has expressed that this is not necessarily an ideal situation. In fact we could have a situation where there would be a stand-off between houses as there is in the United States quite constantly and where it has to be resolved with some sense.
—It could be under the present system.

—Yes, it could be here too and, of course, here there is no reason why a double dissolution might be a way out for a government because, if there are no Bills in place, there is no way that the Senate could be sent off to the electors. That has long been recognised as one of the really unsatisfactory features of our present system.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, there is a lack of an ideal situation in both the present system and what is proposed. It is possible that we might find disruption at some time because the Senate will not pass the Budget and cannot force an election but can cause embarrassment. I am inclined to think that political realities would soon force a Senate which no longer had the opportunity to cause an election to think twice about it. So far as the general power that is proposed to be modified by this clause is concerned, I made some comments on this on 25 March. I will just repeat a few words. I said:

I might say that, in any ideal climate, I would cheerfully see the removal of the Senate's ultimate power to refuse supply or defeat money bills. I do not see it as essential to the Senate's real work, as a house of review of legislation and as a powerful investigatory House. It is a weapon altogether too potent and destructive, a blunt instrument which may be used at any time by the politically ambitious-usually residing in the House of Representatives. I do not regard the use of this weapon in 1975 as a sign of Senate power but rather of weakness.

I stand by those remarks which I made then and I say that, as a separate matter, I think there should be some consideration of the Supply power. But one has to face realities in this matter. Any suggestion at present of a change of the rights of the Senate over Supply, which is exaggerated very much in the public eye as being some tremendously important thing rather than a blunt instrument around our necks, raises immediately the possibility of a host of enemies around Australia. If one is going to pass a sensible change-if there is any possibility of it-I say to Senator Evans that we cannot incorporate this excrescence, which it is, in the one proposal. He knows how difficult it is for constitutional referenda to be carried in any event, especially where they are complicated and where they cover a number of subjects. Indeed, this would be rolling into one Bill two very important arguments. I have not the slightest doubt where the basis of controversy would happen in a campaign. It would be exaggerated if this in fact were seen. It was seen in a mini way in the debate on the second reading in this chamber where the eloquence of Senator Crichton-Browne was devoted very substantially to an attack on the Supply power, on the precious power of the Senate and not on the fixed term issue. That is what one would expect to happen if this became a public debate by way of referendum. No matter what amendments and variations may be proposed, if the extraneous idea of changing the powers of the Senate is brought in, instead of doing what the concept of fixed terms really does, that action creates a by-pass operation. It enables us to get around the blockage which has been occurring in public thinking for a long time and ensures that there will not be much use in using the power over Supply or using that argument in the public controversies that occur. Therefore, I believe that we should stick to this as a fixed term proposal and have it rigidly expressed in that way before the public. For that purpose we should remove clauses 8 and 9.

TALK.START.PARA: —Like Senator Missen, I oppose clause 8. I foreshadow that I will oppose clause 9. My remarks will address both clauses. I should make it clear also that I will be opposing Senator Macklin's amendment. I will oppose each for the same reason. The clauses are extraneous to the Bill. They are not, in my view, necessary. Senator Evans painted a number of scenarios under which they might be necessary. The one to which he gave most weight was what he called the Mexican stand-off, that is, that this chamber could negotiate each year on the Budget knowing that the Government had to have the Budget through by the end of November or whatever date was appropriate. That is possible now. It does not happen now. It is a thing with which we live now. I find no very great difficulty in envisaging living with it under conditions of fixed term parliaments. Circumstances will be no different because of fixed term parliaments. If they were, the provisions for a double dissolution would apply in both circumstances. I am not fussed at all about that. The reason I do not like this provision is that I want the public and the people interested in this matter to have a look at the fixed term concept as a concept. Once we bring in this highly controversial and contentious issue, the Senate's power over money Bills and over Supply will receive attention; and this proposal will fail for that reason. In my submission, there is no way that we would get a Bill to change the Senate's money power through a referendum in this country.
—How confident are you that you will get a referendum through without this clause, given the attitude of your mates on the front bench?

—If Senator Evans is asking me that question, I must say that I have no confidence that this will go to a referendum in the near future. What I hope is that, arising out of this issue, there will be a serious debate on the relative merits of fixed term parliaments against the present system without emotion, inaccuracy and irrelevancies which, I am afraid, clouded the debate to some extent in the past. We should look at the matter seriously. We may decide not to go ahead, but let us look at it in its own right. Let us not clutter it up with total irrelevancies on the Senate's power over Supply, which argument will, by its very weight, sink this proposal which I think is quite good. I do not want to see it destroyed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also will oppose clause 8. I fully support the proposition that Senator Hamer has put forward. I have circulated to honourable senators a substitute for this clause, if the Committee should so desire to have such a clause in the Bill. The proposition that I mentioned regarding clause 1-that it would be a far better Bill if it dealt with only one item-I still stand by. I believe that the amendment that I foreshadowed may very well meet all the problems that have arisen in debates on Supply since 1975. It is a proposition that ultimately increases the powers of the Senate. I believe that the part of section 53 of the Constitution which states 'The Senate may not amend proposed laws imposing taxation' ought to be deleted.

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that the Senate ought to have the power to amend and review any legislation. That is an essential development of our Federal system. On the other hand, we also need a workable Federal system. If one takes the notion that the Senate is a House of review, this may give us the clue as to where to go. The Senate ought to have the power to review every piece of legislation that comes before it. How that might be compatible in what Senator Evans is seeking to achieve with his amendment is that a government in the House of Representatives could have some confidence that it would receive Supply. I believe that could be achieved by saying that in relation to the Appropriation Bills-we really do not need to talk about taxation measures here since they flow on from year to year-the House of Representatives ought to be entitled to the level of appropriation that the Senate itself reviewed and passed in the previous year. That is the kernel of the foreshadowed amendments. If the Committee is so desirous to have such a clause within the Bill, I believe it would be preferable to that which Senator Evans has included. It is a political movement in two ways: It extends the power of the Senate to the position to which it ought to have been extended, that is, it gives the Senate the right to review every piece of legislation regardless of whether it is a money Bill or not. Essentially, that is what the Senate can do.

The difference between an amendment and a request, as we have seen within the last year, becomes an academic concern in that essentially what the Senate can do by way of request it can do by way of amendment to other Bills. The House of Representatives and the government in the House of Representatives-that is, the Executive wing of government, which is within the legislature-must also have some security of tenure. These are the contending propositions that we have had since 1975. I believe that all proposals to date, rather than to seek a consensus, have drawn the parties apart. I believe my proposal would extend the powers of the Senate and, at the same time, secure for the House of Representatives a level of appropriation that the Senate itself had considered adequate for the previous financial year. That might not be everything that the Government would wish but it would be held secure that no matter what, after 30 days, as my amendment suggests, the House of Representatives would be entitled to go to the Governor-General for the Queen's assent to the legislation as if it had passed both Houses.

If a government seeks to go beyond the mandate that the Senate itself in the previous financial year had granted, that is entirely up to the Senate. In other words, by extending the Senate's power over appropriation we are increasing that power of federation to query, to review and to reject anything that the Senate does not consider appropriate. On the other hand, by this method the House of Representatives could be content that the Senate could not prevent it from governing. It could not prevent it from receiving a due appropriation although it may not be able to receive that appropriation for all its new activities. The way out of this is to think laterally from the way we have been thinking. No proposal yet has actually considered that by technically extending the powers of the Senate we can secure for the Executive its appropriation. That is the amendment I foreshadow. If Senator Evans's clause remains intact, I will move this clause that I have circulated to honourable senators to replace it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is appropriate that we are debating this Bill at this time. The Press have had a field day. Speculation is rife throughout the nation that the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) intends to make a statement today or tomorrow about an election. I am attracted to and I will support the concept of a fixed term for the Parliament. I think it is appropriate that we are debating this matter at this time. There has been very much uncertainty because a Prime Minister can call an election 12 months before the term of the House of Representatives expires. He can do that when it is politically expedient. Therefore, I will support the Bill, but I certainly will not support clauses 8 and 9. I will not support anything that would weaken the powers of this chamber, which is the House of review and which is responsible to the States. I represent Queensland and I want to ensure that whatever is done in this place is right, proper and appropriate for the constituents I represent. I would not want to do anything that would weaken the power of the Senate. Therefore, I will not support clause 8 or clause 9.

—As would have been obvious from the second reading debate and, indeed, from the points brought forward by Government senators in speaking to this provision, the Government will oppose clause 8 in any form because of the reduction of the Senate's powers which is involved. I gather that that matter was expanded upon by Senator Crichton-Browne in his speech on this matter. We will also oppose the clause because of the general opposition of the Government to the Bill.
—I will not support the clause because I do not agree with Senator Evans on this matter.
—The question is: That the words proposed to be left out by Senator Evans's amendment be left out.
—The question now is: That the words proposed to be inserted by Senator Evans's amendment be inserted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment (3), leave out all words after 'clause 8,', insert: 'leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
''8. The Constitution is altered by omitting section 53 and substituting the following section:

'53. Proposed laws appropriating revenue or moneys, or imposing taxation, shall not originate in the Senate. But a proposed law shall not be taken to appropriate revenue or moneys, or to impose taxation, by reason only of its containing provisions for the imposition or appropriation of fines or other pecuniary penalties, or for the demand or payment or appropriation of fees for licences, or fees for services under the proposed law.

The Senate may not amend a proposed law appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government so that the sum appropriated for a service in respect of a financial year would be less than the sum appropriated for that service in respect of the immediately preceding financial year.
The Senate may not amend any proposed law so as to increase any proposed charge or burden on the people.

Where the House of Representatives passes a proposed law appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government, such that the total appropriated for those services in respect of a financial year to which that proposed law applies would be not more than the total appropriated for those services in respect of the immediately preceding financial year, and transmits it, at least one month before the date fixed under section twenty- eight of this Constitution for the expiry of the House of Representatives, to the Senate for the concurrence of the Senate and, at the expiration of one month after the date on which the proposed law is so transmitted to the Senate, the Senate has not passed the proposed law, the proposed law shall be presented to the Governor-General for the Queen's assent as if it had been passed by both Houses of the Parliament.
Except as provided in this section, the Senate shall have equal power with the House of Representatives in respect of all proposed laws.'.''.'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to indicate my reaction to Senator Macklin's amendment in the unhappy event that my amendment is defeated. What Senator Macklin's amendment purports to do is something which on the surface is very attractive to the Australian Labor Party-namely, to remove the Senate's capacity to reject or block Supply Bills at least to the extent that such Bills appropriate money for the same amount, in effect, as the previous year's Budget. That is superb as far as it goes. The trouble is that there is a bit of rottenness lying behind the skin of that shiny apple Senator Macklin has held out, and that is the other aspect of his proposed amendment to section 53, which proposes to take away the present restriction on the capacity of the Senate to amend other classes of money Bills; in particular, proposed laws imposing taxation.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst I would love to be able to go into government knowing that Supply was guaranteed, at least to that extent, I must confess that I would hate to go into government with the whole of the revenue legislation contingent upon the whims of our populists in this chamber. For those reasons, as much as in some respects it hurts, I am afraid that I must report the incapacity of the Labor Party to accept the overtures of Senator Macklin and the Australian Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now before the Committee is: That the words proposed to be left out by Senator Macklin's amendment be left out.
—Mr Chairman, in that case I crave your clarification. I thought the same words were being left out as we have in fact just moved to leave out and that we would now move to-
—No. Senator Macklin is now proposing that words be left out of Senator Evans's proposal that words be inserted.
—So Senator Macklin would be, in fact, removing the words without inserting any fresh words at this stage.
—Indeed.
—In that case I would be very happy to support Senator Macklin in his very excellent intention.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question before the Committee is that the words proposed to be left out by Senator Macklin's amendment be left out.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment to the amendment agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is: That the words proposed to be inserted by Senator Macklin's amendment be inserted.
—As Senator Macklin's amendment also involves a reduction of the powers of the Senate in an important respect, the Government is also opposed to that proposal.
—The question before the Committee is: That the words proposed to be inserted by Senator Macklin's amendment be inserted.
—The question now is: That the words proposed to be inserted by Senator Evans's amendment be inserted.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. I seek clarification. Is there anything left of clause 8?
—Yes. The question now is: That clause 8, as amended, be agreed to.
—I indicate for the benefit of honourable senators that I do not intend to pursue amendments Nos 4 and 5 which have been circulated in my name.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 5, after clause 8, insert the following new clause:
'8A. The Constitution is altered by omitting section 54 and substituting the following section:

''54. Laws appropriating revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government shall contain only such appropriation, and any law which contravenes this section shall be of no effect.''.'.
The effect of this amendment is to put some teeth into the Constitution. Currently, of course, section 54 of the Constitution states:
The proposed law which appropriates revenue or moneys for the ordinary annual services of the Government shall deal only with such appropriation.

Since we are dealing only with a proposed law then indeed there is no possibility of High Court intervention in relation to that item until it becomes law. I will admit that the amendment again contravenes the proposals that I have been supporting that we should deal only with one issue. I wish to raise it because I believe it is an issue that is current and does come within the purview of the discussions the Senate has been having. It would be more appropriate if we re-phrased the law so that a judgment could in fact be made in relation to those particular laws and they could be brought under the purview of the High Court. Hence, I have moved an amendment. I believe the indications are that the amendment will not be passed. I believe it is an item which we need to discuss at a later date, particularly the means by which the High Court is able to give interpretations in relation to the Constitution. I believe that as we move through our constitutional history this proposal may become more and more important. Many of the problems experienced in 1975 arose because of the inability of the High Court to give a deliberative type of judgment. It seems to me that now may well be the right time to look at how we can re-draw our Constitution to enable the High Court to give those types of judgments, before an event such as that which occurred in 1975 rather than after it.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the fact that we have removed clause 8 entirely from the Bill-I think the feeling of the Committee is that this is what will happen to clause 9-this particular amendment, however worthy, is irrelevant to the Bill as it will emerge from the Committee. Therefore, I suggest that the amendment should not be accepted.

—I indicate the opposition of the Australian Labor Party to this particular clause. The concept of ordinary annual service is something of a moveable feast. It is best resolved by a degree of negotiation or agreement between the two Houses of Parliament as has been the case in the past. I do not see any utility in having it made justiciable in the absence of the kind of provision that Senator Macklin was seeking to incorporate in his previous amendment. It made some sense to have it tightened up in that context. In my submission, it makes no sense at all in the absence of the success of Senator Macklin's previous amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I merely wish to indicate that the Government opposes the amendment. It is a very serious matter which would require serious consideration by the Government before it could be accepted. The Government will oppose it also in line with the argument that Senator Macklin himself advanced about keeping the Bill within narrow confines. I am surprised, in the context of that argument, that he has moved this amendment to amend the Constitution.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Clause 9.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —So far as clause 9 is concerned, I indicate to the Committee that it is my desire, as I indicated previously, to restore the original section 57 and not to proceed with the concept inherent in the original clause 9 of the Bill. Accordingly, I would urge that the Committee negative clause 9 of the Bill. I do not proceed with amendment No. 6 that was circulated in my name. The effect of that will be to leave section 57 of the Constitution untouched.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause negatived.
Consideration interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! In conformity with the sessional order relating to the adjournment of the Senate, I formally put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the Chair and report to the Senate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: South Australian Economy-Uranium

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —It being after 7 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Foreman Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I want to raise a matter which I feel ought to be brought to the attention of all South Australians. It concerns the deliberate attempt by the Tonkin Government in South Australia to mislead the public about the State's economic performance under its leadership. Figures supplied by the Australian Bureau of Statistics show clearly that the investment figures used by the Government have been fabricated. Last week the Premier claimed that of total manufacturing investment in Australia, one-fifth or 20 per cent was in South Australia. The ABS figures show that this is totally untrue and that the real figure is 7.4 per cent, less than one-twelfth. The Premier claimed also that South Australia's share of total investment in Australia was now higher than it was under Labor. Again, ABS figures show that South Australia 's share of the national investment cake has fallen from 7.5 per cent in September 1979 to the current level of just 6.3 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The Liberals have also deliberately tried to pull the wool over the people's eyes in relation to employment. The fact is that there are 51,200 people out of work in South Australia; that is, 5,300 more than in 1979. The Premier claimed also that employment has actually grown over the last three years. The fact is that total full time employment in South Australia actually fell by 1,700 between 1979 and 1982. According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, in the last year total employment fell by nearly 13,000. Finally, the Premier has claimed that there are now more job vacancies in South Australia when in actual fact the number of job vacancies has fallen by more than 50 per cent since 1979. Therefore, as I have shown, the Tonkin Liberal Government is guilty of a malicious and carefully orchestrated attempt to mislead the South Australian people.

I want now to summarise briefly the economic performance of South Australia over the last three years under the Tonkin Government. As I have already mentioned, unemployment is up by 5,300 and is now running at 9 per cent in metropolitan Adelaide and even higher at Whyalla and Mount Gambier. Youth unemployment in South Australia is now up to 29 per cent, the highest level in Australia. The average duration of unemployment has skyrocketed from 32 weeks in 1979 to 40 weeks in 1982. The number of person unemployed for each job vacancy has risen from 20 in 1979 to 50 in 1982, an increase of some 150 per cent. Of course, the unemployment figures would be much higher only for the fact that thousands of South Australian have left the State to try to find work in other States. As I indicated a moment ago, total full time employment in South Australia has fallen by 1,700 since the Liberals came to power, while in Australia as a whole total employment has risent by 300,000.

In the building industry, the level of new dwellings approved in the three months to August was 32 per cent below the 1979 level. New dwellings completed in the 1981-82 financial year were over 1,000 units below what they were in 1978 -79 under the Labor Government. In real terms, new private business premises completed in 1982 were 20 per cent below the figure achieved in 1979. New foreign investment approved in South Australia in 1980-81 was $3.4m below the 1978-79 level. So much for the achievements of the Tonkin Government.

As far as State finances are concerned, the figures show clearly that the Tonkin Government has not honoured its 1979 promises to cut taxes. In 1982-83, according to the South Australian Budget Papers, total State revenue will be $ 552m, an increase of 44 per cent over the 1978-79 level. State taxes per head of population increased from $296 in 1979 to $414 in 1982, an increase of 40 per cent. Surely the clearest indication of the Tonkin Government's incompetence in economic management is the fact that the Budget outcome in 1982-83 will be a $61 .3m deficit, compared with a surplus of $6.5m in the last year of the Labor Government. It is as a direct result of the Tonkin Government's mismanagement of the South Australian economy that the total number of people directly employed by the State Government has fallen by 5,000 since 1979. South Australia is the only State in which such a fall has occurred.

The outlook for South Australia is certainly very poor indeed, with retrenchments now occuring almost daily. An article in the Adelaide Advertiser on Wednesday by industrial reporter Michael Grealy shows quite clearly that the dramatic worsening of the State's unemployment situation is one of the reasons why the Liberals decided to go to the people in November rather than in March. I quote a small portion of the article, which states:

South Australia is well into a serious downturn in the manufacturing industry. It has not been evident for most of the year, but especially since July. The Metal Industry Association of South Australia does not expect improvements until at least the middle of next year. Its director, Allan Swinstead estimates that 10 per cent of the 40,000 jobs lost nationally in the metal industry so far this year have been lost in South Australia.
So much for Mr Tonkin's claim that South Australia is not doing as badly as other States. I quote further from the article:

Vehicle and automotive components manufacturers, so important to South Australia 's industrial base, have entered a slump that is expected to get much worse before any improvement takes place. The prospects for the housing and timber industries remain bleak. Consumer and service sectors, particularly South Australia's white goods industry, have deteriorated.

And so it goes on. The fact is that South Australia, because of its heavy dependence on the car and white goods industries, will no doubt fare worse than the other States in the next 12 months. All that the Tonkin Government can deliver is pie in the sky mining developments which will not create jobs until 1990. For instance, in the Adelaide Advertiser today we find the headline 'U- plant unlikely before 1990: Group chairman'. The article states:
A uranium enrichment plant, either in South Australia or Queensland, was unlikely to be built before 1990, the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia chairman, Mr E. F. Herbert said last night.
UEGA was looking at a time span of three to four years 'before any question of a decision to proceed with a plant is around the corner.'
The article goes on to say:
Mr Herbert said last night it was 'difficult to envisage a uranium enrichment plant coming into production until 1990'.

What South Australia needs now is a government that has the capacity to restructure our industrial base and attract diversified industries to the State. If Mr Tonkin seriously believed what he has been saying lately, he would have accepted Mr Bannon's offer to debate the issues on television. If the Liberals seriously believe their costing of Labor's programs is accurate, why are they not prepared to have both parties' programs submitted to an independent body for scrutiny? The fact is that the Liberals are becoming so desperate that they will try any underhanded or sneaky tricks to mislead the people of South Australia. What they do not realise is that the people of South Australia know that they were conned in 1979, and come 6 November I am confident that Mr Tonkin will be scourged from office and South Australia will once again forge ahead confidently under the Bannon Labor Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator Sir JOHN CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for National Development and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —That rather florid rhetoric, which was read so precisely by Senator Foreman, has some very selective defects, as I shall show. For example, let us take almost his last point-uranium enrichment. He said that what had been said was that uranium enrichment would create no jobs until 1990. But then he was careful to read what Mr Herbert had said, and that is that it was difficult to envisage it coming into production until 1990. The difference there is that building a uranium enrichment plant takes some 2,000 people quite some years, and it has to be built over those years for it to come into production by 1990. What Senator Foreman did not say, because it would have spoilt his argument, was that what the chairman of the Uranium Enrichment Group of Australia was indicating was that such a plant being built to meet the market of 1990 would create over the years some 2,000 jobs a year and, when in operation, some 800 jobs.

SPEECH.PARA: The defect of Senator Foreman's argument is that history has shown that the great time of the expansion in South Australia in jobs and industry was under the Playford Liberal Government. You yourself, Mr President, being a South Australian, will recollect that it was the Playford Government that brought to South Australia the concept of development of industry, the automotive industries, the white goods industries, the decentralisation of towns and cities , such as Elizabeth, and the great growth of jobs for what had been a State that was dependent almost exclusively on rural matters. That impetus was stifled under the Dunstan Government. The decade of the Dunstan Government was such that there was no growth of industry to speak of, to the point that the Tonkin Government was elected to office because of the stagnation of the Dunstan Government. It is worthwhile for Senator Foreman to recollect why the people of South Australia put out the Dunstan Government. It was because it was neglecting bringing in new industries. Of course, one cannot rectify the errors of a decade in the brief space of three years, but let us have a little look at this matter, bearing in mind that Senator Foreman has been very selective indeed. I note that the Premier of South Australia said in his policy speech the other night:
We inherited the highest level of unemployment in Australia in 1979.

That is something that the electors knew had come about because there had been a decade of neglect. Honourable senators will recall that Senator McLaren said recently that there had been no new industries in the Tonkin era. Today I was able to give the Senate statistics to show that in the first two years of the Tonkin Government nearly 7,000 new companies were registered and that the number of companies actually on the register increased from 39,041 in June 1980 to 41, 570 in June 1981-a net increase of 6.5 per cent in the space of that one year. Here is evidence indeed. Those figures come from the South Australian Corporate Affairs Commission. Of course, one cannot give a list of some 7,000, but some 86 manufacturing projects have had a total project cost of more than $250m completed in South Australia since October 1979. Of course, these results will not show until they are in place, but the Premier of South Australia was able to say in his policy speech a few days ago:
Since we were elected to Government-a full three-year term ago-some $1,500m has been invested in the manufacturing industry in South Australia-almost one fifth of the national total.

The fact is that the investment of sums of money during that time will reap its benefit in the years ahead. It cannot be instantaneous. We cannot have the waste of a decade of the Dunstan Labor Government and suddenly create jobs. Let us look at the kind of projects that are now being lined up. It is very important to understand that the Labor Party is knocking these projects. Suddenly, several days ago, there was some suggestion that the Roxby Downs project might not be rejected by the Labor Party. But we cannot turn back the vote in the South Australian Parliament. History has that. We cannot turn back the decision of the Federal Conference of the Labor Party on uranium. History is there for that. Indeed, industry after industry overseas asks the question how it could be sure that it could establish in South Australia if there were a change of government, because clearly the policy is to prevent those things.

Senator Foreman is very selective indeed. He forgot that the Cooper Basin-Stony Point project is something very real, because liquids are flowing down that project now to Stony Point. The installation there has created jobs. That project has a capacity for 3,000 jobs. Senator Foreman has forgotten that there is under discussion the establishment of a refinery and petrochemical industry there. All these things are tangible. There is a pipeline in position. The fluids are coming down from Cooper Basin. A very big infrastructure is developing at Stony Point. In that Iron Triangle there is the opportunity for more industries.

At Roxby Downs-which were dirty words to the Labor Party until the cool air of the election came upon that party because it was rejecting it-there is the opportunity of 1,000 jobs now, with the potential for many more thousands of jobs in the future. The tourist industry has an extra 3,000 jobs now and a potential for up to 10,000. It is not good enough to sneer and say 'Ah, Roxby Downs; that is for the years ahead'. The fundamental defect of the Labor Party is that it rejected any concept of lead time during the decade of the Dunstan Government. It did not put into place these large industries, as the Playford Government had done with the automotive industries and others. The Tonkin Government inherited a situation of stagnation. It came to office because the people rejected the inertia of the Dunstan Government.

I will not hold up honourable senators tonight. As I have said, the clear case is that the figures will demonstrate that what is being put in position now is a development of industrial infrastructure which will, under a Liberal government, provide some thousands more jobs. The Premier has said that his blueprint indicates the provision of some 30,000 more jobs in the years ahead, and that is where the solid base of government is aimed.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7.21 p.m. until 1.45 p.m., on Tuesday, 9 November 1982.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 17 August 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Are increasing numbers of pet owners buying cheaper cuts of fresh meat for animals in preference to the more expensive canned petfood.

(2) Is it possible that hydatid cysts in fresh-killed meat can pass close inspection undetected and be sold to the public, leading to human infection through contact with animals, possibly causing epilepsy, blindness and even death, depending on where tapeworm eggs are carried in the bloodstream.

(3) Will the Minister for Health initiate a public awareness campaign to warn consumers of the potential danger of feeding uncooked meat to animals by making posters available to retail outlets and pamphlets available to schools emphasising animal hygiene.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Information about the quantity and preparations of meat products purchased by pet owners is not available to my Department.

(2) Small hydatid cysts in offal can pass close inspection undetected. Such offal could be sold to the public. If eaten by the human it would not produce infection. If offal is fed in the raw state to dogs or other Canidae, the human could become infected through the faeces of such animals. The signs and symptoms occurring in the infected human depend upon the size and location of the hydatid cysts. Whilst location of the cysts is frequently in the liver and lungs, most tissues can be the site of cyst development. Involvement of vital organs could prove fatal. Epilepsy and blindness could occur from invasion of the central nervous system, although the likelihood is small.

(3) Such a campaign is the responsibility of State and Territory health authorities. Campaigns to highlight the dangers of hydatid diseases have been conducted by State and Territory health and agricultural authorities over many years. Pamphlets and other literature are available from these authorities as part of continuing campaigns. Repeated education reinforcement for the general public is the most effective means of increasing public awareness.

The National Health and Medical Research Council, at its 93rd Session in June 1982, issued the following statement which has been drawn to the attention of the relevant State and Territory authorities:
The Council noted varying practices in the States and Territories for inspection and sale of raw offal, both as pet food and for human consumption.

Although offal may be passed as fit for human consumption it could still contain hydatid cysts. Although the cysts are harmless to humans, the disease could be transmitted to pets in this way. For this reason, no raw offal should be fed to pets. All raw offal, including liver, should be thoroughly cooked before feeding to dogs.
Council suggested that the States and Territories might consider the display of posters in butcher shops as a useful means of drawing this matter to the attention of the public.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Primmer Sen C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 October 1982:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What action has been taken to investigate the threat made by Mr R. J. Smith to Mr D. W. Witheford, as outlined in a letter from the latter to the Minister for Foreign Affairs, dated 8 April 1982.
(2) Have any of the relevant files or documents lost by the Department of Foreign Affairs been found.
(3) Can the Minister provide any information as to what files and documents are missing.
(4) What stage has been reached in the Commonwealth Ombudsman's investigation into allegations of bullying of witnesses by police.
(5) Has income tax been paid on all Government moneys received by Mr Bowden and his children.

(6) Why did the Minister for Foreign Affairs seek to have the Parliament believe that the fraudulent conversion of a cheque for approximately $8,700 occurred before Mr Bowden arrived at the Hong Kong post.
(7) On what date did Mr Bowden arrive in Hong Kong.
(8) On what date was the cheque drawn.
(9) Was the evidence by Mr Henderson to Senate Estimates Committee D on 10 September 1982 a factual account of the inquiry and other matters.
(10) What action has been taken to restore the careers of those staff whom Mr Henderson had withdrawn from the Tehran Embassy at the request of Mr Bowden.
(11) Why have not both Mr Henderson and Mr Bowden been suspended from duty.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) I am advised that Mr R. J. Smith has not made any threat against Mr D. W. Witheford. There is therefore no question of an investigation.

(2 and 3) Senator Primmer asked whether certain files or documents which he described as 'relevant' and as having been lost by my Department, had been found . I note first that with respect to the documents provided to the Department of Finance investigators, those officers stated at page iv of their report, which I tabled in the House on 26 August that, and I quote:

'Access to all documents requested was provided by the Department of Foreign Affairs. While there is no technical way of establishing whether the files consulted were complete, as the file folios are not always numbered, the investigating officers were not conscious of any significant gaps in them.'

Mr Witheford has referred to the fact that some documents relating to events during the period have not yet been located. In this regard I note that a substantial quantity of original departmental documents were attached by Mr Witheford to the statement of allegations which he submitted to me for investigation on 8 April 1982 (page ii of the Finance report refers to some 95 documents). Those original documents had earlier been in the Department's custody. The removal of these documents from their authorised storage place did result in some gaps in the Department's files. As mentioned above, however, in their report the investigating officers stated that 'access to all documents requested was provided by the Department of Foreign Affairs'.

If Mr Witheford or anyone else still has official documents in his possession, he should hand those over to the Minister or to the Department to whom they belong. In this regard I repeat my statement of some six months ago that if there is in the hands of individuals any information relating to this matter, that information should be brought forward.

(4) Mr Witheford's allegations against the Federal Police are still the subject of investigation by the Police Internal Investigation Division. The report of that investigation will be transmitted to the Ombudsman.

(5) As to Mr Bowden and his children's taxation obligations, I note that this is now raised for the first time in relation to this matter. Matters relating to those taxation obligations are not matters for the Minister for Foreign Affairs but for the Commissioner of Taxation.

(6) Although it is true that there was an inaccurate reference to Mr Bowden's arrival in Hong Kong in my statement of 26 August as a result of an error in the preparation of the final draft of the statement, the details of the matter and the investigations made into it are completely clear from the report by the Department of Finance which I tabled. It is clear from that report that there is no suggestion whatsoever that Mr Bowden was in any way personally responsible for or involved with the fraudulent conversion of the cheque in Hong Kong. The matter was fully investigated by both the Hong Kong and Australian police at the time. To attempt by innuendo or inference to link Mr Bowden with that fraudulent conversion is completely unwarranted.
(7) Mr Bowden arrived in Hong Kong on 6 June 1972.
(8) The cheque was drawn on 20 October 1972.
(9) The statement made by Mr Henderson to Senate Estimates Committee D on 10 September is a factual account of the enquiry and other matters.
(10) The question of what is described as 'restoring the careers' of staff withdrawn from the Tehran Embassy has been covered in my statement of 26 August.
(11) Neither Mr Henderson nor Mr Bowden has been suspended from duty because there is no reason for them to be suspended.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Commonwealth Games: Role of Federal Police

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 24 August 1982 (Hansard, page 392) Senator Ryan asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: My question concerns the role that the Australian Federal Police will play at the forthcoming Commonwealth Games. Will members of the Australian Federal Police be sworn into the Queensland police force as special constables? Will any members of the Australian Federal Police be used to implement the much criticised Commonwealth Games Act in Queensland? Can the Minister guarantee that the Australian Federal Police will not be used at the Commonwealth Games to deny any person's right of peaceful protest? Will the Australian Federal Police be available to be used to ensure the security of National Aboriginal Conference members who will be meeting in Brisbane at that time?

Later that day, I advised that the AFP would be providing assistance for VIP protection, airport security, bomb search and mail screening-functions normally undertaken by the AFP. In addition, the AFP had been asked by Queensland to provide a liaison officer in the Queensland Police headquarters operations room and assistance in policing the marathon route. I undertook to obtain further information in relation to the assistance for the marathon route.
The Minister for Administrative Services has now provided the following further information:

The Government, after carefully considering the matter, agreed to the Queensland request for AFP assistance in policing the marathon route. Approximately 125 AFP members were involved on the morning of 8 October 1982.

Although AFP members were made special constables of the Queensland Police to provide them with appropriate general police powers, the line of command permitted AFP members manning the marathon route to remain under the command of AFP officers.
The marathon route was not notified under the Queensland Commonwealth Games Act.

The assistance requested from the AFP was provided in a professional and unobtrusive manner. In this regard, it should be noted that the marathon event was in no way marred by any demonstrations or similar activities.

As it was not possible for a full reply to be incorporated in Hansard before the marathon, I wrote to the honourable Senator on 6 October advising of the Government's decision to provide assistance for the marathon route.
